"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 一</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 一  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1"">one</br></br></a>  ""One down, 2041 to go. ;).""<br><br> ""To learn this one kanji, I recommend (#2000) this story : Bambi is in a cave, eating a side-dish of salad when trying to learn the kanjis. As he succeed to learn the kanji for """"one"""", you get jealous and decide to shoot him with a slingshot. At this moment you hear the police coming, so you hurriedly burn all the proofs into a fire (so you remove the key-words Bambi, slingshot and fire from recommend). So that when the police arrives, the only remaining clue is a single horizontal bar.""<br>#1<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 二</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 二  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2"">two</br></br></a>  Two lines.<br><br> ""Roman numeral II, written on its side.""<br>#2<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 三</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 三  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=3"">three</br></br></a>  One + two = three.<br><br> ""THREE measurements define the female shape: BUST, WAIST, and HIPS. Waist is the smallest, and for most women the HIPS are wider than the chest.""<br>#3<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 四</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 四  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=4"">four</br></br></a>  FOUR year-olds often put their FOOT (human legs) in their MOUTH - but they are too young to realize.<br><br> ""I imagine a giant devouring a human in four bites. First the giant bites off the person's head, then he bites the torso, then from the waist to the knees, and finally the giant plucks up the remaining portion of the human legs into his mouth. See the fourth bite falling in there?""<br>#4<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 五</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 五  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=5"">five</br></br></a>  三 + two vertical lines = 5.<br><br> ""This Kanji looks like a """"3"""" Kanji with two added vertical lines. 3+2= 5.""<br>#5<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 六</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 六  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=6"">six</br></br></a>  ""Indicating 6 parts of the human body: head, body, 2 arms, 2 legs.""<br><br> Six-Six-SIX ((666)) Mark of the Beast!! Imagine that dapper old beastly fellow summoning his top hat to himself. See it scamper over to him on a little pair of beastly legs.<br>#6<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 七</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 七  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=7"">seven</br></br></a>  ""This kanji is our good old seven, turned upside down.""<br><br> I wrote it upside down so I crossed it out.<br>#7<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 八</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 八  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=8"">eight</br></br></a>  """"""Hachi"""" (eight) begins with the sound of the katakana """"ha"""", and it's approximately the same character.""<br><br> The valcano hasn't erupted for 8 years.<br>#8<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 九</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 九  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=9"">nine</br></br></a>  Kinda of looks like the kanji of 1　一 with the kanji of 8 八added. So think of it as 　一＋八＝九.<br><br> ""Warning - naughty reminder A woman in the doggie style position, waiting for my NINE inches.""<br>#9<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 十</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 十  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=10"">ten じゅう</br></br></a>  ""Two needles crossing marks the spot, or you can use the Roman character for ten (rotated 45 degrees).""<br><br> I scared away ten vampires with a single cross!<br>#10<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 口</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 口  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=11"">mouth</br></br></a>  Looks like a huge open mouth.<br><br> ""Momma used to say: """"Keep your trap shut!"""" This thing is shaped like a trap door.""<br>#11<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 日</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 日  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=12"">day</br></br></a>  ""Open the window, new day.""<br><br> Picture two halves of a 24-hr period: Day & Night.<br>#12<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 月</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 月  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=13"">month</br></br></a>  A month is longer than a day.<br><br> ""Am I the only one who sees this as someone sticking their ass in the air """"mooning"""" someone (two cheeks of the butt and the legs coming off of it)? The Moon meaning connects well to the meaning of month, considering that months were traditionally measured by the phases of the moon. Also, the mooning """"ass"""" part of it connects well to Hesig's seemingly unconnected """"flesh"""" or """"part of the body"""" meaning (when used in primitive form).""<br>#13<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 田</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 田  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=14"">rice field</br></br></a>  A rice field divided into four parts.<br><br> Ten people use their mouths to eat the yield of the rice fields.<br>#14<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 目</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 目  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=15"">eye め</br></br></a>  There are 3 sections. Imagine the outer two being the whites of your eye. The middle is the pupil. Fill it in with imaginary color.<br><br> 目_目.<br>#15<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 古</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 古  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=16"">old</br></br></a>  Tombstone and cross on an old man's grave.<br><br> You get OLD fast if you have ten open mouths to feed.<br>#16<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 吾</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 吾  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=17"">I われ</br></br></a>  I have 5 senses.<br><br> I eat five times at day.<br>#17<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 冒</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 冒  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=18"">risk</br></br></a>  ""Don't look at the sun directly with your eyes, it's risky!""<br><br> You'll risk your eyesight if you look up at the sun.<br>#18<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 朋</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 朋  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=19"">companion</br></br></a>  My companion and I are like two moons side by side.<br><br> ""Under the twin moons of Tatooine, Luke had no COMPANION.""<br>#19<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 明</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 明  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=20"">bright</br></br></a>  The sun makes the moon bright.<br><br> ""The sun and the moon are brightest objects in the day and night, respectively.""<br>#20<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 唱</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 唱  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=21"">chant となえる</br></br></a>  Someone chanting with their mouth open for two consecutive days.<br><br> Chants from our mouths are meant to reach the sun and the stars. Stars are just suns just further away so they seem smaller.<br>#21<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 晶</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 晶  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=22"">sparkle</br></br></a>  A diamond sparkles as brightly as three suns.<br><br> Sparkle is a forest (#197) of suns!<br>#22<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 品</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 品  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=23"">goods</br></br></a>  Three boxes of goods are devoured by the hungry mouths of waiting consumers.<br><br> Three hungry mouths waiting for the goods to come.<br>#23<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 呂</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 呂  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=24"">spine</br></br></a>  Spine connects head and body.<br><br> The spine goes from one opening mouth/opening (mouth/face) to another mouth/opening (genitals). Just think of these openings being enlarged to represent the head and the body. The bottom is bigger because the body is bigger than the face.<br>#24<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 昌</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 昌  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=25"">prosperous&nbsp;りゅうしょう</br></br></a>  If you work from Sun UP to Sun DOWN you will be prosperous.<br><br> ""I kept getting this mixed up with meanings like 'fortune', so here is a fool proof story! Remember the Vulcan salute from 'Star Trek' (a fiction of the sci-fi genre in which heavenly bodies such as SUNS play a huge role) used with the phrase 'live long and PROSPER'? If that's not enough of a visual reminder, the Vulcan salute shows the fingers parted in to 2 sets of 2, and visually kind of looks like this kanji if you think about it.""<br>#25<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 早</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 早  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=26"">early</br></br></a>  ""The sun up is early, well before ten.""<br><br> An early sun-flower looks like a miniature sun perched on a needlelike stems.<br>#26<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 旭</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 旭  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=27"">rising sun</br></br></a>  9am carries with it the rising sun.<br><br> Nine planets revolve around our rising sun.<br>#27<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 世</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 世  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=28"">generation</br></br></a>  3 tens = generation.<br><br> ""They SAY a generation is ten+ten+ten years, with the big first ten providing a grounding, and the next ten providing a little more grounding for the final ten. But I wish the next generation didn't always SAY """"yo!"""". (ON reading is SEI, KUN reading is yo).""<br>#28<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 胃</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 胃  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=29"">stomach</br></br></a>  The rice field is harvested once a month to get food for our stomach.<br><br> ""The stomach is the part of the body that digests food (which, in Japan, is mainly rice).""<br>#29<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 旦</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 旦  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=30"">nightbreak 旦那</br></br></a>  A nightbreak happens when the sun rises over the horizon (floor).<br><br> ""It may be easier to think of the keyword """"DAYBREAK"""" or """"MORNING"""" for this kanji (other kanji dictionaries do). Then the mnemonic phrase """"SUN rising over the HORIZON"""" works better. It is an infrequent kanji, but can be found in: 旦夕　（たんせき） morning and evening, or 元旦　（がんたん） New Year's Day.""<br>#30<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 胆</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 胆  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=31"">gall bladder</br></br></a>  The moon has a lot of gall sticking around after sunrise.<br><br> <br>#31<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 亘</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 亘  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=32"">span</br></br></a>  The sun spans from horizon to horizon in a day.<br><br> The span of the day is the time between the sun goes up and comes down.<br>#32<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 凹</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 凹  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=33"">concave</br></br></a>  ""The letter """"U"""" is concavely written.""<br><br> Concave has a concave shape.<br>#33<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 凸</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 凸  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=34"">convex</br></br></a>  ""When I get vexed, I give people the middle finger.""<br><br> Convex has a convex shape.<br>#34<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 旧</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 旧  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=35"">olden times</br></br></a>  Age 18 = olden times.<br><br> The old man with a walking stick kept talking of olden times all day long.<br>#35<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 自</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 自  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=36"">oneself じ分</br></br></a>  ""Faced with his clone, our hero valiantly cut a mark on his forehead right above his eye so that his comrades could tell his true oneself from the enemy.""<br><br> ""To use an eyedropper by oneself, aim from above to put a drop into the eye.""<br>#36<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 白</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 白  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=37"">white しろ</br></br></a>  A white ray is a drop of sun.<br><br> Even a small drop (') of the sun (日) would make you see nothing but white.<br>#37<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 百</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 百  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=38"">hundred ひゃく</br></br></a>  100 turned sideways. {sort of the same as what ashoksaraf said}.<br><br> That dirty ceiling was painted WHITE a hundred times!<br>#38<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 中</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 中  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=39"">in なか</br></br></a>  Pocky goes in the mouth.<br><br> My GF lets me come in her mouth (pictogram).<br>#39<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 千</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 千  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=40"">thousand</br></br></a>  It takes many drops of ten to get to a thousand.<br><br> One T = one thousand.<br>#40<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 舌</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 舌  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=41"">tongue</br></br></a>  ""What is in a mouth that permits it to speak a thousand things? Yes, a tongue.""<br><br> Kissing a thousand mouths eventually gets you some tongue.<br>#41<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 升</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 升  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=42"">measuring box</br></br></a>  Is it a thousand or ten? I need my measuring box.<br><br> ""I can fit a thousand needles into my measuring box, but only if I bend the thousand.""<br>#42<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 昇</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 昇  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=43"">rise up</br></br></a>  ""You know that your salary has RISEN UP when your MEASURING BOX has enough dollar bills in it to reach the SUN.""<br><br> We Measure the Sun to decide when we should Rise Up out of bed.<br>#43<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 丸</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 丸  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=44"">round</br></br></a>  Nine plus a drop rounds it off to ten!<br><br> ""Watch out for plump (#120). Here Heisig could have added a """"t"""" and we would have had a much better keyword : rotund. Rotund is more specific than """"round"""" which begs for confusion with circle (#1811). A dictionary search on """"fat"""" or """"round"""" doesn't yield this kanji, but """"rotund"""" does! Primitive suggestion: the Laughing Buddha is often depicted as a rotund, smiling bald man in robes with a largely exposed pot belly stomach (symbolizing plenitude).""<br>#44<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 寸</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 寸  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=45"">measurement&nbsp;すん法</br></br></a>  The decimal system uses drops of ten as a measurement.<br><br> ""Glue two sticks together to make the best measurement. (I always remember the primitive, but never the original keyword.).""<br>#45<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 専</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 専  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=46"">specialty</br></br></a>  ""After you have chosen your <b>10 fields</b> of study, <b>measure</b> how good you are at each to find out your specialty.""<br><br> 10 brains glued together allows you to specialize in any specialty that you want. Imagine each brain having its own specialty.<br>#46<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 博</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 博  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=47"">Dr.</br></br></a>  Ten specialties grants you the title of Dr. with a dot.<br><br> ""Watch for doctor (#1694), the sooner the better! In fact this kanji refers to someone well """"learned"""", with extensive knowledge. This could apply to any kind of field. The kanji 医 (""""doctor"""") is directly related to medicine. I would suggest to take away completely the idea of medicine here, and use a popular character whose name includes the keyword such as """"Dr. Who"""", """"Dr. Jekyll"""", even """"Dr. Dobb's"""" if you're into programming.""<br>#47<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 占</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 占  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=48"">fortune-telling</br></br></a>  Fortune-telling: using a mouth as a divining rod.<br><br> ""A great number of people who do fortune-telling are """"almost old"""".""<br>#48<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 上</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 上  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=49"">above うえ</br></br></a>  A magic wand standing on above the floor.<br><br> ""Above all else, be grounded if you are going to practice augury (#2103)卜. You could turn yourself into a トoad...　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　ジョウ　以上　いじょう(above)　　　　ショウ　上人　しょうにん(saint).""<br>#49<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 下</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 下  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=50"">below した</br></br></a>  Roots are below the ground.<br><br> A magic wand hanging below the ceiling.<br>#50<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 卓</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 卓  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=51"">eminent</br></br></a>  The most eminent magician is he who learned to use his magic wand early in life.<br><br> The eminent sunflower is the one that stands above the others.<br>#51<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 朝</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 朝  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=52"">morning</br></br></a>  There is mist as the moon fades away in the morning.<br><br> ""Morning has come """"ten"""" hours """"early""""!!! The """"moon"""" is still in the sky!""<br>#52<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 只</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 只  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=53"">only ただ</br></br></a>  Imagine an animal with only a mouth and legs.<br><br> ""My girlfriend insists that the only thing I want from her is what's between her legs.. She's drawn me this pictograph to demonstrate. It's a head and two legs spread apart.. I explain that I also love her breasts, and then she smacks me in the face. I'll never understand women.. (I keep failing this kanji, hopefully this silly story will help me!).""<br>#53<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 貝</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 貝  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=54"">shellfish</br></br></a>  Eye thought I saw a shellfish legging it down the beach!<br><br> ""Stare at the shellfish, it looks like an eye with legs.""<br>#54<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 貞</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 貞  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=55"">upright</br></br></a>  A magic wand is needed to make a clam stand upright.<br><br> Just the thought of my magic wand on her clam makes my magic wand stand upright.<br>#55<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 員</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 員  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=56"">employee</br></br></a>  An employee (member of the company) has to clam up his mouth if he wants keep the job!<br><br> An employee is basically a shellfish with a mouth.<br>#56<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 見</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 見  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=57"">see みる</br></br></a>  ""As a primitive, this is Mike Wazowski from Monsters Inc. (the giant eyeball with legs...) Makes for easy stories later on.""<br><br> Eyes and legs are all you need to see the world.<br>#57<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 児</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 児  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=58"">newborn babe</br></br></a>  ""In the olden times, a newborn babe came out legs first.""<br><br> Only 18 and already got a newborn babe. Young girls are so quick to spread their legs these days...　　　RTK2:　ジ　児童　じどう　(child)　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　ニ　小児　しょうに(infant).<br>#58<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 元</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 元  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=59"">beginning げん気</br></br></a>  In the beginning were just two who walked on human legs.<br><br> ""In the beginning God created woman, and God asked her how she liked his work. Woman replied, """"Well, you know how I have two eyes, two arms, two legs... it seems redundant to have three breasts. It would look more symmetrical with two."""" God nodded, and the middle breast fell off... and it was good. Woman picked up the breast and said, """"Thank you, God! But what do I do with this useless boob?"""" And God created man. That's why the women today only have two boobs to match their two human legs.""<br>#59<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 頁</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 頁  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=60"">page</br></br></a>  A shellfish carrying a page balanced on its head.<br><br> One drop of ink from a shellfish can fill a whole page.<br>#60<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 頑</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 頑  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=61"">stubborn</br></br></a>  A stubborn person in the <b>beginning </b>gets something into their <b>head</b> and can't change their mind.<br><br> ""Picture a STUBBORN schoolboy, with his arms crossed and his book still open to the BEGINNING PAGE. Despite the teacher telling him to turn the page, he refuses and keeps his book on the BEGINNING PAGE.""<br>#61<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 凡</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 凡  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=62"">mediocre</br></br></a>  A drop of breeze is naught but a mediocre wind.<br><br> Is there anything as mediocre as a drop of piss in the wind?<br>#62<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 負</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 負  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=63"">defeat まける</br></br></a>  ""Tied up, the shellfish had to accept defeat!""<br><br> Defeat is defined by a shellfish in binds.<br>#63<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 万</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 万  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=64"">ten thousand まん</br></br></a>  I bound ten thousand dollars together and hid it under the floor.<br><br> ""We have """"one"""" at the top and if you turn the kanji 90 degrees you will see arabic 4 shich means it has four zeros in front of it!""<br>#64<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 句</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 句  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=65"">phrase</br></br></a>  Some Japanese phrases are difficult to wrap your mouth around.<br><br> A bound mouth cannot utter a single phrase.<br>#65<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 肌</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 肌  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=66"">texture はだ</br></br></a>  When you expose your flesh to the wind it gets textured: goosebumps!<br><br> <br>#66<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 旬</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 旬  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=67"">decameron じゅん</br></br></a>  Hesig should be BOUND for a DAY (or maybe 10 days - a decameron) for calling this Kanji DECAMERON. See martyrdom (#809).<br><br> ""If you bind up ten days, you get a decameron.""<br>#67<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 勺</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 勺  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=68"">ladle</br></br></a>  A ladle binds drops together.<br><br> Forget about the primative 'bound up'. Imagine instead the shape of a ladle and holding it upside down to drink the last DROP (of water).<br>#68<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 的</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 的  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=69"">bull's eye てき</br></br></a>  I managed to hit the bull's eye by throwing my white ladle.<br><br> ""A white, bound up, drop in the center is the bull's eye. (why Heisig had to use """"ladle"""" instead of the original two primitives that make up """"ladle"""" I'll never understand!).""<br>#69<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 首</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 首  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=70"">neck</br></br></a>  ""The V shape is your neck on top of your collar bone, or the straight line. Yourself, or the rest of your body is below that!""<br><br> The mooses neck supports it's big horns and long nose.<br>#70<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 乙</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 乙  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=71"">fish guts</br></br></a>  ""This is a fish hook, that pulls out the fishguts.""<br><br> You cut a fish in a z shape on the belly to make it easier to open the fish and rip out its fish guts silly!<br>#71<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 乱</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 乱  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=72"">riot 混乱</br></br></a>  <br><br> A tongue with a hook can cause a riot.<br>#72<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 直</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 直  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=73"">straightaway</br></br></a>  ""If you get a needle in your eye that is hooked in there, get to a hospital straightaway.""<br><br> ""I caught a freaky creature with ten eyes on my fish hook, so I threw it back straightaway.""<br>#73<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 具</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 具  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=74"">tool</br></br></a>  Keep an eye on your tools while you work at the table.<br><br> ""One tool nobody should be without - a Mordor-type eye that floats over the workbench. It jerks around, monitoring all who come near, and if anyone so much as removes a stapler from the bench - ZAP.""<br>#74<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 真</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 真  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=75"">true まっ直ぐ</br></br></a>  A compass is a <b>tool</b> with a <b>needle</b> on top that points to true north.<br><br> Ten tools are all a true craftsman needs.<br>#75<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 工</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 工  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=76"">craft</br></br></a>  I consider craft to be one of the harder primitives to use in stories so I've personified it as Bender the crafty robot from Futurama who was designed to bend I-beams.<br><br> I crafty.<br>#76<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 左</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 左  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=77"">left</br></br></a>  ""The LEFT side of my brain posesses the faculties needed for logical crafts, like engineering.""<br><br> ""The left side of my brain, is for crafts.""<br>#77<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 右</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 右  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=78"">right みぎ</br></br></a>  The right hand is for putting food in your mouth. (The other hand is for ass-wiping!).<br><br> Always keep your right to free speech (mouth) by your side!<br>#78<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 有</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 有  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=79"">possess</br></br></a>  ""Possessed by the Earth's gravity, the moon stays by its side.""<br><br> ""By my side I POSSESS a moon of flesh, better known as your big ass!""<br>#79<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 賄</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 賄  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=80"">bribe&nbsp;</br></br></a>  ""To bribe someone, money is a necessary possession.""<br><br> ""If you possess enough shellfish, you can bribe anyone.""<br>#80<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 貢</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 貢  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=81"">tribute</br></br></a>  """"""This next song is a TRIBUTE to a little SHELLFISH friend of mine who was tragically crushed by an I-shaped table."""".""<br><br> Tribute is the craft of raising money.<br>#81<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 項</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 項  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=82"">paragraph</br></br></a>  To write a paragraph is the craft of grouping sentences on a page.<br><br> ""To craft a page well, we need paragraphs.""<br>#82<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 刀</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 刀  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=83"">sword かたな</br></br></a>  ""This SWORD is so sharp, it can cut the top part of カ off in カタナ.""<br><br> If you look really close this kanji looks like a person bending over touching the ground Waiting for someone to put there sword in his ass!<br>#83<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 刃</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 刃  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=84"">blade</br></br></a>  The part of a sword where a drop of blood can usually be found is the blade.<br><br> A drop of blood on the blade of my sword.<br>#84<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 切</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 切  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=85"">cut きる</br></br></a>  The <b>seven</b> samurai used their <b>swords</b> to cut their opponents.<br><br> Seven swords cut better than one.<br>#85<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 召</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 召  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=86"">seduce</br></br></a>  ""A man is easily seduced by a mouth to his """"sword."""".""<br><br> To seduce is to make a sword of one's mouth.<br>#86<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 昭</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 昭  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=87"">shining</br></br></a>  Shining is the sun's seduction.<br><br> The sun was shining so bright that it seduced Icarus and he flew too close.<br>#87<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 則</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 則  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=88"">rule</br></br></a>  ""When you have both money and the power of the sword, you can make the rules.""<br><br> ""If you've got CRABs on your SABER, then you didn't follow the rules of safe sex!""<br>#88<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 副</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 副  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=89"">vice- ふく</br></br></a>  ""The wealthy guy with the sword standing next to the king, that's the vice-roy who does all the dirty work.""<br><br> Vice-president Cheney: a wealthy saber rattler.<br>#89<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 別</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 別  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=90"">separate べつ</br></br></a>  I don't know about you but to me this seems like someone's head is about to be separated from his body. You can see he's kneeling and his mouth is wide open gasping for the last breath he will ever take.<br><br> A wise old samurai keeps his hostages (with their mouths bound up to keep them quiet) in a separate room from his sabers. Putting them together would be a silly mistake.<br>#90<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 丁</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 丁  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=91"">street</br></br></a>  ""Today, the program """"Sesame Street"""" is brought to you by the letter """"T"""".""<br><br> Two streets make a T-intersection.<br>#91<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 町</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 町  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=92"">town</br></br></a>  ""Actually this means town, like one that has lots of streets and is surrounded by all the rice fields.""<br><br> ""Getting this one confused with Town is easy, so remember it with this rhyme. """"Pillage the village, for the rice and and the tea."""" the street primitive on the right looks like a 't'.""<br>#92<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 可</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 可  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=93"">can 可笑しい</br></br></a>  ""A mouth on the street asking for things: """"Can I get some help?! Can I get directions, Can I have some money? Can you please speak English?!"""".""<br><br> I can eat nails.<br>#93<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 頂</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 頂  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=94"">place on the head&nbsp;いただき</br></br></a>  If I put a street sign on my head what do I get ? A place on the head !<br><br> ""NAILS - place directly on the forehead, NAILS - place directly on the forehead, NAILS - place directly on the forehead, 　　　The HEAD ON commercial nails it into your head......""<br>#94<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 子</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 子  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=95"">child</br></br></a>  A child who is ten will still ask for his ma (top looks a bit like katakana ma).<br><br> ""A pictograph of a child, with arms outstretched for mother (or perhaps because she is chasing a rat?). Note that this kanji occupies the first space on the Zodiac circle, and is the sign for the rat (such as 2008!).""<br>#95<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 孔</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 孔  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=96"">cavity</br></br></a>  The <b>child's</b> arms flailed around at the sight of the <b>hooked</b> tool the dentist was going to use to fill his cavity.<br><br> ""I warned him about cavities, but the child is still hooked on sweets.""<br>#96<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 了</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 了  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=97"">complete</br></br></a>  The experiment was a complete failure! The child was made without any arms!<br><br> A child with the arms inside the blanket will be completely wrapped up.<br>#97<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 女</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 女  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=98"">woman</br></br></a>  ""To remember the order of strokes, remember a female ninja is called a """"kunoichi"""". That is, く(hiragana) ノ(katakana) 一(kanji, ichi=one).""<br><br> My mother taught me that a woman should always sit with her legs crossed (but the arms can be stretched out).<br>#98<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 好</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 好  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=99"">fond すき</br></br></a>  A woman is fond of her child.<br><br> ""Jane Fonda carrying a Vietnamese child. Pro-war protesters hold signs, """"I'm not fonda Jane!""""...　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　コウ　好評　こうひょう(favorable criticism).""<br>#99<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 如</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 如  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=100"">likeness</br></br></a>  ""Women share a common likeness. Their mouths are always open, whining about this and that.""<br><br> From a woman's other 口comes a baby with a perfect likeness.<br>#100<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 母</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 母  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=101"">mama はは</br></br></a>  The two breasts of a momma who breastfeeds.<br><br> ""This mama had twins, one mouth for each nipple.""<br>#101<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 貫</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 貫  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=102"">pierce つらぬく</br></br></a>  Ariel the Little Mermaid's clamshell bra was held to her breasts by piercings.<br><br> The sad fate of Mama shellfish was to be captured and pierced to make an earring.<br>#102<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 兄</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 兄  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=103"">elder brother</br></br></a>  My elder brother was basically a mouth on legs when he was a teenager.<br><br> ""Mother, why is elder brother's mouth between the neighbor girl's legs? RTK2:　ケイ　父兄　ふけい　(father and elder brother)　　　　　　　　　キョウ　兄弟　きょうだい(brothers)…　　　　　　　　　　　　　MIXED GROUP:　(ｺｸ): 克104　(ｷｮｳ): 況145　競434　(ｼｭｸ): 祝1089.""<br>#103<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 克</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 克  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=104"">overcome こく服</br></br></a>  Ten elder brothers can overcome anything.<br><br> A teenager addicted to heroine must overcome the needle.<br>#104<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 小</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 小  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=105"">little</br></br></a>  A little penguin with its wings at its side.<br><br> ""A depressed child, head low and arms hung low, because he's too little to ride the roller coaster.""<br>#105<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 少</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 少  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=106"">few</br></br></a>  Only a few people can make an ugly face like that.<br><br> ""Few usually refers to three. To emphasize three, we underline the three drops in little.""<br>#106<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 大</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 大  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=107"">large</br></br></a>  A person stretching their arms and legs to look large and scare a bear away.<br><br> Think of a large St. Bernard dog with his paws all stretched out.<br>#107<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 多</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 多  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=108"">many</br></br></a>  Two evenings too many!<br><br> ""This reminds me of a childish pseudo-confucion rhyme: """"He who eats many prunes sits on toilet many moons"""".""<br>#108<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 夕</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 夕  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=109"">evening</br></br></a>  ""The evening is young, the moon is not full.""<br><br> ""In the evening, I try my best to remember the katakana symbol for """"TA"""" (ie. """"ta ta!"""").""<br>#109<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 汐</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 汐  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=110"">eventide しお</br></br></a>  ""Eventide is just another word for evening, and it has the word tide in it which we associate with water.""<br><br> Drops of water shower the beach as the evening tide approaches: eventide.<br>#110<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 外&nbsp;</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 外&nbsp;  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=111"">outside そと</br></br></a>  A young magician likes to practice outside in the evening with his magic wand (as opposed to the old magician who wakes early to practice with his wand in eminent (#51)).<br><br> ""Outside in the dark of evening, only a magic wand can help you.""<br>#111<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 名</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 名  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=112"">name</br></br></a>  ""In the evening, when it becomes dark, open your mouth to say your name so that people can recognise you.""<br><br> ""In the evening, her sweet mouth whispered my name.""<br>#112<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 石</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 石  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=113"">stone</br></br></a>  Indiana Jones jumps up and grabs the lip of cliff just in time to evade the huge STONE rolling out of the mouth of the cave!<br><br> ""There's a VERY simple way to remember this, in case the cliff thing isn't working for you... Just see it as a stone [いし] being hammered by a miner searching for jewel stones [ほうせき] ;).""<br>#113<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 肖</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 肖  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=114"">resemblance</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""Hey baby, it might be a little bit of flesh now, but in a moment it'll bear a strong resemblance to a candlestick.(nudge nudge, wink wink).""<br>#114<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 硝</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 硝  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=115"">nitrate</br></br></a>  That stone has sparks coming out of it! Someone must have poured nitrate acid on it.<br><br> <br>#115<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 砕</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 砕  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=116"">smash</br></br></a>  To SMASH a STONE you need to hit it NINE or TEN times.<br><br> The Stones (the Rolling Stones) are 90 aged but they've done a new SMASH hit!<br>#116<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 砂</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 砂  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=117"">sand</br></br></a>  ""Here's how I remember that stone is on the left. This is because sand starts as stones, and only later they become few.""<br><br> ""In good SAND, stones are few, if any.""<br>#117<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 削</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 削  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=118"">plane けずる</br></br></a>  Sparks will fly if you attempt to PLANE your sabre.<br><br> ""With today's strict air regulations, carrying a sabre onto a plane could spark quite a commotion.""<br>#118<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 光</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 光  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=119"">ray ひかり</br></br></a>  A ray of light is not a wave but made of little photons with human legs.<br><br> The ray from Honey I Shrunk the Kids made people little - ha! look at them run around on their tiny legs!<br>#119<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 太</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 太  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=120"">plump</br></br></a>  A large person with a big drop of sweat dripping off of him because he is so plump.<br><br> ""Fat(""""plump"""") men always have small penises.....the kanji is a combination of """"large"""" with a drop(representing the small penis between his legs).""<br>#120<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 器</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 器  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=121"">utensil</br></br></a>  Imagine four hungry mouths all sitting around the table. They are all banging their utensils on the table waiting for a big meal to be placed in the centre.<br><br> ""Note: 器 by itself means container/caliber/vessel. And 食器 means eating utensils (""""food container"""", hehe).""<br>#121<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 臭</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 臭  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=122"">stinking くさい</br></br></a>  The ST. BERNARD DOG lifted his large NOSE high in the air to find out where the stinking smell comes from.<br><br> <br>#122<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 妙</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 妙  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=123"">exquisite&nbsp;奇妙</br></br></a>  Exquisite women are few and far between.<br><br> ""A geisha is an exquisite and delicate (another meaning of this kanji) women, however, even in the past there was only few of them.""<br>#123<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 省</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 省  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=124"">focus</br></br></a>  You focus by concentrating your eye on fewer objects.<br><br> Success (or survival?) method for accelerated juggling course: focus on a few nitroglycerine filled juggling balls flying OVER your eyes ---(I have trouble with this few primitive that can be anywhere in a kanji. To build in its location in the story is important somehow).<br>#124<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 厚</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 厚  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=125"">thick あつい</br></br></a>  ""In Sparta we throw our Children over a Cliff. Under the Sun, they fight other Children. In the end, if they survive, they sure have thick skin.""<br><br> The thick cliff walls protected the children from the sun.<br>#125<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 奇</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 奇  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=126"">strange</br></br></a>  ""I find it strange that so many people commit suicide in Tokyo by throwing themselves in front of the train. To me when I look at this kanji, I see a train just about to come out of a tunnel, and above the man waiting for his oppourtunity where he can end it all.""<br><br> Imagine a ST. BERNARD DOG carrying a CAN instead of a barrel in rescue missions. How strange!<br>#126<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 川</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 川  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=127"">stream かわ</br></br></a>  So as not to confuse this with river (#146) think of streamers falling down.<br><br> ""There are three default I/O Streams in UNIX, stdin, stdout, and stderr.""<br>#127<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 州</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 州  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=128"">state</br></br></a>  There were 3 little islands in the stream who all decided to set themselves up as independent states.<br><br> ""シュウ　The original meaning of this character was """"sandbar"""", and for me this conjures up images of the Mississippi River, which is very wide with many sandbars and which was used to define the borders in ten American states. Picture Huck Finn and Tom Sawyer floating by state after state as they adventure down the mighty Mississippi, occasionally beaching their raft on sandbars.""<br>#128<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 順</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 順  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=129"">obey&nbsp;じゅん</br></br></a>  """"""Obey, Obey!"""" says the brain-washing scientist as he sends a stream of orders to fill your head.""<br><br> Obey the orders streaming down from head office.<br>#129<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 水</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 水  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=130"">water</br></br></a>  ""The kanji for water is an abstract primitive itself, so unless one is willing to break down its etymological development, it should just simply be memorized by strokes; constructing a story is not necessarily useful unless it strongly denotes its shape (I find that Heisig's story doesn't do this).""<br><br> ""For those having issues with this* """"A 7K foot pool of water"""" Notice it looks like a 7, and a K. Might have to practice writing it a few times.""<br>#130<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 氷</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 氷  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=131"">icicle</br></br></a>  Icicles start with 1 frozen drop of water.<br><br> A drop in temperature turns water into an icicle.<br>#131<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 永</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 永  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=132"">eternity</br></br></a>  It would take an eternity to count all the drops of water.<br><br> ""It takes but one drop from the most special water: the fountain of youth (and it is written in a special way to with an extra horizontal line on the top) to live for an eternity. (In order to remember that the drop is at the top, think that the drop must come from the topmost water in order for its effects to be true).""<br>#132<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 泉</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 泉  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=133"">spring</br></br></a>  ""White is a symbol of purety, so white water is pure water, the precise definition of spring water.""<br><br> ""Perhaps the most common appearance of this kanji is in the word 温泉 (おんせん, onsen), a Japanese hot spring. The kanji is an excellent image of someone enjoying a Japanese hot spring: a little white towel on top, water below. (This helps keep all associations: spring, little and onsen).""<br>#133<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 原</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 原  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=134"">meadow</br></br></a>  Follow the springs down the cliff and you will find a nice meadow.<br><br> ""Sorry about this, but Heisig was stupid calling this kanji meadow, used in composite words the most common meaning is ORIGIN... To remember just think that life may have begun in pounds or springs in a land with many cliffs ... Just to answer correctly the review lessons think of meadow as the origin of a huge forest.""<br>#134<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 願</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 願  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=135"">petition お願い</br></br></a>  Let's petition to save that beautiful MEADOW from overdevelopment by signing on this PAGE.<br><br> ""Japanese hippies PETITION to save a meadow by getting people on the street to sign their page - as you pass by they call out: """"お願いします、おねがいします。”.""<br>#135<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 泳</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 泳  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=136"">swim</br></br></a>  With that much WATER (2 actually) you would need to swim for an ETERNITY.<br><br> ""If you don't know how to swim, you'll be in that water for eternity.""<br>#136<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 沼</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 沼  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=137"">marsh</br></br></a>  ""The marshlands near Mordor seduce Frodo into gazing upon them, and he falls into the water--splash!""<br><br> A marsh is where water is seduced into the ground.<br>#137<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 沖</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 沖  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=138"">open sea</br></br></a>  Open sea is a lot of water in the middle of nowhere.<br><br> Water in the middle of the ocean is referred to as open sea.<br>#138<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 江</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 江  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=139"">creek</br></br></a>  A CREEK is a small trail of water easily crafted with a stick.<br><br> ""Creeks are small water, easily crossed with a simple i-beam.""<br>#139<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 汁</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 汁  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=140"">soup しる</br></br></a>  To make soup you just take water and add (+) the rest of your ingredients.<br><br> To make soup you just take water and add ten tasty ingredients.<br>#140<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 潮</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 潮  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=141"">tide ちょうせき</br></br></a>  ""The morning tide is basically, well, WATER in the MORNING.""<br><br> <br>#141<br></span>"
