"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 源</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 源  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=142"">source</br></br></a>  The water that flows from the meadow is the source of life for the wild antelope.<br><br> The source of clean water is from the meadow (#134): it comes from that spring at the bottom of the cliff. Pay no attention to Julie Andrews lying face down in spring. The water's clean. Trust me.<br>#142<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 活</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 活  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=143"">lively&nbsp;かつ</br></br></a>  ""Conversations can become more lively after everyone has had a few drinks. It's because """"watery tongues"""" loosen lips!""<br><br> I'm sure I can get her pretty lively and wet using my tongue.<br>#143<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 消</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 消  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=144"">extinguish</br></br></a>  ""To extinguish a SPARK, you need WATER.""<br><br> You need a few drops of water to extinguish the candle.<br>#144<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 況</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 況  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=145"">but of course</br></br></a>  ""If you ask your teenager if what he's drinking is water (and not Vodka), he will answer """"but of course"""".""<br><br> ""キョウ But of course, this character really means """"situation/condition"""". """"Elder brother gulped some water and said, 'What the hell was Heisig's mental CONDITION when he came up with this definition? Heisig must have a drinking CONDITION. But of course, if Heisig sticks to water, rather than sake (like me, water quaffing, situation assessing, sober elder brother), his SITUATION may improve.'""""　[MODEL COMPOUND: 状況　(じょうきょう)　state of affairs; conditions].""<br>#145<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 河</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 河  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=146"">river</br></br></a>  A river CAN exist only if there is WATER.<br><br> ""I kept confusing this with stream. My Japanese friend said that to him this is for an artificial river. Looking at kanji compounds with this there are two that struck me: One is the Yellow River in China (黄河), and the other is the Milky Way (銀河). Now I either think of the Little Engine that could dragging a bunch of stuff down a river in China and polluting it (so it turned yellow) or I see the Little Engine that Could flying across the sky making the Milky Way.""<br>#146<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 泊</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 泊  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=147"">overnight</br></br></a>  Please supply a guest who stays overnight with WATER and WHITE sheets.<br><br> ""When I go to an OVERNIGHT party, all I need is a bit of water and some of that hard white. (crack). (not really, but come on. much easier to recall than white sheets).""<br>#147<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 湖</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 湖  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=148"">lake</br></br></a>  ""This is my favorite story. Simply associate the sad moment of an OLD person, standing near the WATER of the lake and looking at the MOON reflected in the lake. The created primitives themselves are put so beautifully, that you will not forget this kanji.""<br><br> Water reflects the old moon in the lake.<br>#148<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 測</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 測  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=149"">fathom</br></br></a>  A fathom is the unit you use when making rules about water's depth.<br><br> You can't fathom how deep this water is. Perhaps you should use a ruler to measure it?<br>#149<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 土</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 土  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=150"">soil</br></br></a>  ""Remembering soil is easy. If soil is soft, you can take a walking stick and plunge it two* feet into the ground.""<br><br> King Arthur pulled the magical sword Excalibur out of the hardened soil to claim his place as king.<br>#150<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 吐</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 吐  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=151"">spit</br></br></a>  <div><br /></div><br><br> SPIT goes from my MOUTH to the GROUND.<br>#151<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 圧</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 圧  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=152"">pressure</br></br></a>  The GROUND at the base of a CLIFF must suffer from enormous pressure.<br><br> ""For physics people: p = F/A (p:pressure, F:Force, A:Area). Where the force is from the immensity of the cliff. The area on the cliff is covered by soil. So the equation becomes p = F/A = cliff/soil which preserves the position of the primitives.""<br>#152<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 埼</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 埼  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=153"">cape</br></br></a>  ""This refers to LAND, not the STRANGE gear superheroes wear.""<br><br> ""Cape Cod """"odd"""" is a land where odd=strange things happen.""<br>#153<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 垣</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 垣  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=154"">hedge</br></br></a>  ""Before the Great Wall of China, there was a dirt hedge that spanned across.""<br><br> The HEDGE of roses growing from the castle grounds fully spanned the castle walls.<br>#154<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 圭</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 圭  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=155"">squared jewel</br></br></a>  Piling SOIL upon SOIL for aeons is how SQUARE JEWELS are formed deep in the earth.<br><br> How would you stop someone stealing your biggest square jewel? Bury it deep in the soil under ground. Then plant ivy to mark the spot.<br>#155<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 封</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 封  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=156"">seal</br></br></a>  The king used a special seal of ivy leaves glued onto his document.<br><br> ""A bit of ivy glued to a letter can make a lovely SEAL when in a pinch, says Martha Stewart.""<br>#156<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 涯</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 涯  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=157"">horizon 生涯（しょうがい）</br></br></a>  Try to reverse Heisig's story in this Kanji: imagine being trapped in one of those prison towers on an ivy cladcliff like in the movies. From your prison ontop the ivy clad cliff all you can see in the distant horizon is nothing but water.<br><br> ""From the water, I can see the ivy-clad-cliffs on the horizon.""<br>#157<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 寺</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 寺  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=158"">Buddhist temple</br></br></a>  ""At the Buddhist temple the monks are seated on the ground, glued there in meditation.""<br><br> ""To be allowed to join the Buddhist temple, imagine an aspiring monk being asked to stand still in the soil for a long time in a measurement of his resolve.""<br>#158<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 時</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 時  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=159"">time とき</br></br></a>  ""When the SUN starts to shine on the TEMPLE, it's time to get up.""<br><br> ""In ancient Japan, TIME of ''day'' was announced at the ''buddhist temples''. They did this by ringing large iron bells. This is similar to churches who ring their bells to announce the time of day.""<br>#159<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 均</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 均  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=160"">level</br></br></a>  Soil is scooped up into a ladel. The extra drop is brushed off to make it level.<br><br> ""To remember the extra stroke in the ladle, make a vivid image of a big drop of excess soil fr0m the ladle falling out onto the ground when you level it.""<br>#160<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 火</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 火  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=161"">fire</br></br></a>  ""For some reason, this kanji reminds me of a person running, her arms (the two drops) raised up, because she caught on fire!""<br><br> A tepee getting shot at by fire arrows.<br>#161<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 炎</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 炎  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=162"">inflammation</br></br></a>  To fight fire with fire would just inflame a situation.<br><br> An inflammation can often feel like FIRE upon FIRE burning.<br>#162<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 煩</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 煩  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=163"">anxiety</br></br></a>  An anxiety feels like FIRE in the HEAD.<br><br> ""Many performers get """"Michael Jackson anxiety"""" wherein they fear their head will catch on fire.""<br>#163<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 灯</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 灯  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=165"">lamp ともす</br></br></a>  Imagine old gas lamps which had a flame to light up the street signs.<br><br> A lamp is fire you can hang from a nail.<br>#165<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 畑</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 畑  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=166"">farm</br></br></a>  Many farms are created by first setting FIRE over the land to clear the land for the FIELDS.<br><br> <br>#166<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 災</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 災  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=167"">disaster</br></br></a>  ""What a disaster! First a FIRE, then on top of it came FLOODs.""<br><br> ""Don't know about Japan, but here in Australia, flooding rivers and bushfires are the most common natural disasters.""<br>#167<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 灰</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 灰  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=168"">ashes</br></br></a>  The fire underneath the cliff will eventually turn everything above to ashes.<br><br> ""Scene from """"The Big Lebowski"""" : Walter scatters Donny's ashes, but a wind blows much of the ashes into """"The Dude"""" Lebowski's face. Upset, The Dude lashes out at Walter. Walter apologizes and hugs The Dude, before suggesting """"Fuck it, man. Let's go bowling."""" I bet you that The Dude wanted to cremate (fire) Walter right there and then, at the top of the cliff! (thanks Elktapestry).""<br>#168<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 点</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 点  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=169"">spot てん</br></br></a>  The FORTUNE TELLER was burned by FLAMES on the spot because she was accused of being a witch.<br><br> You have to stimulate the G-spot with your magic wand in order to get her on fire. Or you can juste use your mouth...<br>#169<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 魚</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 魚  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=171"">fish さかな</br></br></a>  ""The elements of this kanji are bound up, rice field and cooking fire. When I think of bound up cooked rice, it makes me think of sushi, which in turn brings to mind fish.""<br><br> Bind that FISH and cook his brains! Yarhh!<br>#171<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 漁</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 漁  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=172"">fishing</br></br></a>  You need WATER and FISH for fishing.<br><br> ""If you are confusing this with angling like me, take fishing to mean not the act of catching a fish but the act of being a fish not living but fishing (i.e. in the water).""<br>#172<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 里</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 里  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=173"">ri/computer primitive</br></br></a>  The ri is a Japanese way of measuring the area of the GROUND underneath a RICE FIELD.<br><br> ""Hint: Heisig makes here a severe disservice to everyone by using a weird keyword for this character. You'll save a lot (and I mean, a whole lot) of trouble later by giving it instead its intended meaning: House of the Parents.""<br>#173<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 黒</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 黒  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=174"">black くろ</br></br></a>  ""If you burn the GROUND of a RICE FIELD with FIRE, eventually it will turn black.""<br><br> ""If your parent's home catches on fire, it will turn black.""<br>#174<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 墨</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 墨  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=175"">black ink</br></br></a>  Theres BLACK on the GROUND...most likely someone spilt some black ink.<br><br> Anyone who has worked with laserjet ink cartridges will know the black ink looks like powdered dirt.<br>#175<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 鯉</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 鯉  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=176"">carp こい</br></br></a>  Japanese carp are massive<b> fish </b>- they are measured in <b>ri!</b><br><br> The fish got carpal tunnel syndrome from the computer(I know it's lame but it's hard to find a good story for this).<br>#176<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 量</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 量  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=177"">quantity りょう</br></br></a>  ""I did such a quantity of work that when NIGHT BREAK came, I was asleep on the COMPUTER.""<br><br> ""If you find that by nightbreak, you're still playing at your computer, chances are your World of Warcraft character has a high quantity of levels. [thanks to ssmoler] ..... To remember that nightbreak appears ABOVE computer, think of looking UP from your computer at the window to realize you've been playing until nightbreak.""<br>#177<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 厘</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 厘  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=178"">rin&nbsp;九分九厘</br></br></a>  ""I threw my Rindows computer off a cliff because it kept crashing. Now, after its last crash, it's worth less than a rin.""<br><br> A computer dropped off of a cliff would be worth about 1 RIN.<br>#178<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 埋</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 埋  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=179"">bury うめる</br></br></a>  <br><br> I used SOIL to BURY my COMPUTER.<br>#179<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 同</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 同  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=180"">same おなじ</br></br></a>  ""Muslim women wearing veils (HOOD) all look the same, you can just see ONE MOUTH and very little else.""<br><br> Imagine monks wandering around the monastery. Covered in their hoods and chanting as if with one mouth they all look the same !<br>#180<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 洞</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 洞  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=181"">den ほら</br></br></a>  All the animals in the den share the <b>same water.</b><br><br> """"""Den"""" and """"cave"""" also make me think of a monk's cell. Monks take vows of silence and fast. So a den is where you'd find nothing but water (to drink) and a monk.""<br>#181<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 胴</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 胴  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=182"">trunk どう</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""Dead flesh all looks the same when you chop off everything but the trunk. Yes, I'm appalled at how gruesome this story is too.""<br>#182<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 向</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 向  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=183"">yonder</br></br></a>  Look over yonder ! That tiny dot is robin hood at the mouth of his secret cave !<br><br> ""There was an old woman named Wanda,// Who wanted to make herself blonder.// She covered her くち// With a glass hood from Gucci// And dropped some hair dye on from yonder.""<br>#183<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 尚</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 尚  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=184"">esteem なお</br></br></a>  An especially esteemed alien has three antennae on his helmet.<br><br> ""Remember that scene from Star Wars, where Luke is wearing that helmet that only his mouth could see, and was swinging at that little thing buzzing around the room? That was Obi-Wan's trick to get Luke to build his self-esteem, or his confidence in the Force.""<br>#184<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 守</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 守  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=186"">guard まもる</br></br></a>  ""A GUARD is usually """"glued"""" to the house he watches.""<br><br> A guard provides a measure of security to those under a roof.<br>#186<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 完</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 完  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=187"">perfect かん璧</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""In the beginning, Adam and Eve had a home in Eden. It was perfect.""<br>#187<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 宣</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 宣  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=188"">proclaim せん言</br></br></a>  You can proclaim your opinions from the comfort of your HOUSE and have it SPAN the entire globe these days via The Internet.<br><br> I heard young Muslims have to memorise the Koran and proclaim it aloud as a kind of rite of passage. Imagine the SPAN of hours spent under a ROOF practising that! It must surely be worse than trying to get through Heisigs RTK - count yourself lucky.<br>#188<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 宵</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 宵  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=189"">wee hours</br></br></a>  I burn the CANDLE in my HOUSE until the WEE HOURS reviewing the kanji!!!<br><br> ""I agree with elktapestry. This kanji really means """"early evening"""", not """"wee hours"""" [Heisig really should have done his homework on this and several other characters (e.g., #145 """"but of course"""" -- what the hell???). Oh well.] """"Every house lights candles in the EARLY EVENING which stay lit until the wee hours"""". E.G. 宵の口（よいのくち）early evening; 今宵（こよい）this evening; tonight.""<br>#189<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 安</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 安  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=190"">relax</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""You can only relax, when you have woman under roof to do all chores.""<br>#190<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 宴</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 宴  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=191"">banquet</br></br></a>  The WOMAN spent all DAY preparing a banquet in the HOUSE.<br><br> ""Under the roof, all day long, the woman prepared for the banquet (this wording helps me remember the order of this kanji's elements).""<br>#191<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 寄</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 寄  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=192"">draw near</br></br></a>  ""The strange house has a sign saying """"DRAW NEAR"""" in its window, instead of a 'Beware' sign. It must be a trick!""<br><br> Imagine a horror movie set in a haunted mansion. The house is very strange. The characters draw near to one another for protection against the unknown.<br>#192<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 富</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 富  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=193"">wealth</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""In ancient Japan, a RICE FIELD is a unit of wealth as it can produce enough to feed all the MOUTHs in ONE HOUSE.""<br>#193<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 貯</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 貯  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=194"">savings</br></br></a>  It takes a lot more than one clam of savings to buy a house on a street.<br><br> ""My SAVINGS plan - I nail my moneybags up in the rafters below my roof. I'm very secretive about it, and I wear a disguise with a big mustache (another meaning of this kanji) while I stash my loot.""<br>#194<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 木</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 木  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=195"">tree</br></br></a>  ""If you need a story for a tree, then you need to be hit by one.""<br><br> Pictograph of a tree.<br>#195<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 森</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 森  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=197"">forest</br></br></a>  ""The higher you go up a mountain the less trees there are, that's so u dont mess up with their possition like i do.""<br><br> Another tree planted within a grove turns it into a FOREST.<br>#197<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 桂</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 桂  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=198"">Japanese Judas-tree</br></br></a>  ""Simple mnemonic : """"The Japanese Judas-tree is the tree on which Judas hang himself to the ivy"""" (Judas the traitor of the Christian bible). Just picture Judas hanging himself, using ivy as a if it was a rope.""<br><br> ""A tree covered in poison ivy will quickly betray you, thus the name JAPANESE JUDAS-TREE.""<br>#198<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 柏</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 柏  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=199"">oak</br></br></a>  ""The wood from oak trees can be used to make barrels in which white wine is aged. What's more, I love white wine with an oaky flavour...""<br><br> ""An oak tree is white, from left to right!""<br>#199<br></span>"

The rest are made of metal or plastic.<br>#200<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 梢</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 梢  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=201"">treetops こずえ</br></br></a>  ""At Christmas time, on the treetops, people used to place great big candles (Now we usually place a star instead).""<br><br> ""If you cut off the treetops, they still resemble the trees they used to be part of. Treetops=tree resemblance.""<br>#201<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 杏</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 杏  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=203"">apricot</br></br></a>  From the tree straight into the mouth is the best way to eat an APRICOT!<br><br> Imagine Totoro sleeping under his tree. As he snores a giant apricot falls nicely into his open mouth and he emits a giant burp of satisfaction. I can hear that music alreay....to - to to - to - ro...<br>#203<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 桐</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 桐  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=204"">paulownia </br></br></a>  ""In Japan, a paulownia (きり）is known as the """"princess tree"""". It was once a traditional TREE planted at the SAME time as the birth of a daughter. It would grow fast enough that, at the time of her wedding, it could be used to make a dresser as a wedding present for her.""<br><br> Paulownia is a Japanese tree which looks same as any other tree.<br>#204<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 植</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 植  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=205"">plant</br></br></a>  Plants don't become <b>trees straightaway</b>.<br><br> ""When you plant plants, you use a piece of WOOD to make the plant grow STRAIGHT.""<br>#205<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 枯</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 枯  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=206"">wither かれる</br></br></a>  A tree withers away as it gets old.<br><br> ""When flowers get old they suffer (frame 225), but old trees just WITHER away painlessly. (Picture flowers crying in pain, but a dried up tree silent and sad).""<br>#206<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 朴</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 朴  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=207"">crude</br></br></a>  Wooden wands are the crudest. <br><br> <br>#207<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 村</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 村  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=208"">village むら</br></br></a>  ""If you've ever played an old 8 bit or 16 bit RPG, like Dragon Warrior or Final Fantasy or Inindou, you'll remember that every town was all bordered off by a line of trees with no space in between to get out through. Imagine that the trees were glued together so you could only exit town through the main or side gates, (so you couldn't escape the important scripted scenes.).""<br><br> ""Pfft. At it's core, a town is just a bunch of wood glued together. Edit - Stop starring this piece of crap story! xD.""<br>#208<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 相</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 相  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=209"">inter-</br></br></a>  The prime minister is having inter-course behind that tree! All you can see are his eyes poking out from the righthand-side of the tree.<br><br> ""ソウ/ショウ/あ INTER /MUTUAL /ASPECT /PHASE /MINISTER. """"Long ago, before there were telephones, people living far from one another would climb trees to eye each other's aspects and inter-act for their mutual benefit. Those who did this best became government ministers, with the top person (perhaps the one with the longest neck (首, neck (#70)) becoming the prime minister 「首相 (しゅしょう)"""".""<br>#209<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 机</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 机  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=210"">desk つくえ</br></br></a>  ""My wooden desk is so messy, it looks like a strong wind blew my things all over it.""<br><br> ""Whenever I'm alone at my computer desk, I'm always getting wood and breaking wind.""<br>#210<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 本</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 本  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=211"">book</br></br></a>  The origin of a book is paper made out of TREEs. ONE tree can make many books.<br><br> An axe cutting a tree to make books.<br>#211<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 札</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 札  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=212"">tag</br></br></a>  Botanists like to identify TREEs by HOOKing tags on them.<br><br> ""Might be good to note that this is also the Kanji for """"Paper Money"""" w/ the reading さつ (千円札＝1000 Yen paper bill)... It also takes on the meaning of Playing Card with the reading of ふだ as in 花札 (Hanafuda cards) or トランプの札 (""""trump"""" playing cards). For the tag meaning I like to think of wooden tags hung on hooks from trees... but for these other meanings I like to think of both paper money and playing cards as paper (tree) products with the ability to """"hook you in"""" so to speak.""<br>#212<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 暦</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 暦  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=213"">calendar</br></br></a>  ""Years-Months-Days: It takes many years for a cliff to form or erode. A tree takes many months to grow. But days pass by regularly - so in this way, we see the movement of time such as with a CALENDAR.""<br><br> ""This is just a picture of a wall calendar with a page for each month. The bottom half has the grid of days, the top half has a pretty picture of a forest this month. The cliff radical here is the top and left edges of the paper. You can see the paper curling up at the lower left where a breeze is trying to turn the page.""<br>#213<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 案</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 案  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=214"">plan あん</br></br></a>  I plan to RELAX on top of that TREE.<br><br> ""If you bring a woman to your house, generally its not a good plan to stick your wood up her bottom, she may scream in pain あん!""<br>#214<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 燥</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 燥  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=215"">parch</br></br></a>  ""It's been so parched recently that your furniture suddenly catches fire."" しょうそう<br><br> The parchment says you need fire to make goods from trees.<br>#215<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 未</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 未  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=216"">not yet まだ</br></br></a>  I believe a better version of that by mameha1977: [Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree (木) does not yet (未) have exremities (末) of vermilion (朱).<br><br> [Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree (木) is not yet (末) vermilion (朱).<br>#216<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 末</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 末  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=217"">extremity</br></br></a>  ""The tree has reached the extremity of its growth and no longer produces small, new branches at the top. Instead the existing top branch just grows longer and longer.""<br><br> ""There are no great stories for this one yet, and I always forget it.. So, let's try something ridiculous: The man lived by himself in the wilderness, with no females within miles. So, his only way of relief was to stick his extremity into a small hole in a tree.. The poor guy. Which horizontal stroke is the extremity? The longer one or the shorter one? That, my friends, is up to your own imaginations. I'd prefer not to dwell on that point, myself. ;).""<br>#217<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 沫</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 沫  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=218"">splash しぶき</br></br></a>  The extremity of a wave of water is the splash.<br><br> A splash is WATER that has reached its EXTREMITY.<br>#218<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 味</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 味  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=219"">flavor あじ</br></br></a>  My mouth has not yet swallowed the food because the flavor is so delicious that I keep chewing it.<br><br> ""To enjoy a food's FLAVOR, it must be in one's MOUTH but NOT YET swallowed.""<br>#219<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 妹</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 妹  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=220"">younger sister いもうと</br></br></a>  My younger sister is NOT YET a fully grown WOMAN.<br><br> Is your younger sister a woman? Not yet! Damn!<br>#220<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 朱</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 朱  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=221"">vermilion&nbsp;</br></br></a>  It's autumn: only one vermilion leaf on the tree has not yet fallen.<br><br> [Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree (木) is not yet (未)[correction wrong character before] vermilion (朱).<br>#221<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 株</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 株  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=222"">stocks かぶ</br></br></a>  ""Which tree would you buy stocks in - the healthy one on the left, or the one with only one vermilion leaf left on the right?""<br><br> ""Ideally, one buys stocks when a company is young, """"green,"""" and rapidly growing -- then sells them just before the last vermillion leaf falls off, and a period of dormancy or limited growth begins.""<br>#222<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 若</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 若  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=223"">young わか者</br></br></a>  The young little girl held a cute flower in her right hand.<br><br> ""In Hawaii, if you wear a flower over your left ear, it means you are taken. A flower over the right means you are not. The younger you are, the more likely you are to have a flower over your right ear…　　　　　　RTK2: 　ニャク　老若　ろうにゃく (young and old)　　　　　　　　　　　　　　 ジャク　若干　じゃっかん(few).""<br>#223<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 草</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 草  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=224"">grass</br></br></a>  Grass grows in earlier than flowers.<br><br> This grass is very long. The only flowers you can see are sunflowers – the rest are hidden by the grass.<br>#224<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 苦</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 苦  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=225"">suffering く</br></br></a>  Flowers for the old man suffering in the hospital.<br><br> The derivates from opium poppies such as morphine can be used to tame the suffering of the old.<br>#225<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 寛</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 寛  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=226"">tolerant かん容</br></br></a>  A tolerant person will ignore SEEing GRASS (marijuana) in the HOUSE of a friend.<br><br> ""To be tolerant is to see flowers (meaning """"beautiful things"""") in every house, instead of looking for drawbacks.""<br>#226<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 薄</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 薄  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=227"">dilute うすい</br></br></a>  A<b> Dr</b>. missing his needle can only use dilute <b>flower water</b> for medicine.<br><br> ""Note This character belongs to a set of characters which share the flower/water primitive such as:: dilute (#227), fall (#299), clan (#1912), and seaweed (#2035).... (落 薄 藩 藻) It may be helpful to create a primitive keyword for this occurrence (like seaweed or watering can) which can save a lot of time distinguishing them from characters like Sino 満 and Full 満, where the water primitive is larger than the flower primitive.""<br>#227<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 葉</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 葉  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=228"">leaf は</br></br></a>  ""On top of the leaves a flower appears, promising new generations for the old tree below.""<br><br> The flower generation spent far too much time up trees trying to smoke leaves.<br>#228<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 模</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 模  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=229"">imitation</br></br></a>  ""If I find out this furniture you're selling me is made of imitation wood, I'll put you in the graveyard.""<br><br> ""The Japanese are so enamored of everything plastic, they even put IMITATION plastic trees in their graveyards! (No, not really, but I wouldn't be surprised).""<br>#229<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 漠</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 漠  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=230"">vague&nbsp;漠然(ばくぜん)</br></br></a>  The precise locations of sailors who meet a WATERY GRAVE are vague.<br><br> ""The water in the graveyard has worn away the headstones, so the writing is vague.""<br>#230<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 墓</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 墓  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=231"">grave</br></br></a>  The soil under a graveyard is full of graves.<br><br> A grave is a patch of soil in a graveyard.<br>#231<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 暮</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 暮  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=232"">livelihood 暮らす</br></br></a>  He made a livelihood out of robbing GRAVEYARDS in broad DAYlight.<br><br> ""The gravedigger makes his LIVELIHOOD digging in the graveyard all day For graveyard, imagine an idyllic picture: beautiful grass with the sun shining down...and a dog peeing on one of the graves. Don't confuse with occupation (#1034). Hold onto the irony of making your LIVElyhood from tending dead people.""<br>#232<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 膜</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 膜  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=233"">membrane まく</br></br></a>  ""In the moonlight of the graveyard I hear a zombie say, MMMMM..EMM...BRANEsssss.""<br><br> The membranes in your flesh rot when placed in the graveyard.<br>#233<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 苗</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 苗  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=234"">seedling</br></br></a>  If you plant seedlings in a FIELD eventually they will FLOWER.<br><br> Crap! There are flowers in the rice field... Who let those seedlings get in there?!<br>#234<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 兆</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 兆  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=235"">portent</br></br></a>  When your wife's LEGs get huge hairs on them it is surely a bad portent for things to come.<br><br> A bad portent makes the hairs on your legs stand.<br>#235<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 桃</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 桃  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=236"">peach tree</br></br></a>  The pits of a peach tree look like turtles.<br><br> <br>#236<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 眺</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 眺  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=237"">stare ながめる</br></br></a>  Sauron's One fiery eye stare at Frodo and it is a sign of portent. Evil will become whomever the eye is staring upon.<br><br> ""You lost a staring contest with a turtle because you blinked your eye before he did. (The contest wasn't fair, because turtles have nictitating membranes, and don't need to blink so often.) Eye comes first, because stare is most associated with eyes. And compare with challenge (#658) where this same obstreperous turtle challenges you to a finger wrestling contest. (Sibyl's story with some notes that helped me).""<br>#237<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 犬</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 犬  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=238"">dog</br></br></a>  ""A large dog, dripping drool.""<br><br> ""If we remember large (#107) as a man with his arms outstretched, the drop represents man's best friend - a dog.""<br>#238<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 状</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 状  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=239"">status quo じょう</br></br></a>  It was left to the turtle to make right with the dog and thus maintain the status quo..<br><br> A turtle mounting a chihuahua clearly disrupts the status quo.<br>#239<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 黙</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 黙  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=240"">silence 沈もく</br></br></a>  ""The computer won't stop beeping, which is making the chihauhua bark, and it's driving this guy insane. The only solution he can come up with is to throw them both on the fire and finally enjoy the silence.""<br><br> ""Your neighbor is so sick of you playing Led Zeppelin that he takes your copy of the song Black Dog and burns it. Finally, silence in the neighborhood.""<br>#240<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 然</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 然  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=241"">sort of thing</br></br></a>  ""Flesh of a dog over a cooking fire = """"hotdog"""". There are all sorts of things in hot dogs. Believe me, you don't want to know what sort of things . Visualize the hotdog curling as it cooks, to remember the unusual way the flesh primitive curves in this kanji. (tweaked version of ziggr's. Thanks!).""<br><br> ""There are all sorts of things in hot dogs. (I use hot dog for this primitive (meat of a dog over a cooking fire). I swear I can actually see the 月 here as a hot dog, with its slight curve and grill marks.).""<br>#241<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 荻</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 荻  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=242"">reed</br></br></a>  REEDS are the only FLOWERS that WILD DOGS like to FIRE up and smoke while they are playing poker.<br><br> A reed is a flower that looks like a hot dog.<br>#242<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 狩</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 狩  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=243"">hunt</br></br></a>  Actually when hunting it may be a good idea to use a pack of dogs as your personal guard.<br><br> ""After a pack of wild dogs hunt some food, they will guard it fiercely.""<br>#243<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 猫</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 猫  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=244"">cat ねこ</br></br></a>  The cat hid in the FLOWERS of the FIELD from the WILD DOGs.<br><br> Dawgs always wanna put their seedlings in pussies.<br>#244<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 牛</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 牛  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=245"">cow</br></br></a>  ""A cow tried to climb up a vermilion tree, but in doing so, it broke its two bottom branches off.""<br><br> A cow bleeds vermilion when you cut off two of it's legs.<br>#245<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 特</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 特  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=246"">special</br></br></a>  ""Think of not special people, but special animals. The sacred Hindu cows are special - they can wander around the temple without fear of becoming roast beef.""<br><br> ""The Church Lady is traveling through Japan and notices with distaste a sacred cow relieving itself inside a Buddhist Temple. """"Well, isn't that special"""".""<br>#246<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 告</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 告  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=247"">revelation</br></br></a>  ""The revelation makes the cow's mouth drop down, """"Hamburgers are made of what?!"""".""<br><br> ""When you get a revelation, you may drop to the ground with your mouth wide open.""<br>#247<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 先</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 先  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=248"">before</br></br></a>  I've never seen a cow with human legs before!<br><br> ""Nasty story but it keeps the meaning true to the kanji. """"BEFORE you stick it in a COW and SPREAD the legs (the bottom stroke of this cow looks like two legs) make sure she has HUMAN LEGS""""-------------sorry, I'll remove if I get enough reports, but will keep if I get more stars.""<br>#248<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 洗</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 洗  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=249"">wash あらう</br></br></a>  ""In Japan, you always wash with water from the shower before you enter the bathtub.""<br><br> You wash things with WATER to get them back to the clean state they were in BEFORE.<br>#249<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 介</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 介  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=250"">jammed in</br></br></a>  ""The two strokes at the bottom look like a J and I, which stands for """"jammed in."""".""<br><br> Two people jammed in under an umbrella. A woman with a dress and a man (straight). It's always me that ends up getting wet.... but the tail of the skirt is this time!<br>#250<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 界</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 界  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=251"">world</br></br></a>  One Japanese farmer I know is so small minded that he thinks the entire world is JAMMED IN the borders of his little RICE FIELD.<br><br> A famous philosopher once said that his world consisted of all the things he could jam into his brain.<br>#251<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 茶</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 茶  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=252"">tea おちゃ</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""When I drink herbal tea I like to drink it under a parasol. If it's too hot I go """"ho, ho, ho !!"""" (katakana ホ).""<br>#252<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 合</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 合  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=253"">fit</br></br></a>  ""I wouldn't mind a meeting of mouths with her, she's really fit !""<br><br> He had such a big mouth that he could easily fit one whole umbrella in it.<br>#253<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 塔</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 塔  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=254"">pagoda</br></br></a>  In order to build a pagoda in this small Japanese garden everything has to fit: the soil to the left and the flowers in the upper right corner.<br><br> ""Pictograph-o-rama. This is a corner of a Japanese garden, with a small mound of soil on the left, and a little concrete pagoda in the front with flowers behind it. (To my eye, the fit looks a lot like a little pagoda anyway. This may or may not cause confusion for you, though...).""<br>#254<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 王</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 王  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=255"">king</br></br></a>  To be king you have to be a real crafty one !<br><br> The king unites heaven and earth. (imagine heaven being the top line over the soil).<br>#255<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 玉</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 玉  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=256"">jewel</br></br></a>  The king is said to have only one family jewel below the belt...<br><br> ""The king is said to have only one family jewel below the belt...and he hangs left! (I always screw up the direction of the """"drop"""").""<br>#256<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 宝</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 宝  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=257"">treasure</br></br></a>  On treasure island there is a single house - where all the jewels are stored.<br><br> ""Put a """"roof"""" (lid) on your jewels and voila! You've got a treasure chest.""<br>#257<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 珠</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 珠  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=258"">pearl</br></br></a>  The king of the Oysters produces special Vermillion pearls!<br><br> King Vermillion is a little queer and likes to wear pearl necklaces.<br>#258<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 現</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 現  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=259"">present</br></br></a>  The KING ... can SEE clearly the PRESENT state of affairs in the land. (maybe he hees them in the crystal ball on the left?).<br><br> ""Hey, I want my money back! This crystal ball is out of order, I can see the present instead of the future!""<br>#259<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 狂</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 狂  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=260"">lunatic</br></br></a>  Oh no ! A pack of dogs has bitten the king. He has turned into a rabid lunatic !<br><br> ""Think of King Nebuchadnezzar, who for 7 years lost his sanity and had to live like a wild animal.""<br>#260<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 皇</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 皇  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=261"">emperor</br></br></a>  ""Ancient Rome had Emperors instead of Kings, and they wore white robes. Thus an emperor is a king in white. (make sure you picture a roman emperor not a japanese one and you'll be ok).""<br><br> The white dove descended on the king and he was promoted to emperor.<br>#261<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 呈</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 呈  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=262"">display</br></br></a>  The mouth of the king is displaying his bling.<br><br> ""What a pathetic display! The king is sprawled on his throne, head back and mouth wide open, fast asleep. We should never have let him drink so much at that banquet last night.""<br>#262<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 全</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 全  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=263"">whole ぜん</br></br></a>  ""The fat king hogs the whole space under his umbrella. (tweaked version of radical tyro's story. """"fat"""" makes a more vivid image for me.).""<br><br> The king takes up the whole space under his umbrella.<br>#263<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 栓</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 栓  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=264"">plug</br></br></a>  ""The fat king under his umbrella offers useless advice to the workers. """"You'll need the whole tree to plug that gap"""". Imagine a grossly fat, incompetent king under a parasol giving annoying advice to sweating workers who know what they're doing. (I always have trouble bringing up the """"whole"""" primitive. This story reminds me how to build that part. ).""<br><br> ""To plug the hole, you need to use a whole piece of wood - like a cork or something.""<br>#264<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 理</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 理  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=265"">logic</br></br></a>  The king of LOGIC is the computer.<br><br> Computers are ruled by logic (it is the king of computers).<br>#265<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 主</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 主  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=266"">lord</br></br></a>  A lord is a little drop down from King in hierarchy.<br><br> ""Although this kanji's meaning hasn't caused me much trouble, I've had problems remembering the direction of the drop above king, since drops at tops of kanji often seem to appear in different directions. To remember this one, I think of the placement of the drop in jewel (#256). Both of them use the king primitive and include a short drop stroke going from the top left to bottom right.""<br>#266<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 注</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 注  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=267"">pour</br></br></a>  Visualize an idiot trying to figure out how to extinguish a candle. He sees a glass of WATER and decides to pour it onto the CANDLESTICK to put it out. Water spills everywhere.<br><br> Like water the hot wax poured down the side of the candlestick.<br>#267<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 柱</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 柱  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=268"">pillar</br></br></a>  The main pillar in a house should be made of the biggest and strongest tree - the lord of the trees.<br><br> """"""Why has this pillar been carved in the shape of a giant penis?!"""" """"You said that 'it should be made of wood', My Lord."""".""<br>#268<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 金</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 金  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=269"">gold</br></br></a>  The fat king taking up the whole space under the umbrella actually isn't fat - he just has two big gold bars hidden under his clothes.<br><br> ""Under the umbrella's shade, the king sang, """" Drop it to the left, drop it to the right, give me all the GOLD in sight!"""".""<br>#269<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 銑</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 銑  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=270"">pig iron</br></br></a>  ""Pig iron is basic/crude metal, that is, before it has been processed.""<br><br> <br>#270<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 鉢</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 鉢  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=271"">bowl 鉢合わせ</br></br></a>  ""This is the BOWL of an alchemist: see how he mixes metals in his bowl, as he follows the instructions from his book?""<br><br> ""If I was begging with a BOWL, I would want GOLD and BOOKS.""<br>#271<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 銅</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 銅  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=272"">copper</br></br></a>  ""I can't believe no one has used this one yet: Copper is metal which looks almost the same as gold. Really, look it up on Wikipedia, it's yellow and it's shiny (atleast in some compounds)!""<br><br> ""Copper is an excellent conductor. In other words, it's a metal for which the voltage is the same everywhere. That's why it's used for wires.""<br>#272<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 釣</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 釣  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=273"">angling</br></br></a>  All the people that go to the Japanese festivals to catch fish part time are suckers. Me? I'm a pro. I bring a big-ass golden ladle. I'm a true ANGLING professional.<br><br> Imagine an effeminate Roman 2000 years ago angling with a golden ladle instead of a rod because it matches his eyes and hair better and it impresses the boys. (Why a Roman? Because 'angling' is just the roman-derived way to say 'fishing' - use this to distinguish fishing from angling.).<br>#273<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 針</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 針  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=274"">needle</br></br></a>  Remember the story of the needle in the haystack. Why would someone even look for a needle if it wasn't a GOLD NEEDLE?<br><br> A golden needle is worth ten times more than an ordinary needle.<br>#274<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 銘</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 銘  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=275"">inscription</br></br></a>  ""A piece of metal with a name on it. Well, this is basically the definition of inscription.""<br><br> I imagine ancient Egyptian inscriptions: Pharaohs' names written in gold.<br>#275<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 鎮</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 鎮  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=276"">tranquillize 鎮圧</br></br></a>  Tranquilize - using a metal syringe to get the truth.<br><br> Enough gold can tranquilize the truth in anyone.<br>#276<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 道</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 道  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=277"">road-way</br></br></a>  ""When we go out on the ROAD-WAY, we often risk our own necks (that's why I take the train! ).""<br><br> ""Watch as a villianous fiend stretches a poor damsel's neck over a dusty road. Her ear pressed to the ground, she can hear the rumble of a carriage thundering down the roadway. Will the hero save her in time?
