Or will her neck be ground into the road, spilling it's precious contents into the dust?""<br>#277<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 導</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 導  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=278"">guidance みちびく</br></br></a>  ""For guidance on the road-way, glue a GPS unit to your car.""<br><br> Good guidance will help you stay glued to the right path.<br>#278<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 辻</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 辻  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=279"">crossing</br></br></a>  Cross-road.<br><br> <br>#279<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 迅</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 迅  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=280"">swift</br></br></a>  The car went too swiftly on the road and was hooked by the cops, the cops realised the driver was on drugs after seeing all the needles.<br><br> ""In the Heisig version of Frogger, you can image ten giant fish hooks sweeping across the road, with our hapless hero 'froggy' forced to make a swift crossing or end up as fish bait.""<br>#280<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 造</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 造  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=281"">create</br></br></a>  A cow creates a road by eating all the grass on its path.<br><br> <br>#281<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 迫</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 迫  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=282"">urge</br></br></a>  ""When you have the URGE to go to White Castle, you know it's time to hit the road.""<br><br> ""When you start down the road of cocaine, you're sure to feel some pretty bad URGEs soon.""<br>#282<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 逃</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 逃  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=283"">escape にげる</br></br></a>  ""I used my pants to make a rope, which I then used to escape from prison; hence the naked, hairy legs running along the road!""<br><br> A turtle version of frogger dodging cars to escape to the other side of the road...　　　RTK2:　トウ　逃走　とうそう(escape)...　　　　　　　MIXED GROUP:　桃236　(ﾁｮｳ): 兆235　眺237　挑658　跳1284.<br>#283<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 辺</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 辺  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=284"">environs へん</br></br></a>  ""Caution: this kanji doesn't mean environment; it means """"environs; boundary; border; vicinity"""". To separate the environs, create the border by placing daggers on the road.""<br><br> ""To protect the environs around their village, samurai would travel the roads with their swords.""<br>#284<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 巡</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 巡  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=285"">patrol</br></br></a>  The cops don't PATROL anymore - they just flood the road.<br><br> The Venice cops patrol on river roads.<br>#285<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 車</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 車  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=286"">car</br></br></a>  My car is so fast it can go through ten rice fields in ten minutes.<br><br> ""Rather than hobbling along with a walking stick to cross through a span, it's much better to use a car. (Imagine an old man with a walking stick creeping along a span of road, and you, in a car, whizzing right by him. It's funny 'cause it's true.) Also, it's important to include the word """"through,"""" so you know the walking stick goes right THROUGH the span.""<br>#286<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 連</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 連  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=287"">take along</br></br></a>  When you put your car on the road you should always take along a few friends. Don't confuse with carry (#303).<br><br> ""This kanji also means """"linked"""" or """"series"""" so I've changed the kanji meaning to """"GO ALONG (WITH EACH OTHER)."""" Well, a ROAD and a CAR certainly GO ALONG with each other. And the CAR will help you to GO ALONG the ROAD. This Kanji is the """"Union"""" in Soviet Union and the """"United"""" of United Nations (the countries that """"go along with each other"""" at least some of the time).""<br>#287<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 軌</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 軌  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=288"">rut</br></br></a>  My car got so stuck in a rut it required nine people pushing to get it out again.<br><br> I got my car stuck in a rut ! I'm gonna have to call 999 !<br>#288<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 輸</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 輸  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=289"">transport&nbsp;ゆ入</br></br></a>  <br><br> The vehicle transports animals for a meeting with the butcher.<br>#289<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 前</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 前  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=290"">in front</br></br></a>  When I get horny my flesh sword sticks out in front of me.<br><br> ""If you stand in front of a bull's horns, you are asking for your flesh to be cut (or butchered if you prefer).""<br>#290<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 各</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 各  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=291"">each</br></br></a>  ""Son, I've never told you this but each woman has a second mouth between their fiiiiiine walking legs.""<br><br> Each and every one of us walks and talks differently.<br>#291<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 格</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 格  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=292"">status</br></br></a>  """"""Ranger! I want you to go check the status of each tree."""" """"Errr, Each tree sir?"""" replies the ranger looking out over the vast forest. """"That's Right, I want the status of each tree! Move out!"""".""<br><br> A man measures his own status by the size of his woody...and compares it to each one he sees.<br>#292<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 略</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 略  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=293"">abbreviation</br></br></a>  <br><br> A very anal farmer wants to catologue <b>each</b> grain of rice in his <b>rice field</b>. Imagine him scribbling a tiny abbreviation of his name and a number on each grain. <br>#293<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 客</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 客  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=294"">guest きゃく</br></br></a>  Each person under my roof is treated as a guest.<br><br> In my house I welcome each guest.<br>#294<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 額</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 額  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=295"">forehead</br></br></a>  Sign the guestbook page with your forehead. (Picture a guestbook full of forehead prints like thumbprints).<br><br> ""In New Zealand, people welcome guests by touching their foreheads together.""<br>#295<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 夏</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 夏  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=296"">summer なつ</br></br></a>  In SUMMER you are hot from the top of your head down to your walking legs.<br><br> ""I personally think it was too confusing to try and use head as the primitive. (How am I supposed to remember that the animal legs are replaced with walking legs instead of human legs?) Rather, I think have the image of a hot summer and you want to keep oneself under a ceiling not out jogging around.""<br>#296<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 処</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 処  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=297"">dispose</br></br></a>  The best way to dispose of a nasty bit of wind is to let it go and use those walking legs to dissapear. Nobody will ever know it was you.<br><br> To dispose of rubbish you should walk it to the bin not throw it to the wind.<br>#297<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 条</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 条  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=298"">twig&nbsp;条約</br></br></a>  They all say they have a TREE between their WALKING LEGS but most only have a TWIG.<br><br> ""Don't confuse with branch or bough - think of snapping twigs. A twig is always the kind of wood that snaps when the hunter's walking legs just barely touch it, making a snapping sound that alerts the prey to the hunter's presence.""<br>#298<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 落</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 落  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=299"">fall おちる</br></br></a>  Water each flower or the petals will wither and fall.<br><br> <br>#299<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 冗</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 冗  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=300"">superfluous じょうだん</br></br></a>  ""The king's crown was blown off by the wind. """"Oh well,"""" he said, """"it's just a superfluous symbol."""".""<br><br> ""The court jester wears a crown and is full of wind with bad jokes. He is superfluous to the King's court. This kanji is read as """"JOU"""" and commonly used to create the compound for jou-dan 冗談 (jest or joke) hence court jester. Also jou-go 冗語 (redundancy) and jou-in 冗員 (useless workers) 員-employee (#56).""<br>#300<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 軍</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 軍  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=301"">army ぐん</br></br></a>  British army cars are at the service of the crown.<br><br> Imagine a crown is the hood ornament on every army car.<br>#301<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 輝</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 輝  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=302"">radiance</br></br></a>  Rays of light emitted from Apollo's chariot = radiance. Don't put the sun into this kanji. The rays are coming from the chariot directly!<br><br> Radiance is an army of rays.<br>#302<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 運</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 運  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=303"">carry はこん</br></br></a>  ""Don’t confuse it with “take along” (287). In that one, there was a car so you could take along your friends once you found them on the road. In this one, there is an army chariot just to carry military supplies (sorry no room for you).""<br><br> Roads carry armies (in contrast to seas carrying navies or skies carrying air forces).<br>#303<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 冠</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 冠  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=304"">crown</br></br></a>  ""Remember the SUPERFLUOUS CROWN that flew away in the WIND? Well now the king is saying """"i should have had the thing GLUED to my head from the BEGINNING"""".""<br><br> ""A crown, from the beginning of the new king's life, is glued to him. He must inherit it.""<br>#304<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 夢</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 夢  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=305"">dream ゆめ</br></br></a>  Last night's date with Miss Sweden was like a dream. She even laid flowers over my eyes to crown the perfect evening.<br><br> ""In the movie American Beauty, Kevin Spacey liked to DREAM about his daughter's friend and have a rose petal fall onto his eye from the ceiling. He did this lying in his bed each evening. You can almost see him lying in his bed in this kanji.""<br>#305<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 坑</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 坑  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=306"">pit こう&nbsp;廃坑</br></br></a>  A whirlwind digs a hole in the ground throwing out lots of dirt until it ends up with a giant pit.<br><br> Tazmanian Devil whirlwinds a pit into the soil. Note: Take care difference between pit and rut.<br>#306<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 高</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 高  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=307"">tall</br></br></a>  ""Two little aliens in a trenchcoat and top hat, trying to look TALL. The bottom one, in the glass helmet, is under the coat. The top one has his top hat pulled down in disguise, so all you can see is his mouth.""<br><br> Here we have TWO MOUTHS each wearing a different hat. The top one is wearing a TOP HAT which is know to be as a TALL hat. The bottom one is wearing a SPACE HELMET which is known as an EXPENSIVE hat. (this kanji means both).<br>#307<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 享</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 享  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=308"">receive</br></br></a>  ""In basketball tall children receive all the attention.""<br><br> Tall children receive all the attention. They also make great receivers in football... this kanji also means 'catch' (therefore a football receiver is a great image).<br>#308<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 塾</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 塾  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=309"">cram school</br></br></a>  Welcome to our cram school: you will receive a rounded education on our grounds.<br><br> """"""You can receive a well-rounded education if you study at our cram school"""" says the advertisement. """"Just come to our school grounds and check it out yourself!"""".""<br>#309<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 熟</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 熟  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=310"">mellow 熟知</br></br></a>  Imagine tall children sitting round the fire toasting marsh-mellows.<br><br> ""The cram school (309) tortures its students - especially the tall and fat ones who need to grow up - over a fire until they mellow. (Note that here the keyword 'mellow' only means to mature, ripen, or acquire skill; not the colloquial meaning of 'chill out').""<br>#310<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 亭</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 亭  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=311"">pavilion</br></br></a>  The Pavillion on crown street is the tallest I have ever seen.<br><br> The tallest Pavilion crowns the street.<br>#311<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 京</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 京  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=312"">capital</br></br></a>  ""Tokyo, capital of Japan: tall buildings, small people (compared to the buildings).""<br><br> ""The capital is where the powerful act formal wearing top hats, open their mouths, and get little done.""<br>#312<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 涼</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 涼  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=313"">refreshing</br></br></a>  ""When you're a tourist in the capital during the heat of summer, finding a water fountain is oh, so refreshing.""<br><br> ""The water from the capital of Japan, Tokyo, is so refreshing!""<br>#313<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 景</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 景  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=314"">scenery</br></br></a>  Imaging the sun rising over the capital--classic postcard scenery.<br><br> ""Anyone who's been to Kyoto doesn't need to think too deeply into this Kanji! Imagine a sunny day in the old capital, and there's no better scenery.""<br>#314<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 鯨</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 鯨  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=315"">whale くじら</br></br></a>  ""If fish were cities, the whale would surely be the capital.""<br><br> When the whale was first discovered it was the biggest fish people had ever seen. Stories exaggerated its size - people said it was as big as the entire capital city!<br>#315<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 舎</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 舎  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=316"">cottage</br></br></a>  The cottage is so small - it has an umbrella for the roof; soil for the floor and room for only one mouth.<br><br> My vacation cottage is nothing but a hole in the ground covered by an umbrella.<br>#316<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 周</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 周  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=317"">circumference&nbsp;しゅう囲</br></br></a>  ""If my LIDDED CROCK has the same CIRCUMFERENCE as my head, I like to use it as a HELMET.""<br><br> You're at a motorcycle store looking to buy a helmet. The only way to check the circumference of your head is to put increasingly larger lidded crocks on your head until one slips on just right. Now you know what size helmet to buy.<br>#317<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 週</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 週  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=318"">week</br></br></a>  Imagine a road built so well that it takes only a week to travel the circumference of the earth.<br><br> ""Actually the week is like a never ending road where we travel in a circle through the same seven days again and again, the circumference is always the same. circumference (#317) also means circuit or lap, so that also makes think about the rotations of the moon, sun and the earth -- all important for measuring all kinds of time periods.""<br>#318<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 士</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 士  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=319"">gentleman</br></br></a>  ""What a handsome gentleman. Standing up so straight, and broad shoulders too!! He's like a modern samurai!""<br><br> A gentleman has broad shoulders and doesn't soil himself.<br>#319<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 吉</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 吉  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=320"">good luck</br></br></a>  The samurai's wife gives him a (uhum) before battle for good luck.<br><br> ""A true samurai gentleman will always mouth, """"Good luck"""" to his opponents before a match.""<br>#320<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 壮</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 壮  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=321"">robust</br></br></a>  Half of a turtle shell as a shield makes a samurai more robust.<br><br> The Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles are robust gentlemen aren't they?<br>#321<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 荘</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 荘  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=322"">villa</br></br></a>  A villa is fancier (decorated with flowers) and more robust than the average.<br><br> The teenage mutant samurai turtles live in a villa with flowers on the roof so that the neighbours don't get suspicious.<br>#322<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 売</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 売  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=323"">sell</br></br></a>  ""The samurai happened to find an extra large crown that he wore as a belt on his waist, just above his legs. I wonder if he will sell it to me?""<br><br> ""A """"samurai"""" will never sell his """"crown"""" (king), even it meant having both his """"human legs"""" chopped off!""<br>#323<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 学</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 学  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=324"">study</br></br></a>  ""In the school house there are kids always studying.""<br><br> ""Children in schoolhouses are there to study, nothing else!!!""<br>#324<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 覚</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 覚  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=325"">memorize</br></br></a>  ""In a schoolhouse in class: 1) you see something on the blackboard, then 2) you memorize it.""<br><br> You'll never memorize all the kanji by seeing them in a school house. You need Heisig and RtK!<br>#325<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 栄</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 栄  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=326"">flourish えい養</br></br></a>  ""The TREES FLOURISH in the CLASSROOM, a little too much perhaps, there's no room for the students any more.""<br><br> Students are like young trees. They tend to flourish in the schoolhouse.<br>#326<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 書</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 書  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=327"">write かき</br></br></a>  Make sure you practice writing kanji with a brush every day before the sun goes down.<br><br> ""The calligrapher had a peculiar habit: when using her brush to write, she would stick out her tongue, just slightly.""<br>#327<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 津</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 津  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=328"">haven</br></br></a>  A brush laying in dirty water is a haven for bacteria.<br><br> The haven for a BRUSH is in WATER.. Otherwise they get dry and withered and cant be used?!<br>#328<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 牧</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 牧  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=329"">breed</br></br></a>  ""Imagine a taskmaster giving a cow the command to """"start breeding, and start doing it now!"""", except that the cow takes his advice a bit too literally and starts chasing the taskmaster to carry out this command! instead of finding another cow to breed with. Hence, you see the taskmaster running to the right, trying to stay ahead of the cow.""<br><br> ""Hint: This is the kanji from which taskmaster is derived. Actually, this kanji has nothing to do with breed, and a lot to do with pastures and shepherds (also for cowboys, japanese and spanish don't differenciate between animals). Think of a cowboy (taskmaster) who brings his cows to the pasture.""<br>#329<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 攻</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 攻  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=330"">aggression</br></br></a>  Aggression is the craft of a good taskmaster.<br><br> AGGRESSION is a well-honed craft for any decent taskmaster.<br>#330<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 敗</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 敗  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=331"">failure 失敗</br></br></a>  <br><br> The shell who was defeated before (defeat (#63)) is being chastised by the taskmaster for his failure to win.<br>#331<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 枚</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 枚  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=332"">sheet of</br></br></a>  ""The taskmaster is a strict bathroom monitor who hands out only one sheet of really rough, splintery toilet paper per person. You can see the wood fibers.""<br><br> ""This taskmaster is the bathroom nazi: he counts how many sheets of toilet paper and tissue you use, and then tells you what % of a tree you just killed.""<br>#332<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 故</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 故  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=333"">happenstance/coincidence 何故</br></br></a>  An OLD TASKMASTER is no happenstance (coincidence). The older you get the more rigid in your ways.<br><br> Need to disambiguate from enemy (#443) as it's easy to mix up antique and old here. Let's think of an accidental president -- he is an old taskmaster who has managed to win the election by happenstance .<br>#333<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 敬</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 敬  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=334"">awe</br></br></a>  The flowery phrases of the schoolmaster held the students in awe.<br><br> 敬 【けい】 (n) reverence; respect. 敬語 【けいご】 (n) honorific; term of respect; (P) STORY: The TASKMASTER demands RESPECT. If you don't talk to him in HONORIFICS and FLOWERY PHRASES you will be sorry.<br>#334<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 言</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 言  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=335"">say</br></br></a>  A pictogram of someone saying a four letter word from their mouth after the censors have gotten a hold of it.<br><br> This is simple a pictogram of a mouth SAYing something. The lines are soundwaves. No need to complicate it.<br>#335<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 警</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 警  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=336"">admonish 警察</br></br></a>  To admonish is to enforce awe by means of words.<br><br> Watch in awe as mom admonishes the rude clerk with words that you've never heard her use before.<br>#336<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 計</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 計  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=337"">plot</br></br></a>  A plot is a summary of a book that can be given in ten words.<br><br> Say-ten's (satan's) evil plot.<br>#337<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 獄</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 獄  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=338"">prison 地獄</br></br></a>  The wild dog family visits their cousin in prison. They exchange words over the interphone at the visiting booth.<br><br> The only thing keeping the new chihuahua inmate from being 'initiated' by the pack of wild dogs were his quick words in prison.<br>#338<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 訂</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 訂  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=339"">revise</br></br></a>  ""Revise, revise and revise until you have all the words nailed down.""<br><br> Remember how Martin Luther revised the words of the catholic church and nailed his 95 Theses at the door of the church in Wittenberg?<br>#339<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 討</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 討  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=340"">chastise</br></br></a>  ""I said some bad words, and my mother chastised me by washing my mouth out with glue instead of soap!""<br><br> ""In Colonial New England, people who committed adultery had words glued to them. A famous example is the """"A"""" worn by Hester Prynn for committing adultery (i.e., not being chaste). In this way, words glued to you are supposed to chastise you and prevent further breaches of chastity.""<br>#340<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 訓</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 訓  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=341"">instruction</br></br></a>  ""The best type of Japanese INSTRUCTION is full immersion, which consists of going to Japan and swimming in the stream of words that surrounds you every day.""<br><br> Listen carefully to the words of instruction before you try swimming in the river.<br>#341<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 詔</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 詔  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=342"">imperial edict ちょく</br></br></a>  ""The mnemonic """"words to seduce the masses"""" was just too vague and I kept forgetting it. So now instead I picture a seductive female reading aloud the imperial edict to the masses, thus """"seducing"""" the masses.""<br><br> The emperor did not need an imperial edict; his words were more than enough to seduce Anakin to the dark side.<br>#342<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 詰</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 詰  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=343"">packed</br></br></a>  WORDS of GOOD LUCK are PACKED into fortune cookies.<br><br> ""Nowadays, grafitti comes pre-packaged. The factory takes a bunch of words and aerosol cans and then makes sure the words get tightly packed inside. All you have to do is spray and everything takes care of itself!""<br>#343<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 話</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 話  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=344"">tale はなし</br></br></a>  ""Tales are always spoken, not written, and because of this, words fly out of your tongue, rather than your pen.""<br><br> ""Tales are spoken words, passed on from person to person, eventually being spoken by a thousand mouths.""<br>#344<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 詠</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 詠  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=345"">recitation えいしょう</br></br></a>  ""Listening to the words in a recitation of Vogon poetry is worse than spending an eternity in hell.""<br><br> ""If you study some words for a recitation, there is a good chance they will be stuck in your memory for all eternity.""<br>#345<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 詩</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 詩  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=346"">poem し</br></br></a>  A poem is a temple of words.<br><br> WORDS used in a TEMPLE must be very well chosen. That's why most people will speak using a poem if they are SAYING something in a TEMPLE.<br>#346<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 語</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 語  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=347"">word ご</br></br></a>  The simplest word to say is I.<br><br> May I say a word about that?<br>#347<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 読</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 読  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=348"">read</br></br></a>  Read the WORDS used to SELL things.<br><br> People will say (言) almost anything to make a sale (売); don't believe everything you read (読).<br>#348<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 調</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 調  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=349"">tune ちょう　調理　調子　調査　調整</br></br></a>  ""To tune an old-fashioned radio, you turn the dial the full range of the circumference, until you can clearly hear what's being said.""<br><br> words + circumference The most catchy tunes are words the go round and round the circuference of your head and you can't get it out of your mind.<br>#349<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 談</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 談  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=350"">discuss</br></br></a>  Think of an online discussion group where misunderstanding someone's words leads to flaming. An angry discussion = inflamed words.<br><br> Internet discussions often involve inflammatory words. Flame war!<br>#350<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 諾</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 諾  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=351"">consent 承諾</br></br></a>  The words of the very young are useless without CONSENT from their elders.<br><br> ""Delores might say, """"Yes!"""", but she's way too young give any legal consent.""<br>#351<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 諭</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 諭  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=352"">rebuke</br></br></a>  A PETA activist speaks at a meeting of butchers to rebuke them.<br><br> ""I imagine Socrates gate-crashing a meeting of butchers and REBUKING them: 'You've been killing things again; you have, haven't you?' while the embarrassed butchers blush and try to hide their knives behind their backs and stand in front of hanging sides of beef.""<br>#352<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 式</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 式  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=353"">style</br></br></a>  Each Indian tribe crafts their arrows in a certain style..<br><br> The latest style is shirts crafted out of arrows.<br>#353<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 試</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 試  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=354"">test</br></br></a>  ""In an essay test, you are judged on both your choice of words and your writing style.""<br><br> The Japanese oral exam was a test of my speaking style.<br>#354<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 弐</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 弐  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=355"">II (two)</br></br></a>  ""II (older form of writing 2). After shooting one arrow (the dash top left), I have 2 arrows left in my quiver (bottom left).""<br><br> ""Once you have two old arrows left in your quiver, you better start running...!""<br>#355<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 域</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 域  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=356"">range</br></br></a>  ""An astronaut lands back at the launch range, kisses the earth beneath him with his mouth, then heads off to a fiesta to celebrate a safe flight.""<br><br> ""Instead of Heisig's """"Fiesta"""" I use """"Spear"""". Why? A spear is just a DROP extra on an Arrow. 域, range actually means range as in limits/boundary/border sort of range(In a box it was the old meaning for Country國 (581). Ok way too much etymology here, but back to story. With your SPEAR standing in a HOLE on the FLOOR with SOIL to its left9as you dug some out), you can see the RANGE of the spear in attacking a possible enemy (re Diablo and other RPGs, spear's have range).""<br>#356<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 賊</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 賊  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=357"">burglar</br></br></a>  Burglars... those guys!!! Burglars only want money (clams) so that they can get needles (drugs) and party (fiesta)!<br><br> ""After the fiesta, we found out that some burglar had stolen our money, probably breaking in with a lockpick needle...""<br>#357<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 栽</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 栽  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=358"">plantation</br></br></a>  The plantation is where we get our Christmas trees. We pick them out at Thanksgiving to be sure we get a good one.<br><br> <br>#358<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 載</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 載  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=359"">load のせる</br></br></a>  ""After eating a big Thanksgiving dinner, you have to be careful in the car ride home not to drop a load in your pants.""<br><br> ""After 'Thanksgiving' dinner, my girlfriend gave me a BJ on the drive back home. I blew my 'load' and 'soiled' the 'car'. But it was LOADS of fun! Please report this story if this makes you feel uncomfortable :).""<br>#359<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 茂</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 茂  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=360"">overgrown</br></br></a>  ""The gay parade looks astonishing, as if overgrown with flowers.""<br><br> ""When your garden gets OVERGROWN, it's like the plants are mocking you. Here, you can see the roses actually parading around the yard, wilfully choking out the other, more docile plants. Then they actually go and parade down the street!""<br>#360<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 成</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 成  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=361"">turn into</br></br></a>  It only takes a single stroke of a dagger for a parade to TURN INTO a bloodbath.<br><br> The gay parade suddenly TURNED INTO a DAGGER throwing fight.<br>#361<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 城</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 城  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=362"">castle しろ</br></br></a>  The sand castle is just the <b>soil</b> (#150) that <b>turns into</b> a castle.<br><br> """"""Someday this mound of dirt here will turn into our CASTLE"""", the ants think to themselves when scoping out a new ant hill.""<br>#362<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 誠</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 誠  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=363"">sincerity</br></br></a>  Sincerity happens when what you say actually turns into something.<br><br> Sincerity is turning your words into actions.<br>#363<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 威</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 威  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=364"">intimidate</br></br></a>  The march of women - against intimidation in the workplace - is pretty intimidating in itself!<br><br> ""Interesting that this kanji also has the meanings of """"dignity"""" and """"threaten."""" I can see how a march of women in Japan would be seen as intimidating by most men.""<br>#364<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 滅</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 滅  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=365"">destroy</br></br></a>  Water flows down to destroy the march of fire.<br><br> <br>#365<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 減</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 減  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=366"">dwindle</br></br></a>  ""When WATER was tossed on the PROTESTORS (a march of mouths), the numbers began to DWINDLE.""<br><br> ""When water supplies dwindled, the population became a horde of dry mouths, marching to seize the water in the neighboring kingdom.""<br>#366<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 桟</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 桟  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=367"">scaffold</br></br></a>  Japanese festival floats are often so tall they need wood scaffolds to be completed. (http://www.japan-guide.com/e/e5909.html).<br><br> <br>#367<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 銭</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 銭  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=368"">coin せん</br></br></a>  Political hopefuls in Rome threw gold COINS from floats when they were campaigning for office.<br><br> Interesting fact: The Japanese one yen coin is the only coin in the world that can float on water. http://www.hanamiweb.com/floatingyen.jpg.<br>#368<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 浅</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 浅  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=369"">shallow あさい</br></br></a>  The water can't be too SHALLOW if you expect to float.<br><br> The water isn't shallow enough to ford (#372). We'll have to cross by float!<br>#369<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 止</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 止  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=370"">stop</br></br></a>  ""If you find in the ground a walking stick with a magic wand, STOP! Maybe it's some kind of macumba/black magic/voodoo bad thing.""<br><br> ""If you don't remember this one from the 10,000,000 STOP signs on roads all over Japan, you're beyyond help!""<br>#370<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 歩</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 歩  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=371"">walk あるく</br></br></a>  ""When walking your pet, you must stop a few times along the way when nature calls.""<br><br> ""When you learn to walk, you take your steps a few at a time. Picture a clumsy but happy toddler who falls every few steps but keeps getting up to try again.""<br>#371<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 渉</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 渉  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=372"">ford</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""A ford is a place where one can walk through the water, a place only a few footsteps deep.""<br>#372<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 頻</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 頻  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=373"">repeatedly&nbsp; </br></br></a>  I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head.<br><br> ""Are you familiar with the joke about the ditzy secretary who repeatedly walked back and forth forcibly over all the pages of her boss' most important letters. When confronted she just says """"Well you said they needed to be stamped before they're mailed."""".""<br>#373<br></span>"

And those good old warrior boys, drinking whiskey and rye, said pay up the clams or you'll die. Pay up the clams or you'll die..."""".""<br>#378<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 正</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 正  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=379"">correct ただしい</br></br></a>  If you do it correct on the first attempt you can stop.<br><br> ""The correct way of learning Japanese? First, stop everything you're doing. Then, go pick up a copy of Heisig's book and work from there.""<br>#379<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 政</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 政  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=381"">politics 政府</br></br></a>  Those involved in politics are always trying to elect the correct taskmaster.<br><br> ""Insane political correctness on the left, and facists taskmasters on the right- thats politics in a nutshell right there.""<br>#381<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 定</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 定  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=382"">determine</br></br></a>  ""In The Karate Kid, the boy must prove his determination by MENDING his teacher's HOUSE in various ways.""<br><br> ""People who decide to renovate (ooh, that's a fancy word, let's say """"mend"""") their houses must be very determined DIYers. (Using DIY helps me remember this story when I see DEtermine).""<br>#382<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 錠</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 錠  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=383"">lock&nbsp;じょう</br></br></a>  ""Even if you lock up your GOLD, a DETERMINED thief will get it in the end.""<br><br> ""The best stories for this kanji tend to have a thief in them, which always makes me confuse them with the kanji for burglar (357). So, let's try this one: My girlfriend wears a metal chastity belt with a lock but I am determined to open it! I must get inside!""<br>#383<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 走</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 走  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=384"">run</br></br></a>  ""Hint: This kanji is NOT soil on top of mend, as Heisig claims - that would duplicate one of the strokes. Instead, it is 10 on top of mend. So my story is: If you run 10 miles, you will need to mend your socks!""<br><br> The sports ground needs MENDING after the game as the players have been RUNNING around which has caused the ground to be chopped up.<br>#384<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 超</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 超  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=385"">transcend ちょう</br></br></a>  ""A successful marathon <b>run</b>ner needs to be able to transcend <b>seductions</b>, such as the possibility of rest, shelter from the rain, or a cold beer.""<br><br> ""To transcend oneself is to reach a higher plane of reality. A head shaven monk is telling me this. We are in a Tibetan monastery. He was once an athlete, a runner. He used to run everywhere, until one day, he saw a beautiful cheerleader along his path. She tried very hard to seduce him, but he forced himself to transcend his urges. He did reach his running goal, and he has became a lonely monk. He wishes now he had just broken down back then and....""<br>#385<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 赴</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 赴  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=386"">proceed 赴く</br></br></a>  """"""Don't run into trouble,"""" Dumbledore tells Harry. """"Proceed with caution with your wand out."""".""<br><br> ""While running, my magic wand tells me where to proceed.""<br>#386<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 越</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 越  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=387"">surpass</br></br></a>  The person in charge of<b> running</b> the <b>parade</b> surpassed all our expectations (by just a <b>extra drop</b>...).<br><br> The parade of runners are all trying to SURPASS each other - and they end up running all the way to Vietnam (note that this kanji is also used for the country of Vietnam).<br>#387<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 是</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 是  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=388"">just so 是非</br></br></a>  'Sun' 'Mend' - It just so happens that sunshine can mend your gloomy spirits.<br><br> My image here is of Fabrice (the guy who runs this website) spending all day obsessively mending the code so this page looks just so....<br>#388<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 題</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 題  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=389"">topic 問だい</br></br></a>  ""The """"TOPIC"""" of the day's newspaper must be placed JUST SO at the top of the PAGE to attract attention.""<br><br> ""You spend ALL DAY, mending your socks JUST SO. Then you have a look at the HEADING of the newspaper. The topic---FREE SOCKS TO BE GIVEN AWAY!!!!""<br>#389<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 堤</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 堤  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=390"">dike つつみ</br></br></a>  Making a dike is all about arranging the soil just so....<br><br> <br>#390<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 建</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 建  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=391"">build</br></br></a>  ""Build is easy to remember if you can remember that archtiechts have two steps in building. 1. Take a brush and brush out the blueprints. 2. Get a visual image of the blueprints all rolled up like they usually are. The second step is easy, it's just the architecht stretching out the blueprints and showing it to his clients.""<br><br> ""A construction worker's classic morning. Stretch, brush his teeth, and then start to build.""<br>#391<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 延</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 延  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=392"">prolong</br></br></a>  Stretching correctly prolongs life. Even the top part of 正 is stretching...<br><br> ""Here's a great mnemonic: """"stop, drop, and stretch (!?)."""" Now let's associate it with 'prolong': if you're ever in an uncomfortable spot, like being asked tricky questions or caught in a lie, just PROLONG the situation - stop, drop, and stretch. They may be confused by your odd behaviour, but it'll buy you a few moments to think up another good lie to get out of the sticky situation!""<br>#392<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 誕</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 誕  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=393"">nativity</br></br></a>  ""Nativity = born, being born. Think of birth as a painful and prolonged event. And of course, all the words and curses being yelled at the soon-to-be father for doing this to her!""<br><br> ""When you are being born ( nativity ), your mother's WORDS are PROLONGED. (Thiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiis huuuuuuuuuuuuuurtss a lottttttttt~!! Owwwwwww!!!).""<br>#393<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 礎</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 礎  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=394"">cornerstone</br></br></a>  Features like stones and groves of trees are the cornerstones of a happy zoo.<br><br> ""A zoo which is still under construction is already full of animals. At the moment, only the cornerstone has been set in place. To temporarily keep the animals from escaping, a closely-packed grove of small trees is planted around the stone. (Note that this zoo needs some serious mending.).""<br>#394<br></span>"

(It's a stretch, but the way I remembered this kanji is through that phrase. This way you can remember it through using primitives we have already learned.).""<br>#396<br></span>"
