I'm not sure, but mine always wears a top hat and scarf, and for some reason its back door port is always open...""<br>#399<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 壊</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 壊  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=400"">demolition 崩壊</br></br></a>  ""If you stand too close to a DEMOLITION site, the dust might sting you like NEEDLES in your EYE and get your GARMENTs all dirty.""<br><br> ""Since that needle eye thing turns up a lot, I turned it into Darth Vader. It kinda looks like him to me, with the eye being his metal mouth piece thing. So, Darth Vader swings his cape (his garment) demolishing a nearby building, leaving nothing but a pile of dirt.""<br>#400<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 哀</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 哀  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=401"">pathetic</br></br></a>  One of my friends with a crazy sense of fashion loves to wear a tophat and a scarf so that you can't see his whole face but only his mouth. He thinks it's cool. I think it's pathetic.<br><br> ""A poor, homeless child like Oliver Twist, with a hungry open mouth, is pathetic-- in the original sense of the noun """"pathos."""" The tattered tophat and scarf he wears only adds to the pathos.""<br>#401<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 遠</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 遠  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=402"">distant とおい</br></br></a>  Keep distant from a lidded crock on the road wrapped in a scarf. It might be a bomb.<br><br> ""When traveling to a distant land, what better way of keeping warm on the road is there than carrying a warm lidded crock and wearing a scarf?""<br>#402<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 猿</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 猿  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=403"">monkey さる</br></br></a>  The MONKEY likes to play hide and seek with the PACK of WILD DOGS by hiding in the LIDDED CROCK. But he is easy to see because the SCARF he always wears is at the base of the LIDDED CROCK.<br><br> ""To catch a monkey, chase him with wild dogs into a lidded crock, then tie it with a scarf.""<br>#403<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 初</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 初  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=404"">first time</br></br></a>  """"""This is the first time we've been out of the Shire, Mr. Frodo!"""" Says Sam, covering himself with his cloak and clutching his dagger.""<br><br> ""On his FIRST TIME, he cloaked his dagger with a Trojan.""<br>#404<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 布</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 布  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=405"">linen</br></br></a>  A matador holding his red linen by his side.<br><br> ""The first rule of the Hitch-Hiker's Guide to the Universe is """"DON'T PANIC!"""" The second rule, of course, is to always have a towel by your side. Personally, I prefer the linen sort.""<br>#405<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 帆</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 帆  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=406"">sail</br></br></a>  ""When stranded at sea, we needed a Sail. The best we had was a TOWEL, which was MEDICORE, only catching a DROP of WIND.""<br><br> A towel makes a mediocre sail.<br>#406<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 幅</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 幅  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=407"">hanging scroll&nbsp;はば</br></br></a>  ""In the west, the rich use $100 bills to light their cigars... In Japan, after showering, when the wealthy don't have any clean towels, they simply grab a hanging scroll off the wall and use it to dry off!""<br><br> The towels of the wealthy: hanging scrolls.<br>#407<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 帽</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 帽  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=408"">cap ぼう子</br></br></a>  <br><br> Originally the first cap was a turban which was a towel wrapped around the head to keep the sun out of the eyes.<br>#408<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 幕</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 幕  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=409"">curtain</br></br></a>  ""There is a graveyard outside my house that scares me, so I put a huge towel over the window to serve as a curtain so I can get a good nights sleep.""<br><br> ""When you're dead in the graveyard, """"it's curtains for you."""".""<br>#409<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 幌</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 幌  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=410"">canopy&nbsp;ほろ</br></br></a>  A canopy is a towel to block the suns rays.<br><br> ""From the Hitch-Hiker's Guide to the Universe: A towel is useful, among other things, as a canopy to keep out the sun's rays from your face while napping.""<br>#410<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 錦</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 錦  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=411"">brocade</br></br></a>  Brocade is the art of sewing gold on a white towel.<br><br> ""Never heard of this word before encountering it here. So it turns out that the fanciest brocade in the world is actually a towel used by a Turkish monarch. It's embroidered with gold and cocaine. Yes, cocaine - what you thought it'd be something else? That is some true art right there. I think a great many people would want to own this towel.""<br>#411<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 市</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 市  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=412"">market</br></br></a>  ""My recurring nightmare: Walking through the market, and suddenly realizing that I'm wearing only a top hat...and a towel.""<br><br> At the MARKET you find lots of nice TOP HATS and TOWELS.<br>#412<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 姉</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 姉  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=413"">elder sister</br></br></a>  ""Unlike the younger sister (妹), who is not yet old enough to date... the elder sister is on the market!""<br><br> She's old enough to be allowed to go to the market.<br>#413<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 肺</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 肺  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=414"">lungs</br></br></a>  LUNGS are a PART of the BODY that can be found at any meat MARKET or black MARKET.<br><br> ""The PART OF THE BODY most important if you work at a MARKET is your LUNGS so that you can shout out at the top of your voice """"IRASSHAIMASEEE"""" to attract customers.""<br>#414<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 帯</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 帯  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=415"">sash</br></br></a>  ""First, note that the top half of the kanji consists of one and mountain. Of course, the """"number 1"""" mountain in Japan is Mt. Fuji. The bottom half, under Mt. Fuji, consists of crown and towel. Now for the story. Archaeologists digging under Mt. Fuji (Japan's #1 mountain) in an ancient royal tomb (they know it's royal because of the crown) discover what looks like a towel, but after they clean it up, they see it is actually a splendid royal sash for the king's kimono.""<br><br> ""Beautiful """"Miss Housewife Japan"""" is on posters everywhere, cooking right before Mt. Fuji (the number one mountain) while wearing nothing but her crown, and an apron tied with a sash. (hodgepodge of mspertus, zwarte_kat, et al, with a jot of hadaka apron to focus the image.).""<br>#415<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 滞</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 滞  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=416"">stagnate</br></br></a>  ""History of the first karate blackbelts: In those days, it was often difficult to find fresh, clean water, so samurai usually had to wash their sashes in stagnant puddles. The longer one had been studying martial arts, the older the sash on one's karate uniform and, therefore, the darker the color. So why weren't their karate uniforms black too? Never seen a ninja????""<br><br> A moat is a stagnate ring of water like an obi (sash) of water tied around the castle.<br>#416<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 刺</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 刺  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=417"">thorn</br></br></a>  ""A TREE with a BELT wrapped around the middle. If you tighten the BELT, hundreds of tiny SABERS pop out of the tree in all directions, looking like THORNS.""<br><br> The BELT TREE has THORNS like SABERS.<br>#417<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 制</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 制  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=418"">system</br></br></a>  The system for making leather belts involves slicing up a cow with a sword.<br><br> ""Why all the gore and violence? How about a samurai cow? He doesn't have to be a violent samurai, either. He only wears the sword because he's part of the bushi SYSTEM. Actually, he studies ikebana, shodo, and zen. Imagine him sitting cross-legged in a Zen temple (a very Special Zen temple). The master asks him if a dog has buddha nature and, shifting the swords in his belt, he calmly replies, """"Moo!"""".""<br>#418<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 製</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 製  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=419"">made in...</br></br></a>  Made in china - a system of exploitation . making garments for nothing.<br><br> A SYSTEMATICALLY made GARMENT will no doubt have MADE IN on the label.<br>#419<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 転</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 転  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=420"">revolve</br></br></a>  The REVOLVING wheels of the car (with REVOLVER blaring on the stereo) kicked up RISING CLOUDS of dust.<br><br> ""Just a note to remember the cloud primative: The name of Goku's pet cloud that he used to help him rise (fly) in the Dragonball anime series (and also the scientific name for a certain type of cloud) is Nimbus [ http://www.rpgclassics.com/shrines/gba/dbztlog/screen2.jpg ]. The katakana-ization of this is {ニム}バス, so the rising cloud primative is just an abbreviation of that name written from top to bottom in the old Japanese style.""<br>#420<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 芸</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 芸  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=421"">technique</br></br></a>  ""Imagine an old Kung-fu movie: """"Try my rising cloud flower technique!!!"""" smash pow crack!! .""<br><br> One technique to smoke weed is to vaporize it and inhale those rising clouds to create a stronger effect.<br>#421<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 雨</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 雨  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=422"">rain</br></br></a>  From the ceiling hangs a towel dripping four drops like RAIN.<br><br> ""Towel hung out on a line to ....oops, it's rain.""<br>#422<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 雲</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 雲  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=423"">cloud</br></br></a>  Every rising cloud is a potential rain cloud. (Thanks astridtops).<br><br> Every cloud is a potential rain cloud.<br>#423<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 曇</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 曇  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=424"">cloudy weather 曇り</br></br></a>  Cloudy weather is when a cloud blocks the sun (up above).<br><br> ""In cloudy weather, the sun is still there even if obscured by the clouds...　RTK2:　ドン　曇天　どんてん(cloudy skies).""<br>#424<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 雷</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 雷  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=425"">thunder かみなり</br></br></a>  ""If it's raining and you're standing in the middle of a rice field, you're sure to soon become acquainted with the thunder up close and personal.""<br><br> ""Thunder is a sure sign of rain coming. When you hear the thunder, you've got time to get out of the field before it starts raining.""<br>#425<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 霜</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 霜  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=426"">frost</br></br></a>  ""FROST is kind of an inter-weather, phenomenon, something between rain, snow and freezing temp’s.""<br><br> ""The freezing RAIN formed FROST on the TREE right before your EYES. If you want, frost-y then think Frost Tree to get to the mnemonic. SECOND STORY: FROSTY the snowman? It's RAIN that FROSTS that can then INTER-act with the kids, till he melts of course.""<br>#426<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 冬</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 冬  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=427"">winter</br></br></a>  ""Don't slip off your legs in winter, strap two skis to your feet.""<br><br> In winter my walking legs feel like blocks of ice.<br>#427<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 天</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 天  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=428"">heavens</br></br></a>  ""If you think of the sky as a ceiling above our heads, here you have the heavens as the largest ceiling you could ever imagine. As Heisig pointed out, nothing comes above the ceiling primitive thus the order of primitives is taken care of.""<br><br> ""The ceiling that all large dogs aspire to go to is known as heaven. After all, All Dogs Go to Heaven.""<br>#428<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 橋</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 橋  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=429"">bridge はし</br></br></a>  ""The nicest bridge is not in Hollywood or Los Angeles, but in San Francisco.""<br><br> ""A small 5 year old child has lost her mother in a tragic death. Her family tells her, """"Don't worry, your mom is an angel now, in heaven, watching over you."""" The small girl takes this very literally and is found one day, gathering pieces of wood. Her dad asks her, """"What are you doing with that wood?"""" """"I'm trying to build a bridge to heaven to visit the angels."""".""<br>#429<br></span>"

Similarly, angelic women tend to be attractive.""<br>#430<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 競</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 競  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=434"">vie</br></br></a>  TWO twin BROTHERS are competing (VYING) for the title of who is the older BROTHER. The game is that they must balance a VASE on their head and the one who drops his looses and becomes the younger BROTHER!<br><br> Two crazy brothers vying for the guiness records books of stupidity by trying to stand on their heads the longest.<br>#434<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 帝</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 帝  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=435"">sovereign みかど</br></br></a>  ""The crazy sovereign stands up from his throne, wearing nothing but a crown and a towel. That's why they try to keep him locked up in the castle away from the public.""<br><br> ""This one is so tricky for me. The key is to remember that the bottom stroke on the standing element takes those little crown """"winglets"""" on the right and left. The most effective image might be of QEII (who is quite short) using her crown as a kind of stool. She's standing on her crown rummaging through a high cupboard looking for her apron. I guess the sovereign's servants have the day off.""<br>#435<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 童</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 童  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=436"">juvenile 童貞</br></br></a>  The juvenile stood on top of his computer and broke it. Noob.<br><br> ""The movie Zoolander is a little JUVENILE and silly, but I love it nonetheless. Just remember Owen Wilson standing on the desk, hitting the computer like a monkey. (The files are IN the computer - IN the computer...).""<br>#436<br></span>"

It can be confusing to use a story that has pupil meaning student in it.<br>#437<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 商</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 商  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=439"">make a deal</br></br></a>  The STANDING member at the top is a certain part of the body that all men have and it is approaching the HOLE between TWO LEGS (the HOOD) with extra marks to show they are FLESHY - ie a womans legs. So this shows the oldest DEAL of all time - prostitution.<br><br> ""Slick Willy standing on the motorcycle helmet he's trying to sell you to demonstrate how rugged it is. His legs crash through the top of it and after a moment of awkward silence his mouth opens and says, """"hey, we can still make a deal."""".""<br>#439<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 嫡</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 嫡  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=440"">legitimate wife 嫡男</br></br></a>  Legitmate wifes tend to be women who are antiques in contrast to the young bit of illigitmate fluff on the side.<br><br> Your legitimate wife is like an antique bong. Its not your favorite but you still hit it sometimes...<br>#440<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 適</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 適  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=441"">suitable</br></br></a>  ""Think of the term from televison """"suitable for all audiences"""" to get the sense of the word. What program could be more suitable for the whole family than the """"antiques road(show)"""".""<br><br> That old thing in your attic might be suitable to be shown on the Antiques Roadshow.<br>#441<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 滴</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 滴  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=442"">drip</br></br></a>  DRIPS of WATER were collected in ANTIQUE VASES since the museum had a leaky roof.<br><br> You must never let water drip onto antiques.<br>#442<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 敵</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 敵  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=443"">enemy てき</br></br></a>  The taskmaster became my enemy for life when he smashed the antique vase holding my wife's ashes.<br><br> Indiana Jones is an enemy of taskmasters in search of antique artifacts. RTK2: 　テキ　敵地　てきち(enemy territory)...　　　　　　　　　　　Pure Group:　嫡440　適441　滴442 　摘657.<br>#443<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 匕</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 匕  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=444"">spoon</br></br></a>  ""To remember the primitive meaning, picture someone sitting on the ground performing Seppuku...with a spoon. http://tinyurl.com/co48k.""<br><br> ""Not only is stroke order important, but also be sure to note the direction of a stroke. In both 'spoon' and 'seven', the first stroke is the horizontal one - but here it is written right to left in a downward flick, while in 'seven' it is a strong line from left to right.""<br>#444<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 北</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 北  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=445"">north きた</br></br></a>  Warning: The left part is NOT the primitive turtle! The stroke order is different. Sometimes it will look exactly the same but not always depending on the font / style used to draw this character. Be sure to study the difference!<br><br> ""In the north, the weather is so cold that people are often seen sitting back to back to preserve warmth.""<br>#445<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 背</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 背  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=446"">stature せ中</br></br></a>  ""While japanese people are generally small, people in the northern contryes have taller stature because of all the flesh they eat!""<br><br> ""Up in the Great White North, we eat a lot of meat - thus giving us great STATURE. Mmmm.... baby seals.""<br>#446<br></span>"

(Amaterasu, the sun godesss). Sun, comparing = descendants.""<br>#448<br></span>"

So you pull out a bottle of WATER and pretend you're going to give it to him...but then you dump it all on the ground before his eyes. HAHA, sucked in muchacho!!""<br>#451<br></span>"

Imagine peering through a microscope at a vast sea teeming with microbial life (and perhaps a minaturized submarine). Note: Take care not to confuse with ocean (#549).""<br>#461<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 乾</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 乾  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=463"">drought</br></br></a>  ""During a drought, everything begs for even a mist for relief.""<br><br> Beggar has to drink mist because there is no water in the drought. I get this one confused with thirst 451 but try to remember that there is no water element beacuse it is a drought.<br>#463<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 腹</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 腹  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=464"">abdomen はら</br></br></a>  The only <b>body part</b> that <b>doubles over</b>.<br><br> ""Imagine getting punched in the abdomen, a fairly tender part of flesh, and instead of doubling forward, you double back. That would be pretty painful.""<br>#464<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 複</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 複  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=465"">duplicate ふく数</br></br></a>  ""My girlfiend saw someone wearing the exact same (duplicate) outfit at a party, so she doubled back to change!""<br><br> ""In Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, Hermione uses a device called a """"time-turner"""" to double back in time, but this creates duplicates. The smart thing to do would be to combine Hermione's time-turner with Harry's invisibility cloak. That way, one could double back in time without creating any visible duplicates.""<br>#465<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 欠</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 欠  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=466"">lack</br></br></a>  ""To me, this kanji looks like a person with two arms and two legs, but who lacks a head.""<br><br> When your body lacks oxygen you yawn.<br>#466<br></span>"

(I am sorry for the image, but it sticks forever in your mind).""<br><br> I keep confusing this with suck (#689). Consider someone blowing bubbles using their chewing gum because they're lacking attention in class.<br>#467<br></span>"

Yet these so called can-can dancers are flat-chested and singing a song, so audience of men is yawning in boredom.""<br>#469<br></span>"

Thinking like that, you'll end up alone in an old folks home longing for the good old days!""<br><br> ""Whenever I am next to a woman, I can't help but take notice of her figure.""<br>#474<br></span>"

Because, you know, actual consultants charge huge sums.""<br><br> """"""Consulting with"""" is having words with the next mouth.""<br>#475<br></span>"
