"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 培</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 培  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=477"">cultivate</br></br></a>  ""To cultivate the land is to tame it, control it. In short, you muzzle it's unruly, chaotic nature.""<br><br> The illegal immigrants cultivate the land but are socially and politically muzzled (wear muzzles while they work too).<br>#477<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 剖</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 剖  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=478"">divide</br></br></a>  ""When you DIVIDE someone, there is sure to be a lot of screaming. That's why you should use a MUZZLE before using the SABER.""<br><br> ""Divide and conquer - first you cut them up (saber) , then you shut them up (muzzle).""<br>#478<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 音</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 音  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=479"">sound</br></br></a>  ""If you were standing on the sun, believe me, you'd be making sound.""<br><br> ""The tongue wagging in a mouth produces a very high-pitched sound, breaking a nearby vase.""<br>#479<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 暗</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 暗  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=480"">darkness </br></br></a>  Picture the sun exploding - there would be a gigantic noise and then...nothing. Everything would plunge into darkness.<br><br> ""In places of complete darkness, such as caves where the sun can't reach, creatures such as bats have learned to navigate by sound rather than sight. The poor guys must have to fly around screaming """"Marco!"""" and """"Polo!"""" all the time.""<br>#480<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 韻</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 韻  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=481"">rhyme</br></br></a>  What is a RHYME but some SOUND that EMPLOYEES say to get them through work.<br><br> ""Dr Seuss's employee finally rebels against him: """"I'm tired of odd sounds all the time, I will not, cannot, speak in RHYME!"""".""<br>#481<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 識</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 識  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=482"">discriminating しき別</br></br></a>  Words are difficult to discriminate/discern from sounds in the middle of a fiesta.<br><br> I have discriminating taste. I'd rather listen to the words of a lecture than attend a kazoo concert. (Picture some snobby guy in a tweed jacket turning up his nose at entering a loud raucous kazoo recital).<br>#482<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 鏡</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 鏡  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=483"">mirror</br></br></a>  Mirror should suggest vanity. Imagine a spoiled girl who gets her parents to buy her a Golden mirror so she can stand in front of it all day vainly admiring her lovely human legs.<br><br> metal + stand up + sun + legs remember the legend of Amaterasu who retired in a cave. the other Gods brought a MIRROR made of polished METAL at the entrance of the cave. Amaterasu who was STANDING UP saw her image of the SUN and began to dance with her LEGS.<br>#483<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 境</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 境  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=484"">boundary&nbsp;さかい</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""This is an old trick to keep out migrants. You put a bunch of dirty mirrors on the boundary of your land and theirs. When they approach the boundary, what they see in the mirror is their own land and someone that looks like themselves, only dirtier, so they figure your country isn't any better than their own and they head back home.""<br>#484<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 亡</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 亡  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=485"">deceased</br></br></a>  The top hat hanging on a hook belonged to the now deceased Charlie Chaplin.<br><br> The recently DECEASED are said to hang their hats on a hook by the door to the afterlife.<br>#485<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 盲</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 盲  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=486"">blind</br></br></a>  Deceased eyes! Easy ;).<br><br> A person with deceased eyes is blind.<br>#486<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 妄</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 妄  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=487"">delusion</br></br></a>  ""The delusional woman was carrying her deceased husband on her back.""<br><br> ""If you think you should perish for that woman, you have a major delusion.""<br>#487<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 荒</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 荒  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=488"">laid waste</br></br></a>  ""After Godzilla laid waste to the city, the survivors put some flowers on the bodies of the deceased and floated their bodies down the stream.""<br><br> ""Laying waste is just a euphamism for flushing poop down the toilet. It smells nothing like flowers, more like deceased flowers, and it's flushed down into a stream of sewage. Use """"waste"""" to avoid destroy (#365) demolition (#400).""<br>#488<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 望</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 望  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=489"">ambition のぞむ</br></br></a>  ""You're dead meat, buddy, my ambition is to be king.""<br><br> The ambitions of kings often result in dead bodies.<br>#489<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 方</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 方  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=490"">direction</br></br></a>  Note: The primitives are top hat and bound up. Compare ten thousand (#64). Story: A rich man wearing a top hat and bound up from head to toe hobbles up to you and asks for directions to the nearest police station because he just escaped from his kidnappers.<br><br> I always keep my directions bound to the bottom of my top hat so I won't lose them.<br>#490<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 妨</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 妨  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=491"">disturb 妨げる</br></br></a>  <br><br> One way to Disturb a woman is to give her directions while she is in the middle of driving -- she just can't take that kind of stress.<br>#491<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 坊</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 坊  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=492"">boy ぼう</br></br></a>  Little boys always head in the direction of mud and dirt.<br><br> Boys thoughts often head in dirty directions.<br>#492<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 芳</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 芳  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=493"">perfumed こうばしい</br></br></a>  ""She used a perfume so strong, that you can track her by following the direction of the smell of flowers.""<br><br> ""People always seem to overdo it with their perfume. It seems that whenever I am at school, somebody walks by with their cheap flowery perfume. If I close my eyes, I can actually use that floweriness as a compass - it tells me which direction they're in.""<br>#493<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 肪</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 肪  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=494"">obese 脂肪</br></br></a>  """"""Flesh in all directions"""" = obese.""<br><br> ""Yo momma so obese, she changed the direction of the moon.""<br>#494<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 訪</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 訪  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=495"">call on おとずれる</br></br></a>  ""When you call on someone, you point your words in their direction.""<br><br> ""When calling on a girl, you'd better what what sweet words will turn her fancy in your direction. (Image: last century teenagers on a frilly couch in the sitting room, she with her back to him, and he fumbling for the right words to turn her around).""<br>#495<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 放</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 放  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=496"">set free はなす</br></br></a>  Go in any direction away from your taskmaster when you are set free.<br><br> ""When slaves were set free from their masters, they set off in all directions… RTK2:　ホウ　放射　ほうしゃ(radiation)… Pure group: 倣979.""<br>#496<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 激</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 激  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=497"">violent はげしい</br></br></a>  ""When the taskmaster found his favorite white compas damaged by water, he became the most violent taskmaster there ever was.""<br><br> Overnight the slave got Violent and was Set Free. Overnight....Set Free.<br>#497<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 脱</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 脱  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=498"">undress ぬぐ</br></br></a>  HORNY TEENAGERS love to UNDRESS FLESH.<br><br> Before you undress I should warn you -- the sight of flesh brings out the devil in me.<br>#498<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 説</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 説  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=499"">rumor せつ明</br></br></a>  The words of a horny teenager typically fall into one of two categories: either rumors or explanations.<br><br> The words of the devil incite rumours and false explanations.<br>#499<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 鋭</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 鋭  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=500"">pointed 鋭い</br></br></a>  Pointed is the metal devil's gold pitchfork.<br><br> ""The Horny teenager who worked part time at a gold smelting plant always had uncontrollable errections that pointed out all the time, this is not a good thing to have when you work in a gold smelting plant, surely he will one day end up with a Goldmember!""<br>#500<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 曽</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 曽  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=501"">formerly</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""Formerly, horned animals were used to plough the ricefield, and it took all day."" <br>#501<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 増</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 増  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=502"">increase</br></br></a>  Prices always INCREASE for LAND that was FORMERLY cheaper.<br><br> Farmers work the land so they can INCREASE their formerly puny crop supply.<br>#502<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 贈</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 贈  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=503"">presents</br></br></a>  Presents represent money that was formerly yours.<br><br> ""Imagine if the number of presents you get increases with each birthday. So on your first birthday, you receive just one shell as a present, but the next year it increases to two shells as presents, and so on, increasing and increasing so by the time you're elderly, the number of shells you'll get as presents will have increased to an awful lot of presents. GOT IT YET? PRESENTS = SHELLS + INCREASE.""<br>#503<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 東</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 東  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=504"">east ひがし</br></br></a>  Traditionally seen as a pictograph of the sun rising behind a tree.<br><br> The sun pierces through the trees as it rises in the east…　　　　　　RTK2:　トウ　東北　とうほく (the northeast)　東京　とうきょう(Tokyo)… MIXED GROUP　凍506　(ﾁﾝ):陳1301　(ﾚﾝ): 練1343　錬2030.<br>#504<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 棟</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 棟  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=505"">ridgepole</br></br></a>  Feng Shui states that the ridgepole of a house should be made of wood and face east.<br><br> ""Ok just a note to the 'ridgepole facing east story' im making up a story to JUSTIFY why that is the case. Assuming that 99% of you guys use the age old story of a 'sun rising through a tree tells you were the east is', back in those days when people used ridgepoles they wanted to align their houses in such a way that they face the rising sun, so they wake up with a bright day, and wake up early with the sun seeping through in a perpendicular manner( as the ridge pole faces the sun in the morning).""<br>#505<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 凍</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 凍  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=506"">frozen</br></br></a>  ""Eastern Siberia is often frozen by ice. According to wikipedia, Yakutia (in Eastern Siberia) holds the record as the coldest town on Earth. Check it out yourself...it made it stick for me!""<br><br> The ice will stay frozen until the sun is visible through the trees.<br>#506<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 妊</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 妊  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=507"">pregnancy にん娠</br></br></a>  A pregnant woman is a porter of her child.<br><br> The gentleman gave the woman a bit of sperm...BAM PREGNANCY!<br>#507<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 廷</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 廷  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=508"">courts</br></br></a>  A porter has run away from his master. His punishment is to be stretched out on the rack. So say the courts in this barbaric time.<br><br> The gentleman stretched the truth a bit in court.<br>#508<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 染</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 染  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=509"">dye</br></br></a>  ""To make this dye, I used water and the barks of nine different trees.""<br><br> The baseball team hangs their freshly dyed dripping jerseys at the top of a tree to dry.<br>#509<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 燃</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 燃  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=510"">burn</br></br></a>  Any<b> sort of thing</b> can burn in the<b> fire.</b><br><br> ""Somebody from PETA is really angry that they sell dog meat in China, so they've gone to burn down the whole cart (my mnemonic for """"sort of thing"""" was seeing strips of dog flesh roasting, and saying """"well, that's just the sort of thing they do here in China).""<br>#510<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 賓</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 賓  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=511"">V.I.P.</br></br></a>  ""This <b>house</b> is reserved to V.I.P. only. If you are not one of the<b> few</b> with enough <b>money</b> to call you that way, keep out!""<br><br> ""The V.I.P. visits your house, but your ceiling is too low for his inflated head, which he bumps and hurts. You have to give him your few shells as compensation.""<br>#511<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 歳</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 歳  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=512"">year-end さい</br></br></a>  ""Santa had to put his foot down to stop a march of little guys, namely elves. They were protesting the harsh treatment they get every year-end when Santa asks them to step up toy production for the holiday season.""<br><br> ""At the year-end, everything seems to come to a stop. However, there's still enough time for a little march to celebrate.""<br>#512<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 県</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 県  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=513"">prefecture</br></br></a>  ""In Japanese this is KEN, as in Barbie's boyfriend. He has lovely blue eyes, a girlfriend who is as thin as a straightened out fish hook. But, down where it counts, he has very little to show...""<br><br> ""After sticking a fishhook in your eye, the yakuza boss probably has little more to do to convince you to move to a different prefecture.""<br>#513<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 栃</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 栃  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=514"">horse chestnut&nbsp;</br></br></a>  ""There are a bunch of HORSE CHESTNUT TREES on top of this CLIFF above the beach. Chestnuts keep rolling off the cliff and falling on people's heads. So far TEN THOUSAND people have been killed by falling chestnuts, and the Japanese government still ain't did shit about it.""<br><br> ""There is a horse chestnut tree that has grown by a cliff for so long, it has deposited 10,000 horse chesnuts that lie at the bottom. Don't worry over this one too much, you'll spend so much time trying to figure out the right story for it, you probably won't forget it.""<br>#514<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 地</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 地  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=515"">ground</br></br></a>  <br><br> The soil is littered with billions of scorpions<br>#515<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 池</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 池  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=516"">pond いけ</br></br></a>  ""Remember the story of the scorpion that begged the turtle for a ride across the pond? Halfway across the water, the scorpion stung the turtle on the neck and they both sank to the bottom.""<br><br> Water scorpions loves to live in the pond.<br>#516<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 虫</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 虫  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=517"">insect</br></br></a>  ""I see the bottom of this kanji as an arm, and the top is an insect biting into the arm, sucking some blood.""<br><br> Insect in one drop of amber. Think Jurassic Park.<br>#517<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 蛍</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 蛍  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=518"">lightning bug</br></br></a>  Bugs have to go to school to learn how to become lightning bugs. Only the brightest bugs graduate to become lightning bugs.<br><br> ""Q: Who's the smartest insect in school? A: The lightning-bug. Because he's so bright! (Image: lightning bug in school with glasses, pocket protector, etc. Maybe even have some cool kids teasing him).""<br>#518<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 蛇</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 蛇  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=519"">snake へび</br></br></a>  ""A snake eats <b>insects</b> and he does that outside, while we eat in the <b>house</b> and preferably with a <b>spoon</b>.""<br><br> ""Solid Snake crawled like a bug, infiltrated my house, and took out everyone with a spoon.""<br>#519<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 虹</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 虹  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=520"">rainbow</br></br></a>  ""Little is it known that a rainbow is actually created by insects of different colours flying in formation, a craft they have perfected to create the rainbows we see today.""<br><br> ""Rainbow is of course created by billions of colored insects (what? you really thought it was an optical illusion?). However I had problems remembering that the insect primitive goes on the left. If you have similar difficulties, try this: rainbow is an Insect-Craft. Mnemonic: I.C. Rainbow (I see rainbow).""<br>#520<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 蝶</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 蝶  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=521"">butterfly</br></br></a>  A butterfly is an insect that appears after spending a generation on a tree as a cocoon.<br><br> ""Butterflies are insects that like to eat just the flowers but leave the leaves behind. (helps me to think of the kanji for leaves, minus the flower bit).""<br>#521<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 独</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 独  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=522"">single ひとり</br></br></a>  <br><br> A SINGLE guy is a WILD DOG who BUGS many women.<br>#522<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 蚕</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 蚕  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=523"">silkworm</br></br></a>  A silk worm is a heavenly insect<br><br> <br>#523<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 風</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 風  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=524"">wind かぜ</br></br></a>  They say that when an INSECT flaps its wings even the single DROP of WIND that it creates is sometimes enough to create a hurricane on the other side of the Earth.<br><br> ""The WIND usually carries things around in it - drops of rain or snow, and lots of insects.""<br>#524<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 己</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 己  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=525"">self おのれ</br></br></a>  ""This kanji looks like the """"s"""" of """"self"""", looking at its own reflection in a mirror (reversed sideways), as if pondering about his """"self"""".""<br><br> ""When Superman looks at himself in the mirror, this is what he sees on his chest.""<br>#525<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 起</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 起  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=526"">rouse おきる</br></br></a>  ""Be careful when you're RUNNING through the jungle, because you might step on and ROUSE a sleeping SNAKE. Then you'll have to RUN like hell before it bites you!""<br><br> Nothing will rouse you quite as much as finding a snake in your bed. You will run away like you've never run before!<br>#526<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 妃</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 妃  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=527"">queen きさき</br></br></a>  Medusa the Queen of Snakes. Remembering using her to farm Ancients in Dota 2.<br><br> ""Be careful you don't pick up a drag queen at a club - they might look like women, but they have a snake down there!""<br>#527<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 改</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 改  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=528"">reformation 改めて　改善　</br></br></a>  ""The taskmaster of Slytherin ( wizardry house symbolized by a snake ) plans a reformation of Hogwarts, disallowing the study of magic to all muggle-born. こわいですね！.""<br><br> ""This is a Meiji reformation taskmaster, trying to force usage of the Roman alphabet in Japan in place of Kanji. He holds a snake in the shape of the letter S and tries to explain how much simpler this is (j/k).""<br>#528<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 記</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 記  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=529"">scribe</br></br></a>  A scribe writes down the words spoken by a snake (i.e. a lawyer).<br><br> ""Snakes have no hands. So, when a snake needs to write down something, it has to call in a SCRIBE, who will write down all the sayings of the snake.""<br>#529<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 包</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 包  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=530"">wrap</br></br></a>  The snake bound up its prey by wrapping his body around it.<br><br> ""Imagine Jessie sending in her Ekans (snake pokemon), and telling it to use bind attack to wrap up pikachu.""<br>#530<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 胞</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 胞  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=531"">placenta</br></br></a>  ""Imagine a newborn baby, fresh out of the womb, being entirely wrapped by the long piece of flesh, called a placenta, that once fed him.""<br><br> Placenta is flesh/part of the body wrapped around the foetus.<br>#531<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 砲</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 砲  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=532"">cannon</br></br></a>  Primitive cannons fired stones wrapped with poisonous snakes.<br><br> Cannon = stone projectile wrapped by a barrel.<br>#532<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 泡</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 泡  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=533"">bubble</br></br></a>  ""When water forms a bubble, it wraps a pocket of air.""<br><br> ""To prevent people from popping bubble wrap for fun, the post office has started filling the bubbles with water.""<br>#533<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 亀</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 亀  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=534"">tortoise</br></br></a>  ""It seems bizarre, but tortoises are a genetic cross with the head of a fish and the tail of an eel. Where the shell comes from, no one knows.""<br><br> A tortoise is prosperity bound up with a tail. They are very lucky creatures.<br>#534<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 電</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 電  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=535"">electricity</br></br></a>  ""Think of a two natural sources of electricity: electrical storms (a form of weather) and electrical eels. 電話 でんわ phone, call.""<br><br> ""This kanji was invented by the first Chinaman to discover electricity. He was so unfortunate, he stepped on an electric eel and got struck by lighting at the same time.""<br>#535<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 竜</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 竜  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=536"">dragon</br></br></a>  ""Have you ever seen an asian DRAGON? it looks like an eel, but can stand up because it has legs.""<br><br> ""If the poor villagers don't provide him with a vase full of eels each day, the dragon will lay waste to the village.""<br>#536<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 滝</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 滝  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=537"">waterfall たき</br></br></a>  The Water Dragon dwells in the waterfall.<br><br> ""Ever went under a waterfall, vase in hand, trying to catch eels from the water as it pours down?""<br>#537<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 豚</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 豚  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=538"">pork&nbsp;ぶた</br></br></a>  Pork comes from the flesh of a sow.<br><br> ""One possible pictograph for """"sow"""" primitive: the top line is a feeding trough, the stroke touching it is the head, the long curved stroke is the body (with a little hook at the end for the curly tail), and the four remaining strokes are the sow's legs.""<br>#538<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 逐</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 逐  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=539"">pursue 遂げる</br></br></a>  ""In association with consummate (#540), our sow is on the road pursuing a mate.""<br><br> The pig is on the road in the pursue of the turtle who is trying to escape (#283). (See story on escape (#283) & consummate (#540)).<br>#539<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 遂</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 遂  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=540"">consummate とげる</br></br></a>  This is still Miss Piggy only she's gotten horny (as she often does) and now she's pursuing Kermit to help her consummate her desires.<br><br> ""In association with pursue (#539), our sow has tracked down a suitable mate, they've consummated their relationship, and now the little sow is all grown up into a boar with horns.""<br>#540<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 家</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 家  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=541"">house</br></br></a>  ""Think of """"The Three Little Pigs"""". There was a house made of straw, another made of sticks, and a third made of bricks, each occupied by a pig. So, naturally, housetop over pig means house, the central element of that story.""<br><br> ""Man, ever hear of cleaning? This house is a pig sty.""<br>#541<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 嫁</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 嫁  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=542"">marry into</br></br></a>  ""Since the Nihonjin man is hardly ever home, the <b>woman</b> feels more like she's married into the <b>house</b> than into a relationship.""<br><br> ""Traditionally, it was the women who would marry into the households of their husband's families.""<br>#542<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 豪</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 豪  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=543"">overpowering</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""Ganon, the tall crowned pig, has been overpowering ther land of Hyrule for decades.""<br>#543<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 腸</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 腸  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=544"">intestines</br></br></a>  Intestines are the part of the body that is taken out of piglets to make piggy banks. Just imagine factory workers scraping out the intestines of real piglets and packaging them up for little children.<br><br> ""Taking things too literally, you used a real piglet as a piggy bank. Now when you smash it open to get your coins out, you have to dig out your coins from its intestines. ew.""<br>#544<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 場</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 場  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=545"">location</br></br></a>  ""You're looking for a good location to bury your piggy bank savings. It has to be in some soft soil that's easy to dig up, well hidden, and easy to rememger like this kanji.""<br><br> ""Don't confuse with place (#1127). Think of location not as a single fixed spot, but as the act of locating. You've buried your piggy bank in the dirt in your backyard, but you can't remember where. You frantically dig everywhere in a process of location to find your piggy bank.""<br>#545<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 湯</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 湯  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=546"">hot water</br></br></a>  ""Imagine a hot water kettle for your tea, except this one is a pink piggy bank that pours the water from its snout (and squeals when the water is piping hot). Make sure to use a potholder!""<br><br> ""Hot water is a phrase that can mean """"getting into trouble."""" This kanji pictures just one of the many meanings of that phrase: it's water that you get into (with creditors and the like) when your piggy bank is empty!""<br>#546<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 羊</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 羊  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=547"">sheep</br></br></a>  ""Picture of a sheep run over by a steam roller. Must have been a ram, note the horns.""<br><br> Our Lord and King put on ears and a tail to become a lowly sheep for the slaughter.<br>#547<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 美</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 美  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=548"">beauty うつくしい</br></br></a>  I guess this kanji proves it's not just the Welsh whose idea of beauty is a large sheep.<br><br> A Sheep on top of a dog is NOT a beautiful thing.<br>#548<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 洋</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 洋  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=549"">ocean&nbsp;</br></br></a>  This kanji refers to the waters of the Pasheephic ocean.<br><br> Remember the story of Jason and the Argonauts from Greek myth? Jason travelled across oceans of water in order to recover the fleece of a certain sheep.<br>#549<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 詳</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 詳  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=550"">detailed</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""Say! detailed sheep, not like that! DE-TAILED sheep. Got it?""<br>#550<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 鮮</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 鮮  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=551"">fresh</br></br></a>  ""The freshest fish is caught in the middle of the night while most people are """"counting sheep."""" (If you've ever been to Tsukiji fish market, you know what I mean).""<br><br> ""This one's easy to remember. The kanji gives 2 examples of foods that should be purchased fresh. To remember which foods, take the first letter of fresh, """"F"""", to stand for fish and the final sound of fresh, """"SH"""", to stand for sheep: FreSH. It even puts the primitives in the right order.""<br>#551<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 達</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 達  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=552"">accomplished 私たち</br></br></a>  The dirty sheep had come far down this road and had accomplished many things.<br><br> <br>#552<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 羨</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 羨  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=553"">envious うらやましい</br></br></a>  ""A very thirsty sheep, who always lacked water, spends his days watching his fellow sheep (in the farm <b>next </b>door or in another pen) and being very envious of their water.""<br><br> ""Envious of the greener grass on the other side of the fence, the sheep looks down in disgust at his own dry grass lacking water.""<br>#553<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 差</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 差  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=554"">distinction</br></br></a>  This New-Zealand pro-gamer has won many distinctions playing WoolCraft (a massively multi-user game in which the goal is to shear sheep).<br><br> ""Noob players make no distinction between what games they play, whether it's the geniune thing or a bootleg fake copy. The biggest example of course, would be the legit World of Warcraft and the biggest ripoff there is: World of Wool-craft!""<br>#554<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 着</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 着  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=555"">don きる (to wear)</br></br></a>  A pullover is donned by pulling wool over your eyes.<br><br> Someone who is donning a disguise does that in order to pull the wool over your eyes.<br>#555<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 唯</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 唯  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=556"">solely ゆいつ</br></br></a>  ""The mouth of a turkey is used solely for saying, """"Gobble."""" Likewise, your mouth, full of turkey, is solely used to gobble it up.""<br><br> Sadly my mouth gets to taste turkey solely on Christmas Day.<br>#556<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 焦</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 焦  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=557"">char</br></br></a>  ""When I put the turkey over the oven fire, it always ends up being charred beyond recognition. I'm not a very good cook.""<br><br> Char could be any meat over oven fire. So why is it a turkey in this kanji? Because charred turkey is what sticks out most in your mind as the thing that ruined Thanksgiving dinner.<br>#557<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 礁</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 礁  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=558"">reef</br></br></a>  ""Coral reefs are now dying off due to our abuse of the environment and now look like charred stone. For a picture illustrating this, see http://www.nacri.org/images/Hof-dredgingfig8.jpg.""<br><br> ""Reefs are often formed from volcanic rock, or """"rock that has been charred"""".""<br>#558<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 集</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 集  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=559"">gather</br></br></a>  ""Hunter-gathers, searching all along the ground for food. They never look up and see the Turkeys that have gathered on top of the trees to hide. Those were some smart turkeys!""<br><br> Gather the turkeys for Thanksgiving. Gather the trees for Christmas. In that order...<br>#559<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 准</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 准  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=560"">quasi- じゅんずる</br></br></a>  ""Quasi-modo, the famous hunchback of Notre-Dame wasn't actually a hunchback at all!! He used a frozen turkey to make a hunch!""<br><br> An iced turkey is only quasi-as-good-as fresh turkey.<br>#560<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 進</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 進  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=561"">advance</br></br></a>  ""Why did the turkey cross the road? To advance to the other side, of course.""<br><br> ""[re: raulir] Animals on the road: Turtles escape (#283) and Pigs pursue (#539), while the Turkeys advance (looking very formidable indeed).""<br>#561<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 雑</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 雑  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=562"">miscellaneous ざつ</br></br></a>  ""Newscast: """"Among today's miscellaneous stories, we have a report on a baseball team that was chased up a tree by a turkey. Stay tuned for this and more!"""".""<br><br> ""On the left we have baseball and wood, which obviously means a baseball bat. Instead of balls, there are miscellaneous other objects you may hit with it. While beating people may be one favorite use, in this case we see it used for making turkey mash.""<br>#562<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 雌</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 雌  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=563"">feminine</br></br></a>  Stop | spooning | turkeys. Spoon females.<br><br> To become feminine you must stop using a spoon to eat turkey and use a knife and fork like a proper lady.<br>#563<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 準</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 準  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=564"">semi-</br></br></a>  ""At the turkey fighting semi-final, turkeys are injected with drugs via needles and splashed with water to help them last the match.""<br><br> ""The anhinga, or water turkey, has a needle-like nose, so really it's only a semi-turkey http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anhinga.""<br>#564<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 奮</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 奮  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=565"">stirred up</br></br></a>  The St. Bernard dog pounces on a turkey in a rice field and stirs up all the other birds around. See them all gobble gobbling in fear?<br><br> ""Gruesome, but it makes it easy to remember. Here goes: The St. Bernard stirred up a crowd of turkeys and caught one. It bit the head, brains spilling onto the rice field.""<br>#565<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 奪</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 奪  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=566"">rob</br></br></a>  <br><br> Don't let the neighbor's St.Bernard rob tonight's turkey....glue it to the table if you must.<br>#566<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 確</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 確  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=567"">assurance たしか</br></br></a>  ""To assure that no one will get into the Turkey coop, put a huge rock in the entrance!""<br><br> ""You've heard the expression """"killing two birds with one stone."""" (一石二鳥 is-seki-ni-chou). We'll, there's another one that roughly translates as """"killing an entire coop with a giant boulder. """" That's the method that hunters use when they want absolute assurance of taking home a bird.""<br>#567<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 午</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 午  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=568"">noon ご後</br></br></a>  Noon is a good time for a ten minute nap (using lie down as nap).<br><br> Noon is the hour of the horse.<br>#568<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 許</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 許  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=569"">permit</br></br></a>  ""If horses could speak, you might have to ask their permission before mounting them.""<br><br> Mr Ed ( a famous talking horse ) was finally at a loss for words when told he would need a permit for public speaking.<br>#569<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 歓</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 歓  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=570"">delight よろこぶ</br></br></a>  Imagine a spoiled little girl. Her delight when she gets a Pegasus for her birthday... and then like all spoilt little girls she gets bored of it quickly... hence the yawn.<br><br> I would be delighted if Japanese lacked the Pegasus kanji.<br>#570<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 権</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 権  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=571"">authority 権利</br></br></a>  ""I have Eric Cartman of the “South Park” animated series, wearing a cop uniform, riding a <b>wooden Pegasus</b> (such as on a funfair), and yelling “RESPECT MY AUTHORITAH!!!”.""<br><br> No one has the authority to tie up a pegasus to a tree!<br>#571<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 観</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 観  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=572"">outlook みる</br></br></a>  Microsoft Outlook works about as well as a pegasus that can't see: they both crash all the time.<br><br> ""I used to hate birds.They're loud, stupid and worst of all they shit on your head. Used to think birds were the most vile creatures on earth. Then I encountered a pegasus. I was just walking down the road, minding my own business when I happened to look up. I saw it there, braying noisily, ivory wings outstretched like an angel, back leg raised ever so slightly. It dropped a steaming brown load right on my face. It changed my outlook completely. Birds are the second most vile creatures on earth.""<br>#572<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 羽</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 羽  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=573"">feathers</br></br></a>  Pictograph. Easy enough.<br><br> These days the biggest concern in airline safety is ICE on the WINGS of the plane. Birds that fly long distances also have to worry about getting ICE on their FEATHERS.<br>#573<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 習</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 習  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=574"">learn</br></br></a>  ""Imagine a white bird loosing a couple feathers as it is learning to fly. You learn a lesson as you watch it doing so, maybe you learn that “nothing comes for free” or that “one has to be prepared to loose in order to gain”...""<br><br> Learning is all about adding more feathers to your cap and the most prestigious of all is the beautiful pure white feather you'll receive when you have learned the kanji!<br>#574<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 翌</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 翌  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=575"">the following 翌日</br></br></a>  ""Your <b>feathers</b> would also <b>stand up</b> if you were a hen in a slaughter house and you heard: """"The following!"""".""<br><br> """"""The following segment is sponsored by...Swiffer - who make excellent feather dusters for cleaning your vases"""".""<br>#575<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 曜</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 曜  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=576"">weekday</br></br></a>  ""Tip: feathers + turkey : This combination of primitives appears six times in Heisig, so it's worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest """"futon"""" (your futon is made from turkey feathers). REF: weekday (FRAME 576) , laundry (#577), leap (#1285), outstanding (#2272), twinkle (#2534), shimmering (#2880). Story: On weekdays you hang your futon out in the sun.""<br><br> ""The poor farmer spends every weekday while the sun shines, plucking turkey feathers.""<br>#576<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 濯</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 濯  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=577"">laundry 洗濯</br></br></a>  ""At the laundry you stuff your <b>large futon (made from turkey feathers)</b> in the machine, thereby causing it to break -- as shown by the <b>water</b> spurting out the side.""<br><br> ""When turkeys do the laundry, they put their feathers in water (they don't have clothes).""<br>#577<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 曰</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 曰  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=578"">sayeth</br></br></a>  """"""Sayeth""""?! Who the hell says """"sayeth""""? Doesn't seem quite right...just like this kanji, which is just like """"day"""" but doesn't seem """"quite right."""".""<br><br> ""When pent up alone, one sayeth little.""<br>#578<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 困</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 困  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=579"">quandary</br></br></a>  ""I'm supposed to make an enclosure for my tree, but if I use its wood for the enclosure, there won't be anything left to be pent-in. What a quandary!""<br><br> ""You are pent in the garden of eden with one tree, but outside is the whole world to explore! What a quandary -- should you stay in paradise with the tree of knowledge or should you go out into the world?""<br>#579<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 固</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 固  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=580"">harden かたい</br></br></a>  Fossils are old things pent in that have hardened.<br><br> ""Remember Metapod from Pokemon? All it used was harden, which kept it pent in until it grew old enough to evolve into Butterfree..""<br>#580<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 国</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 国  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=581"">country</br></br></a>  In my country (England) the crown jewels are kept pent-in in the Tower of London. Which happens to be where enemies of the state were once also pent-in (probably for trying to steal those jewels).<br><br> ""Just think of Japan, a country which is like a jewel but historically very enclosed.""<br>#581<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 団</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 団  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=582"">group</br></br></a>  ""When you are admitted into a group like the Yakuza, you're well and truly done (だん) for. You must stick to the group like glue, and you will be pent-in for life, never being able to leave.""<br><br> ""A pent-in group will naturally be more cohesive, or """"glued together."""".""<br>#582<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 因</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 因  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=583"">cause</br></br></a>  We once had a dog with big paws // and oh what great trouble he'd cause // we built a huge pen // to keep him pent in // and stop him from breaking more laws //.<br><br> ""Why is there poop on the kitchen floor? Oh, the cause is that you kept the dog pent in the house all day. Next time remember to walk him.""<br>#583<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 姻</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 姻  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=584"">matrimony</br></br></a>  Matrimony is the state in which the woman has got you pent in like a dog so that you cannot go after other bitches.<br><br> ""When the woman gets angry, she treats her man like a pent in dog (i.e., puts him in the doghouse). It's a perfect metaphor for the state of matrimony.""<br>#584<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 園</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 園  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=585"">park 公えん</br></br></a>  ""A nice picnic pent up in the park, with your crock pot and scarf (picnic blanket).""<br><br> There was a homeless man living in a box at the park so I gave him a lidded crock filled with hot curry tied with a scarf...　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　エン　庭園　ていえん(Japanese garden)…　　　　　　　　　　Pure Group:　遠402　猿403.<br>#585<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 回</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 回  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=586"">-times</br></br></a>  Write mouth two -times.<br><br> ""Pretty much a pictograph, see book. Keyword meanings : to turn round, counter for number of times, counter for rounds. Some simple compounds using previously learned kanji : 次回 (next time), 毎回 (every time/each round), 回る (to wander around).""<br>#586<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 壇</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 壇  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=587"">podium</br></br></a>  A man on the podium announce the rules for the contest: You must fill a top hat with dirt as many times as you can by nightbreak.<br><br> ""Abraham Lincoln used a simple mound of soil for a podium, when he wore his top hat and gave the speech he had practiced many times until nightbreak. But it was so magnificent that no one noticed.""<br>#587<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 店</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 店  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=588"">store みせ</br></br></a>  Try to remember all those stores from Zelda that were inside caves and had fortune-teller like vendors.<br><br> The fortuneteller has a store in a cave.<br>#588<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 庫</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 庫  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=589"">warehouse</br></br></a>  ""I think of the Batcave. It's a big cave that Batman uses as a warehouse to store his car, the Batmobile, and all his cool big-boy toys.""<br><br> Have you ever worked in a warehouse? It's like a giant metal cave. Watch out for that forklift!<br>#589<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 庭</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 庭  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=590"">courtyard</br></br></a>  ""When the courthouse caved in, trials had to be held in the courtyard.""<br><br> ""Back in caveman days, courts were held in caves. When too many people showed up to watch, they spilled out into the courtyard (the yard outside the cave court ) . 庭 (にわ): garden, yard, compound 庭園 (ていえん): garden, park 校庭 (こうてい): schoolyard.""<br>#590<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 庁</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 庁  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=591"">government office</br></br></a>  ""Some bureaucrats at a government office decided that the tunnels of caves need to get street signs, which are then nailed to the walls of the cave.""<br><br> ""In some of the scarier countries, when someone is invited to visit a """"government office"""", it's actually a dungeon where they're dragged into a cave and nailed to the wall.""<br>#591<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 床</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 床  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=592"">bed ゆか</br></br></a>  The two safe places to sleep in the wilderness are in a tree and in a cave. So these can be considered as beds.<br><br> (based on mspertus:) The two safe places to sleep in the wilderness are in a tree and in a cave. So to be on the safe side it is best to put a tree in a cave and use it as a bed.<br>#592<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 麻</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 麻  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=593"">hemp</br></br></a>  ""(Image: while Batman is out, Robin is smokin' a huge doob in a secret corner of the Batcave where he nurtures his hemp grove).""<br><br> ""Where is the best place to hid your grove of hemp trees? In a cave, you dope!""<br>#593<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 心</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 心  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=595"">heart こころ</br></br></a>  ""The four chambers in the heart. In the West, we point to our head when asked about the mind. In the East, they point to the heart. So then, the radical for """"state of mind""""…　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　シン　安心　あんしん(peace of mind).""<br><br> Heart needs three drops of blood to work.<br>#595<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 忘</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 忘  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=596"">forget わする</br></br></a>  You only truly forget her when she has perished in your heart.<br><br> To forget means that something perishes from your heart.<br>#596<br></span>"

By the way, this character is used in the compound 忍者 (ninja) which is why I choose to use ninja as its primitive meaning.""<br><br> Someone with a razor blade stuck in their heart has to endure the pain wherever they go and can tell no one about it.<br>#597<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 認</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 認  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=598"">acknowledge</br></br></a>  ""You are given a speech about some serious mistakes of yours, and you have to endure the whole thing, because all you can do is acknowledge.""<br><br> ""I never read the """"acknowledgements"""" section of books or theses, because they are mostly just boring words that i must endure reading, before i can get to the interesting part. :).""<br>#598<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 串</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 串  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=603"">shish kebab</br></br></a>  ""Naka naka , """"who's there?"""" shish kebab .... """"shish kebab who?"""".""<br><br> This is a pictograph if ever I saw one. Two chunks of meat on a skewer.<br>#603<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 患</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 患  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=604"">afflicted&nbsp;患者(かん‐じゃ)</br></br></a>  A person who is afflicted with the vampire disease can only be killed with a sheesh-kebab through the heart.<br><br> ""If you are afflicted with severe heartburn, eating a spicy shish kebab will feel only slightly less painful than having it jammed straight into your heart.""<br>#604<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 思</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 思  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=605"">think おもう</br></br></a>  Think with your brain NOT your heart.<br><br> To think is to use your brain over your heart.<br>#605<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 恩</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 恩  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=606"">grace</br></br></a>  ""Grace here is a favor freely bestowed, like a good deed. So to remember this kanji, go to the local shelter, find a big dog pent up in a small cage and adopt him. That will cause a warm feeling in your heart!""<br><br> ""This kanji tells us that wherever heart is the cause, grace is the consequence. Think of “grace” as a graceful act: something benevolent that comes from the heart.""<br>#606<br></span>"

Imagine the greater the idea, the louder the sound of the beating heart.""<br>#608<br></span>"

Tongues and noses are nothing special. The new cool is to have your heart done!<br><br> ""Ah recess; tongues slandering, noses being turned up, and beneath it all, young hearts being broken. Dominant in playgrounds is the noise of tongues, which helps me remember that in this kanji tongue comes first.""<br>#611<br></span>"
