Watch as the cyclist shoves the person into a gully that runs alongside the road.<br>#795<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 賞</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 賞  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=796"">prize</br></br></a>  ""This is a bit silly.. or maybe not only a bit, but.. You know some foodstuffs (cereals come to mind) sometimes have prizes mixed in them? Well, in this case, the prize was a shell (money, remember) and you only notice in the outhouse... (see also secret (#904)).""<br><br> ""As a prize for being the 1,000,000th person to use the restaurant's outhouse, I got all the clams I could eat.""<br>#796<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 党</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 党  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=797"">party</br></br></a>  ""Every major political party, if personified, would look like a giant outhouse walking around with human legs spewing out a constant stream of bullshit.""<br><br> ""Every political party is full of shit. But nobody ever says how they get that way. Well, here's your answer - a political party memer is in the outhouse, greedily chowing down on the contents inside. He's grown so accustomed to the taste that he's in all the way, and all you can see are his legs through the window. He'll come inside later to the auditorium to make a speech and spew everything out.""<br>#797<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 堂</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 堂  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=798"">public chamber</br></br></a>  In most communities you will be hauled into city hall if you use the ground as an outhouse.<br><br> There is a secret hall buried in the soil underneath the outhouse.<br>#798<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 常</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 常  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=799"">usual つね</br></br></a>  It's usual to take your towel with you when you go to the outhouse at the onsen (hot springs bath in Japan) so everybody doesn't see your stuff.<br><br> ""In the outhouse toilet you'd usually hope to find toilet paper to wipe your ass. If it's already gone, which is usually the case, simply use the towel.""<br>#799<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 裳</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 裳  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=800"">skirt も</br></br></a>  ""Compared to pants, a SKIRT is the GARMENT to be wearing when you want to use one of those Japanese toilets. It makes it so much easier: you just walk in the OUTHOUSE hike it up, and do your business.""<br><br> ""Haven't you ever noticed that the men / women signs on the front of outhouses are sometimes very similar? The silhouettes are usually the same, but one will decidedly be wearing a garment in the shape of a SKIRT. Also, we've already learned the kanji for """"woman"""", so if the signs are only in kanji you have no right to wander in and claim ignorance, perv!""<br>#800<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 掌</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 掌  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=801"">manipulate てのひら</br></br></a>  ""If you're going to manipulate your body with your hand, then go do it in an outhouse, at least!""<br><br> ""Instead of magazines, we keep a Rubiks Cube in the outhouse to manipulate with your hands while you do your business.""<br>#801<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 皮</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 皮  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=802"">pelt</br></br></a>  A pelt is hooked on a branch. A small tent is made with a pelt and a branch planted in the ground. The mnemonic hints at the first stroke (the hanging pelt) and the hook at the end of the second stroke. This is chinese radical #107 meaning “skin”.<br><br> ""To be honest, this is one of those cases where I have found it easier to """"just remember it"""" as a radical, as it occurs so frequently: 彼（かれ him）波（なみ wave）and so on.""<br>#802<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 波</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 波  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=803"">waves</br></br></a>  Waves are the ocean's pelt (skin).<br><br> ""The Inuit used water-proof seal pelts for their kayaks, to travel the waves.""<br>#803<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 婆</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 婆  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=804"">old woman</br></br></a>  ""An old woman is seen here as a woman with waves (i.e. wrinkles, creases).""<br><br> ""You know """"The Old Man and the Sea."""" Well, this is the sequel, """"The Old Woman and the Sea Waves."""".""<br>#804<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 披</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 披  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=805"">expose ひ歴</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""Think of it in this vulgar way. You really want her to expose her “beaver” pelt, so you have to encourage her with your fingers to expose it.""<br>#805<br></span>"

(Image: cavemen rending pelts right off live animals with stone tools).""<br>#806<br></span>"

Want to get boned straightaway? AUGMENT your breasts and all your troubles will be solved!<br><br> ""In the movie “Gattaca”, Vincent Freeman (played by Ethan Hawke) augments his size by straightening his bones (his legs), in order to match up with the genetically “perfect” population, and reach his goal of travelling in space. In Japanese society, when someone dies they creamate the body and pick out the remaining bones with special chopsticks. In this case, they're out of chopsticks so they decide to use (gasp!) a spoon instead.""<br><br> ""Imagine the grim reaper (the bringer of death), carrying a spoon made of human bones instead of a scythe.""<br>#815<br></span>"

At this funeral it's an open casket, and the dead body (death) is holding flowers with both of its hands.""<br><br> ""During the interment ceremony, the grandchildren placed flowers over the dead body while the widow sat praying with two hands.""<br>#816<br></span>"

Instead of a cigarette or a pen he pulls the person’s crotch out of their ear. Very painful!<br>#819<br></span>"

Just add Viagra.<br><br> I'm not sure I know about erector sets or tinker toys but I do know about jenga. You play by taking wooden pieces from the middle of a wooden tower and adding them to the top. In this way you erect a very unstable structure.<br>#869<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 脇</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 脇  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=870"">armpit わき</br></br></a>  ""What part of the body has a very, very, very powerful smell? The armpit, of course!""<br><br> ""(no important on yomi) The part of Conan's body that is three times more effective at defeating foes than his muscles are his stinky ARMPITs. [Note: Typically, when the flesh primitive is on the left side it refers to a body part - this helps distinguish in from threaten (#871)].""<br>#870<br></span>"

He's three times as powerful ON a full moon.　RTK2:　キョウ　脅迫　きょうはく (blackmail)…　Pure Group:　協872.<br>#871<br></span>"

Being that I live near the ocean, I see tourists and vacationers coming and going constantly on the bridge. Because the bridge is so long, it forms an arc to support the structural integrity. You can see that arc here.""<br>#873<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 律</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 律  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=874"">rhythm</br></br></a>  ""The calligrapher's brush is moving down a column of a script, in rhythm with his meditation.""<br><br> The army COLUMN walked to the RHYTHM made by the drummer using a cool BRUSH like drum stick. Picturing the brush as a drum stick is not difficult if you've seen such a thing in jazz videos.<br>#874<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 径</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 径  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=882"">diameter</br></br></a>  Scientists recently measured the diameter of Earth by drilling a deep hole and dropping a line of thread off a humongous spool until it got to the other side.<br><br> ""Suggestion: Replace """"spool"""" with """"toilet paper/roll"""". Reasons: (1) Toilet paper/roll usually comes on a spool. (2) Toilet paper is used to clean the soil off your crotch. Story: Measure the diameter of a column (maybe Nelson's Column in London?) using a roll of toilet paper. Spool also appears in stalk (#715), suspicious (#716), lightly (#717), sutra (#1360).""<br>#882<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 彼</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 彼  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=883"">he</br></br></a>  What's the main difference between a he and a she? The he has a column covered in a pelt... a penis. Badum-ching.<br><br> ""The ultimate he-man is the Neanderthal cave man. His club is as big as a pillar (column), and he wears a ragged pelt as his only clothing. To remember the column, imagine the cave man resting the club vertically like a column when not in use.""<br>#883<br></span>"

The government is using mental wave emitting statues shaped like St. Bernard's dogs put alongside the boulevards.""<br><br> ""I think BALANCE is an easier keyword. I was walking down a busy French boulevard when between the rushing traffic I saw the wierdest thing. BALANCING on the central crash barrier was a St. Bernard dog, BALANCING a fish on its nose. As I looked closer, I realised it was a trick; it was holding the fish's tail in its teeth, and only pretending to BALANCE it. (keeps the position of the elements!).""<br>#891<br></span>"

Notice how they SHIFT like waves in the slightest breeze. When you hear SHIFT, just picture that scene.""<br><br> Many people are making the shift from white to whole wheat bread.<br>#898<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 愁</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 愁  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=901"">distress うれえる</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""Here we have distressed (think """"gloomy"""") people with """"seasonal mood disorder"""" during the autumn season, when their hearts are feeling down."" <br>#901<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 私</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 私  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=902"">private</br></br></a>  ""Warning sign: """"Private wheat, trespassers will be elbowed"""".""<br><br> ""I already know this as watashi, or """"I"""". In order to associate the keyword of private, I'll think of this one as """"Private I"""", like a detective.""<br>#902<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 秘</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 秘  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=904"">secret</br></br></a>  <br><br> A young couple meets in secret in the wheat field because their families are enemies. They cross their hearts and swear eternal - even if secret - love. Do not confuse with secrecy (#775).<br>#904<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 称</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 称  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=905"">appellation</br></br></a>  ""Taking appellation to mean the act of naming, we have the little baby superman reclining in the space craft that landed in a wheat field. Mr. and Mrs. Kent look down and decide to call him Clark.""<br><br> ""WHEAT that is RECLINING and LITTLE (small) can't get the APPELLATION """"quality wheat"""".""<br>#905<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 利</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 利  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=906"">profit</br></br></a>  ""In the middle ages there where only 2 ways for peasantry to make a profit. one by being a farmer, 2 to be a mercenary and live by the way of the sword.""<br><br> 1. Steal a bunch of wheat from a wheat field by cutting it down with your saber. 2. ????? 3. Profit!<br>#906<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 梨</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 梨  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=907"">pear tree</br></br></a>  ""The Japanese pear tree is the most profitable in the world, because it produces its fruit in pairs [sorry for the awful pun].""<br><br> <br>#907<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 穫</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 穫  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=908"">harvest</br></br></a>  The harvest of genetically modified crops is taken onboard the Greenpeace vessel (see the flower vessel in safeguard (#700)).<br><br> Wheat is harvested; the grain (flower) is put into vessels for shipping.<br>#908<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 穂</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 穂  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=909"">ear of a plant</br></br></a>  ""The travellars only had <b>wheat</b>, so they asked the Indians to do them a<b> favor </b>and trade them for some ears of corn.""<br><br> ""The """"ear of a plant"""" is the seed-bearing spike of a cereal plant, such as corn. In other words, it is the part which feeds us. Hence -- """"the ear (of a plant) is the favor of the wheat"""".""<br>#909<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 稲</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 稲  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=910"">rice plant</br></br></a>  The rice plant is common in Japan because all the wheat was eaten by vultures in the olden times.<br><br> ""It used to be that wheat was grown in Japan. However, this was often stolen by vultures, so in olden times, the gods gave the Japanese the rice plant.""<br>#910<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 香</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 香  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=911"">incense こう水</br></br></a>  <br><br> When the sun burns the wheat a smell of incense remains in the air.<br>#911<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 季</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 季  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=912"">seasons きせつ</br></br></a>  There's a season for planting wheat and there's mating season for having children.<br><br> ""Look at this adorable child with a bale of wheat on his head! He's playing Autumn in his school play the """"Four Seasons"""". Aww...too cute! Perhaps we should light the wheat on fire to complete his Autumn costume. (I know, twisted...but I kept forgetting what was on his head).""<br>#912<br></span>"

Wheat/Fist.""<br>#914<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 透</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 透  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=915"">transparent 透明</br></br></a>  ""If you excel in the Mario Kart road, your movements are saved and you can race against yourself as a transparent racer. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xe8CkcrL-k4.""<br><br> ""If you want to excel at driving in the roadway, it's better if your windows and windshield are transparent. "<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 穀</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 穀  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=917"">cereals</br></br></a>  There are different cereals in different parts of the world. Japan has samurai cereal. Great Britain has Crowned Wheat ... the United States and Russia have Missile cereals.<br><br> ""The samurai crowns wheat as the best cereal, and blows all others up with missiles (he's a cereal killer).""<br>#917<br></span>"

So for example, you have to keep wheat enclosed so it isn't exposed to other plants. That way it can't catch any germs (like fungi) from them.""<br>#918<br></span>"

The rest then is the “tree” meaning “plant” in this contexct. also: USA.<br><br> ""Two drops of rice in a tree, simple.""<br>#919<br></span>"

(Image: geishas patting their face with RICE flour to make it white. Not wheat flour...).<br><br> ""In the United States, part of every meal is made from flour.""<br>#920<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 奥</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 奥  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=928"">core</br></br></a>  ""In the core of a nuclear reactor, scientists have discovered a way to get power from rice, by penting it in under high pressure. It's very dangerous, so they've trained a st. bernard dog to run things, he's adding more drops of rice as necessary.""<br><br> ""奥さん　（おくさん) is a common way to say """"wife"""". In the innermost core of the house, the bored pent up housewife drops her chores and consumes so much rice she becomes a very large housewife.""<br>#928<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 数</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 数  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=929"">number</br></br></a>  ""Young taskmaster is learning numbers by watching women haul sacks of rice past him. """"One... two... four! No, wrong! Go back, go back!"""".""<br><br> Women toil in the rice fields carrying heavy sacks of rice to be numbered and counted by the taskmaster.<br>#929<br></span>"

""I can seeeee you! One! Two! Three!""<br><br> <br>#930<br></span>"

But it's completely dry since the umbrella is lacquered.<br>#932<br></span>"

If you met a person that created a wooden sheep that was squeezing a single grain of rice out of its ass, you'd definitely call that person -sama. Because that is impressive.""<br>#933<br></span>"

I'm using panda as the primitive name when it fits the story. ^__^.<br><br> ""Two reclining victims impaled on bamboo spheres...　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　チク　松竹梅　しょうちくばい(pine, bamboo, plum).""<br>#937<br></span>"

Just look at him laugh!<br>#938<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 笠</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 笠  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=939"">bamboo hat</br></br></a>  ""The bamboo vase was beautifully crafted, but the tourist didn't know what it was and wore it as a little bamboo hat.""<br><br> ""The bamboo part is easy. Just remember that this kanji refers to those particular bamboo hats that are worn primarily by Buddhist monks, who always seem to stand outside of train stations, collecting alms.""<br>#939<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 筋</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 筋  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=941"">muscle きん力</br></br></a>  <br><br> Lifting BAMBOO STICKS is an old way for your FLESH to gain POWER and ultimately MUSCLE.<br>#941<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 箱</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 箱  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=942"">box はこ</br></br></a>  The best kind of BOX is made from BAMBOO sticks that are INTER-laced to make it air tight. Just picture such a box and you've mastered this kanji.<br><br> I think of a box made of inter-locking of bamboo strips.<br>#942<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 筆</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 筆  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=943"">writing brush</br></br></a>  Bamboo is the best material from which to make a brush if you want it to be a writing brush.<br><br> Bamboo would make an excellent writing brush as the ink could flow through the hollow center like an ink pen... 　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　ヒツ　鉛筆　えんぴつ(lead pencil).<br>#943<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 筒</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 筒  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=944"">cylinder</br></br></a>  ""Seriously, all BAMBOO sticks look the SAME, just long CYLINDERS.""<br><br> ""Fully-grown bamboo consists of a number of cylinder-like sections, all exactly the same.""<br>#944<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 等</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 等  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=945"">etc. など</br></br></a>  ""The Bamboo Buddhist Temple has bamboo buddhas, bamboo buildings, bamboo benches, bamboo beds, bamboo bowls, etc. etc. etc.""<br><br> """"""So what'd you see in Japan?"""" - """"Bamboo, temples...etc."""".""<br>#945<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 算</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 算  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=946"">calculate</br></br></a>  ""Before the time of digital calculators, people used old school calculators made of bamboo (abacus). It's not as easy as a calculator, but you don't need any batteries either. All you need are your eyes and your two hands.""<br><br> ""Tip : you may see this as an Abacus, which is used to calculate. This particular ancient chinese Abacus has eyeballs in place of beads, and its frame is made of bamboo. You'd be amazed at how fast people can calculate with this, especially if they can use both hands at once to move the ... eyeballs.""<br>#946<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 答</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 答  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=947"">solution こたえ</br></br></a>  ""The solution to this puzzle is, like the match stick game, to make the <b>bamboo </b>pieces<b> fit</b> together.""<br><br> For the frustrated housewife the solution came in form of a BAMBOO stick that FITS her well.<br>#947<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 策</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 策  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=948"">scheme</br></br></a>  ""The temples in kyoto belt bamboo around trees in a scheme to protect them from the huge number of tourists. (true story)-----------対策　　たいさく　　measure, countermeasure.""<br><br> (Elaboration of jameserb's story:) A clever scheme from Wile E Coyote -- he ties one of those rubber belts to some trees and uses it to launch a bamboo spear at the roadrunner...<br>#948<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 簿</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 簿  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=949"">register</br></br></a>  ""Note : the keyword is not a verb, think of a record book. This acupuncturist who uses bamboo in place of flowers to dilute water into his patients (see frame 227), managed somehow to appear on the register of acupuncturists. Chances are, he won't stay on the register for long. My image is close to that of gorgon's story.""<br><br> This doctor dilutes (see 227) his patients with bamboo stalks rather than the flowers of a standard diluting acupuncturist hence he needs to be on the Bamboo Accumpunturist Diltuers (BAD) register. Pumping that much water into a body can be dangerous; see the huge bamboo stems with gallons of water sloshing in and out of the patient.<br>#949<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 築</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 築  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=950"">fabricate</br></br></a>  <br><br> A bamboo fabrication is a mediocre substitute for wood.<br>#950<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 人</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 人  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=951"">person</br></br></a>  ""Behold Mister T (of """"A-Team"""" fame)! I chose Mr.T because he's sure to make amusing stories. He is a very versatile character since he's both the big, tough guy and the “moralistic” person, telling kids not “to do drugs or alcohol”. He is easy to imagine, the heavy gold chains are probably the most prominent feature of the character. And last but not least you can always pepper your story with the famous line “I pity da foo!” * Fittingly, on the left side of the kanji, it looks like a “T”.""<br><br> ""[I appreciate some people's occasional habit of using P for person in shared stories. That makes it easier to substitute Mr. T, Captain Picard, or whomever else a student is using as person.].""<br>#951<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 佐</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 佐  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=952"">assistant</br></br></a>  ""Mr T's assistant is on his left. Why? Because Mr T has this bad habit of suddenly extending his right arm (what with all the boxing that he did), and his assistant got inadvertently punched in the face more than once (ouch). So now his assistant is always to his left side, much safer - """"Stay on my left, foo!"""".""<br><br> ""On your right is your """"right-hand man"""" that you credit for all your success....on the left...... is your assistant who does all the grunt work and gets no credit for anything...""<br>#952<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 但</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 但  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=953"">however ただし</br></br></a>  ""However drunk Mr T is when he comes back to his place, he always get up at nightbreak. “I pity da foo who gets up after nightbreak !”, says Mr. T.""<br><br> ""MR.T leads a busy life, however he always makes sure to be in bed by NIGHTBREAK, however much he might want to stay up watching A-Team re-runs.""<br>#953<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 住</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 住  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=954"">dwell すむ</br></br></a>  When Mr T shows people round his dwelling he takes a big candlestick (with a candle in it!) so that the light shows off his collection of bling bling jewellery.<br><br> ""Mister T dwells in a big brass candlestick, the flame of which serves as a beacon for the boats in the nearby harbour. Sometimes in the morning, Mister T has to clear the wax that has landed and solidified in front of the door.""<br>#954<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 位</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 位  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=955"">rank くらい</br></br></a>  Mr T ranks first position in the stand-up competition (doing knee flexions). Just picture him doing hundreds of these while the rest of the participants are already completely exhausted after a mere hundred.<br><br> Rank A person's standing.<br>#955<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 仲</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 仲  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=956"">go-between なか間</br></br></a>  ""When negotiating a hostage situation, Mr. T acted as the go-between, or person in the middle, for law enforcement and the terrorist.""<br><br> Go-between The person in the middle.<br>#956<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 体</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 体  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=957"">body からだ</br></br></a>  ""Mister T works out his body (body-building), using two piles of books (i.e. an exercise that can be done at home with two chairs, similar to push-ups but working mostly the shoulders, trapezius and triceps).""<br><br> Mr. T works out his body then rips a book apart to test is body. His favorite to destroy is Dianetics.<br>#957<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 件</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 件  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=959"">affair 事けん</br></br></a>  ""Note: this kanji refers to event or case. """"It's only animal 'man' enough for me"""".""<br><br> ""I'm having a hard time keep straight just which animal Mr. T is having an affair with. chamcham's story made me realize that Mr. T is not having an """"affair"""", he's having an """"heifair."""" Get it?""<br>#959<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 仕</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 仕  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=960"">attend</br></br></a>  ""Back in the day, a person who stands beside a samurai is usually attending to them or working for them.""<br><br> ""[+fuaburisu] Mr T attends to Tom Cruise in the Last Samurai, who is doing hara-kiri. """"I pity da foo' who's so indecisive that he can't make nothin' permanent"""".""<br>#966<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 伯</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 伯  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=967"">chief</br></br></a>  ""If Mr T was white I am sure he would have been commander in chief of the USA, he just the sort of clown Americans love to vote for. (NB: I tried with the indian chief motif but kept adding feathers by mistake).""<br><br> ""Mr T was originally supposed to be the chief of the A-Team, but then the producers realized that America didn't want to see a Black guy as the chief of a prime-time TV show. So here, we see Mr T doing a bunch of cocaine, and then spreading it all over his face to look white, and trying out for the part of Hannibal. The directors were so impressed that they let him stunt double for Hannibal in a few episodes. OR, Mr T chiefin' on some crack cocaine. You make the call.""<br>#967<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 俗</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 俗  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=968"">vulgar</br></br></a>  ""Mr. T says, """"Don't be like them valley girls, always speaking vulgar language and acting all vulgar! They ain't nothing but foos!"""".""<br><br> ""Mr T meets the vulgar (common) people of the valley and participates in the vulgar customs (folkways). Looking at the vulgar (common) people, Mr T says - “I pity you foo!”.""<br>#968<br></span>"

""""Excellent!"""" they both yell. But only after grabbing it do they realize it is chained to the neck of Mr. T, who grimaces angrily at them. """"Bogus!"""" they cry, and totally run away.""<br>#970<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 侍</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 侍  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=976"">waiter さむらい</br></br></a>  Mr. T infiltrates the secret samurai Buddhist temple as a waiter with a tray of green tea. (Careful: attend (#960)).<br><br> ""Remember the kanji for wait, 待. Well, now we have a waiter, and he's dropped a dish. See: 侍! 待 crash 侍.""<br>#976<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 停</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 停  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=977"">halt </br></br></a>  """"""Halt fool"""" - Mr T acting as a bouncer at the pavillion.""<br><br> ""Mister T makes a halt at the African pavilion at the World's Fair. He eats all the snacks on offer, and chats up the ladies - """"“I pity da foo who does not halt by your pavilion, it's the best !"""".""<br>#977<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 値</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 値  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=978"">price 価値</br></br></a>  ""Mr. T (person) tells the used car salesman to tell him the real price straight away, and when he doesn't he throws him through the windshield.""<br><br> ""Mr. T is shopping for new chains. He knows what he wants and money isn't an issue. """"Cut the jibba-jabba, tell me the price, straightaway!"""".""<br>#978<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 倣</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 倣  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=979"">emulate</br></br></a>  ""Mr T downloads an emulator so that he can play his favorite game, Pokemon. He plays for a different reason, though - he hates to see them poor little foos in the ball so he spends his entire time setting them free.""<br><br> <br>#979<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 倒</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 倒  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=980"">overthrow たおす</br></br></a>  ""The A-Team are planning to overthrow the government. However, they can't do a damn thing until Mr T arrives.""<br><br> ""In Return of the Jedi, after a climactic light sabre battle, Luke and Vader overthrow the emporer (literally throwing him over the balcony).""<br>#980<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 偵</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 偵  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=981"">spy</br></br></a>  ""Mr. T is a terrible spy. He walks around upright. """"Why should I hide?! I've got nothing to be ashamed of!"""".""<br><br> ""NOTE: The second primitive is upright, not eminent. There is an error in the book.""<br>#981<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 僧</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 僧  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=982"">Buddhist priest こぞう</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""While a waiter at the Buddhist temple (see FRAME 976), Mr T increases in wisdom and becomes a Buddhist priest.""<br>#982<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 億</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 億  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=983"">hundred million</br></br></a>  Mr. T has an clear idea of what he would do if he ever got hundred million dollar. (I guess it would be a enormous gold chain !).<br><br> ""Mr. T's bright idea is to get a hundred million kids to vow not to use drugs. """"C'mon, foo! Sign the paper!"""".""<br>#983<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 儀</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 儀  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=984"">ceremony</br></br></a>  Mr. T is the master of ceremonies because he is a righteous dude.<br><br> ""Mr. T was briefly a rapper, that is an M.C., that is a master of CEREMONIES (the origin of the phrase). But he sang only RIGHTEOUS songs, no cursing or anything like that. (all true: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7_rBidCkJxo ).""<br>#984<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 償</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 償  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=985"">reparation</br></br></a>  ""Mr. T says, """"This ain't no prize, foo! This is reparations for slavery!"""".""<br><br> ""NOTE: do not confuse with compensation (#476)賠. However, 賠 is always used in conjunction 賠償... But 償 is used in various other compounds. Mr. T sold all his jewelry to give as reparations to slave families. The governent tried to honor his charity by giving him a prize, but it was a shitty outhouse filled with clams.""<br>#985<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 仙</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 仙  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=986"">hermit</br></br></a>  Mr T becomes a HERMIT, a PERSON who lives in the MOUNTAINS.<br><br> ""After living as an hermit (recluse) for a while in the mountains, Mister T becomes an immortal mountain fairy (""""fairy"""" is another meaning of this kanji).""<br>#986<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 催</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 催  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=987"">sponsor</br></br></a>  ""And now a word from our sponsor. We see Mr. T, doing a sort of George Foreman thing, grilling <b>Mountain Turkeys</b>. """"I pity da foo who don't have a Mr. T grill!"""".""<br><br> ""Mister T sponsors a meeting in the mountains (he's an hermit), talking over a megaphone “I pity da foo who does not come to my event !”. The old turkey comes, and Mister T catches it and cooks it for dinner, muahaha.""<br>#987<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 仁</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 仁  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=988"">humanity</br></br></a>  The beginning of humanity required at least TWO people. Mr. T and Mrs. T!<br><br> Mr. T shows his humanity by giving two bucks to every homeless person he sees.<br>#988<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 侮</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 侮  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=989"">scorn</br></br></a>  Mr. T has scorn for every fool.<br><br> People full of scorn tend to hate every person (including themselves).<br>#989<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 使</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 使  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=990"">use つかう</br></br></a>  Mr. T uses the officer as a punching bag.<br><br> ""Of course Mr. T will tell a police officer if he catches someone using drugs, foo!""<br>#990<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 便</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 便  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=991"">convenience</br></br></a>  ""Mr. T loves the convenience of the new konbini. Not only does it stay open even if it grows late, they have brand new toilets, and a Post Office!""<br><br> ""Mr. T takes a dump on the floor of a convenience store. Well, it was growing late and he couldn't wait. He pities the fool who will have to clean it up!""<br>#991<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 倍</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 倍  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=992"">double</br></br></a>  Mr. T keeps his double muzzled ... he wants all the glory.<br><br> ""Mr T, like many holywood stars, has a butt double who is used only for scenes where T's buttocks are exposed (he has issues with bearing his behind). The butt double has no speaking parts - he is muzzled. Of course T himself isn't he's rambling on about pity and foo.""<br>#992<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 優</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 優  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=993"">tenderness やさしい</br></br></a>  ""The A-Team is on a mission to help Hamlet. With uncharacteristic tenderness, Mr. T consoles the melancholy Hamlet. """"No, I really DO pity the poor foo. There, there little guy...take my hanky"""". (Careful: benevolence (#885).""<br><br> Someone can't be melancholy for long if just one person treats them with a little tenderness.<br>#993<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 伐</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 伐  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=994"">fell</br></br></a>  <br><br> Mr T at the fiesta fell over blind drunk.<br>#994<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 宿</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 宿  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=995"">inn</br></br></a>  The Toyoko Inn can house 100 people or 1 Mr. T.<br><br> ""The inn is like a big house that can addomodate a hundred persons. Only this time, there's just Mister T and he's booked all the rooms!""<br>#995<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 傷</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 傷  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=996"">wound</br></br></a>  <br><br> Mr. T gets wounded by reclining on his piggy bank.<br>#996<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 保</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 保  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=997"">protect</br></br></a>  ""Mr. T opens his mouth from the top of the tree saying """"I pitty da foo who don't protect the trees!"""".""<br><br> Tip: Heisig later combines mouth and tree into 呆 dumbfounded (#2181). Story: Your person (Mr. T. or whoever) is dumbfounded when told to protect the bad guys rather than fight them.<br>#997<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 褒</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 褒  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=998"">praise ほめる</br></br></a>  ""Mr. T is praised for his protecting of the trees by being given a top hat and scarf which he wears over his mohawk and chains, respectively.""<br><br> ""An old lady puts a top hat and scarf on her poodle and praises him for how cute he is. The dog thinks, """"Someone protect me from this psycho!""""...　RTK2:　ホウ　過褒　かほう(excessive praise).""<br>#998<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 傑</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 傑  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=999"">greatness</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""Mr T stands in front of you, his greatness radiating out from him so brightly. You need to put on your sunglasses and hide behind a tree to even talk to the guy. """"Recognise, foo!"""".""<br>#999<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 付</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 付  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1000"">adhere</br></br></a>  ""賀 TO EVERYONE WHO MADE IT TO 千 kanji!! Remember, after this, you'll be 読ing japanese novels, the news, and the internet like a native. 吉 to ALL of you in your amazing japanese 往. :).""<br><br> ""If a PERSON ADHERES to something, they stick to it like GLUE.""<br>#1000<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 符</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 符  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1001"">token 切ぷ</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""At the arcade, Mr. T adheres a bamboo rod to his token so that he can put it in the machine and pull it out repeatedly.""<br>#1001<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 府</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 府  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1002"">municipality/area/prefecture etc　ふ県</br></br></a>  ""A municipality, like any type of government, adheres to having caves for offices (see government office (#591)).""<br><br> ""Even if a municipality is in a cave, you have to adhere to its policies.""<br>#1002<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 任</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 任  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1003"">responsibility 任せる</br></br></a>  It is always Mr. T's responsibility to be the porter and carry around everyone's luggage because he's so strong.<br><br> ""In pregnancy (#507), the woman was the porter for the first nine months. Now, as a new father, Mr.T is assuming all the RESPONSIBILITIES that comes with it. Can't you just see him here as the new porter, wearing a harness with a his little dude (who already has a little matching mohawk)?""<br>#1003<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 賃</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 賃  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1004"">fare ちん金</br></br></a>  It's your own responsibility to pay the bus fare with the correct number of shells/money.<br><br> ""In Japan they have automatic ticket gates so you cant easily cheat on your train fare. In England however the ticket gates are fairly open. It is a different kind of system. In England you are given the RESPONSIBILITY to put in the right amount of MONEY, but if you are caught cheating, the fines are stiff and you feel like a real CHINCHIN. """"un.CHIN"""".""<br>#1004<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 代</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 代  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1005"">substitute</br></br></a>  """"""Mister T substitutes an arrow for a toothpick"""" -- The keyword meaning is to replace something with something else, to act for another, to represent. It's best to stick to the first meaning, because the last two are very close to """"mediator"""" which will come in frame 1761. The idea here is that the arrow is not a toothpick, neither it is changed into one, but it can substitute for one.""<br><br> Mr. T shot the substitute teacher with an arrow.<br>#1005<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 袋</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 袋  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1006"">sack</br></br></a>  A sack is an easy substitute for a garment.<br><br> ""A worker who was recently sacked from his job, is wearing a sack of potatoes as a substitute garment (naked otherwise), in some kind of protest. The kanji is close to frame 1547 """"bag"""", and although the later really refers to a """"straw sack"""", I use the image of a sack of potatoes here, and that of a """"plastic bag"""" for frame 1547. The keywords would have been better swapped in my opinion, but the relevancy is not so important at this point (see notes of Lesson 31 in the book).""<br>#1006<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 貸</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 貸  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1007"">lend</br></br></a>  ""In order for the bank to lend you money, you need to put up some sort of collateral as a substitute for the money.""<br><br> The poor substitute teacher asks the class to lend him some money for the bus fare home.<br>#1007<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 化</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 化  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1008"">change</br></br></a>  <br><br> Mr. T reaches into his wallet for some spare change but it has all changed into spoons.<br>#1008<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 花</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 花  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1009"">flower はな</br></br></a>  The flowers change with the seasons.<br><br> ""The flower is the essence of transience. So, the conceptual flower involves both the concept of flower plus change.""<br>#1009<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 貨</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 貨  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1010"">freight かもつ 貨物</br></br></a>  Freight is the shells (money) paid to change the location of something big. Don't confuse with the similar 賃 fare (#1004).<br><br> ""This is a freight train that runs on spare change. Imagine getting on the freight train with a bunch of spare change. You put in some change and it starts up...goes for a few minutes, then starts to slow down. You look at the slot..there's actually a slot for spare change and one for regular shells. Your call, but it seems to prefer spare change over shells.""<br>#1010<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 傾</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 傾  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1011"">lean かたむく</br></br></a>  Mr. T gave a girl some change to lean over and give him head.<br><br> Leaning over changes the position of the head...　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　ケイ　傾向　けいこう(tendency).<br>#1011<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 何</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 何  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1012"">what</br></br></a>  ""What can Mr T do? 'You mean: what can't MR T do, you fool'.""<br><br> What can't Mr. T not do?<br>#1012<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 荷</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 荷  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1013"">baggage に物</br></br></a>  ""TSA guard: What's in the baggage?! It's just flowers, I swear!""<br><br> ""Your girlfriend arrives at the airport. You give her flowers, but she brushes you off and says """"here, carry my BAGGAGE."""" Dumbfounded at her rudeness, you say, """"what?"""".""<br>#1013<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 俊</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 俊  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1014"">sagacious</br></br></a>  ""The entire town wants to get rid of legal prostitutes, but the sagacious Mr T realizes that they are a benefit to the economy and society. So he lets the sa-geishas stay.""<br><br> ""(re: sweetneet) Since he is not very sagacious, Mr. T failed his driver's license and now needs to resort to his walking legs to get around.""<br>#1014<br></span>"

(thx shimouma).""<br><br> ""Mr. T is in the street, standing up, wearing an golden crown and a compass in his hand... he's asking the bystander if they know how to get to buckingham palace (!).""<br>#1015<br></span>"

It's a little more like """"evening"""" with an extra stroke across it (look up the stroke order). So, it helps me to see this kanji for night as: evening plus an extra stroke representing the tuxedo tails to match the top hat which my special person is wearing out on the town...""<br><br> <br>#1037<br></span>"

It solidifes during the day, and becomes fluid only at night, in the absence of light. The question is, could any lifeforms thrive in there ?""<br>#1038<br></span>"

This is Queen of the Hillock. I think of the sounds that would come from the mouths of the 4 dogs if they were bound up together. I'm imagining lots of yelping.<br><br> ""Yell? You mean, Old Yeller. Here, we see four St Bernard dogs all yelling for a chance to play a part in Old Yeller. They're so loud that you have to bound them, and their mouths, up.""<br>#1042<br></span>"

Giraffes, elephants, zebras, rhinos...""<br><br> ""Don't confuse with revolve or axis! Think of rotation as a rotation of animals in the zoo - some are on display (in rotation), some are in cages in the back (out of rotation). The ones currently in rotation (on display) are advertised with a large banner.""<br>#1046<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 遊</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 遊  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1047"">play</br></br></a>  The BANNER warns that CHILDREN PLAY on the ROAD.<br><br> ""There is always a stupid banner talking about children at play near the road. They mean """"drive slowly"""", but it sounds like its slow(stupid) children that are at play.""<br>#1047<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 旅</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 旅  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1048"">trip</br></br></a>  ""The boat starts to leave on it's trip across the Atlantic. Underneath a huge banner that spans the width of the ship and says """"Bon Voyage"""", the people wave their rags signalling a safe journey for all on board the Titanic.""<br><br> ""After a long long trip, what once was a proud beautiful banner, we had nothing more than a simple rag remaining.""<br>#1048<br></span>"

""""This is a piglet...(cuts of head)...NOT!"""".""<br>#1049<br></span>"

Its an animal. If you study japanese you know that living beings and things are discerned from each other with the verbs iru and aru.<br>#1050<br></span>"

I see this as a pseudo-pictograph, and use the horizontal line across the top to represent the curtain rod, since noren don't usually hang from the ceiling.""<br><br> ""A Japanese door has a noren, a flag hanging from a rod. (I give this primitive the meaning of a noren-covered door).""<br>#1076<br></span>"

I was having trouble with positioning of the primitives until I tweaked shaydwyrm's story slightly. If you think of pushing through a noren, this makes sense as a pictograph.
