They don't want to be caught playing solitare on company time.<br>#1084<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 啓</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 啓  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1085"">disclose</br></br></a>  ""Behind closed DOORS, the TASKMASTER tortures to get prisoners to open their MOUTHS and DISCLOSE information.""<br><br> <br>#1085<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 示</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 示  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1086"">show/altar primitive しめす</br></br></a>  ""A boy made an altar, but he's afraid to show it to God because he thinks it's two little.""<br><br> """"""I'll SHOW you mine if you show me yours!"""", she said. I did & she scoffed because it was TWO LITTLE.""<br>#1086<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 礼</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 礼  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1087"">salutation</br></br></a>  """"""Indy, my friend, you must be very careful! If you approach the altar and do not give the proper salutation a large fishhook will rip you away"""".""<br><br> You should fish hook (bend/bow) your body before an altar as a form of salutation to God/gods.<br>#1087<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 祥</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 祥  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1088"">auspicious 発祥</br></br></a>  ""Bringing a sheep to sacrifice on the altar was a sign of an auspicious life.""<br><br> <br>#1088<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 祝</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 祝  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1089"">celebrate&nbsp;いわい</br></br></a>  ""It's a Bar Mitzvah. At the altar, the teenager is singing in his awful, mid-puberty voice. We'll all celebrate when that part is over!""<br><br> When Japanese people turn 20 they usually visit the altar at their local shrine and celebrate no longer being a teenager.<br>#1089<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 福</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 福  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1090"">blessing ふく</br></br></a>  <br><br> Put all your wealth on the church altar and receive one blessing.&nbsp;<br>#1090<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 祉</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 祉  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1091"">welfare し福</br></br></a>  ""And in front of every altar, she stopped to pray for the welfare of the others.""<br><br> Religious Republicans regularly go to the altar to pray for a stop to welfare.<br>#1091<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 社</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 社  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1092"">company 会しゃ</br></br></a>  When you enter a Japanese company it's like you join a cult... your workdesk becomes your altar and you worship the very soil the office is built on.<br><br> ""Some Japanese companies, including Toyota, have a Shinto shrine on their grounds to bring luck and prosperity to the company and its employees.""<br>#1092<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 視</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 視  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1093"">inspection</br></br></a>  ""The beaurocracy in Japan is such that even altars need to be inspection approved. A little man with glasses comes once a year to give the altar a """"visual once over"""" as he calls it (perhaps checking for unauthorised symbology?).""<br><br> [inspection; regard as; see; look at] Inspection: you 示 show (#1086) and someone else 見 see (#57).<br>#1093<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 奈</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 奈  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1094"">Nara</br></br></a>  ""It's beautiful place, but the dark side of Nara is that they sacrifice St. Bernards on evil altars every night after the tourists leave!""<br><br> Nara is just a big show for tourists.<br>#1094<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 尉</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 尉  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1095"">military officer&nbsp;い官</br></br></a>  Of course it had to be the military officer's idea to glue a giant alter to the national flag where he is stationed<br><br> <br>#1095<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 慰</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 慰  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1096"">consolation なぐさめる</br></br></a>  A military officer must offer consolation to the hearts of the families of his fallen men.<br><br> ""This Kanji appears in the word 慰安婦 いあんふ, which was what the infamous WW II """"comfort women"""" were called in Japanese. The story goes something like this: As a way of providing consolation to battle-weary, heartsick military officers and soldiers, the Japanese set up comfort stations (brothels) for their servicemen. (Just to be clear: this is not an endorsement of the practice, just a way to remember the Kanji.).""<br>#1096<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 款</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 款  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1097"">goodwill</br></br></a>  ""Samuari, altar, yawn The samurai is on the altar, preaching about goodwill. The audience just yawns however, they want to see the man fight!""<br><br> ""For better remembering the placement of the eleements: The samurai kneels before the altar at his wedding ceremony, when some of the attendants lets out a big yawn. He is a kind man and for the day his goodwill benefits everyone. No beheadings.""<br>#1097<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 禁</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 禁  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1098"">prohibition</br></br></a>  ""If you live in Japan, your main exposure to this kanji is probably """"no smoking"""" signs. So I imagine the government enacting a prohibition of tobacco, and burning whole groves of tobacco plants on an altar (the altar of public health, or self-righteousness, if you will).""<br><br> ""Hidden in a grove was a church with a secret altar that was stocked full of prohibited alcohol during the American prohibition period of 1920-1933. A local registered himself as a mininster of this altar so he could stock prohibited alcohol """"for sacremental purposes"""" and share it with his kin (きん).""<br>#1098<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 襟</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 襟  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1099"">collar</br></br></a>  ""A collar is the part of your cloak that, if tightened too tight, will prohibit breathing.""<br><br> Collars are prohibited from wizarding cloaks. Blood purists say they're too muggle.<br>#1099<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 宗</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 宗  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1100"">religion</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""All the RELIGIONS have their own temples, which are houses where they place their altars.""<br>#1100<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 崇</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 崇  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1101"">adore</br></br></a>  ""In ancient Greece, it was the religion of the time to adore the gods who live on Mount Olympus.""<br><br> I would adore the religious people if they just went and threw themselves off a mountain top.<br>#1101<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 祭</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 祭  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1102"">ritual&nbsp;まつり</br></br></a>  A ritual such as a circumcision: a small piece of flesh from the crotch is left on the altar.<br><br> There are many famous penis matsuris(festivals) in Japan. The rituals of these festivals involve placing the flesh of the crotch on an altar.<br>#1102<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 察</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 察  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1103"">guess</br></br></a>  I have an informed guess about whose house the dark rituals are performed at.<br><br> It's anyone's guess who's house she will wake up in the morning after the festival (祭-matsuri)　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　サツ　警察　けいさつ(police)…　Pure Group:　擦1104.<br>#1103<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 擦</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 擦  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1104"">grate</br></br></a>  If you mis-guess the cheese you'll grate your fingers on the cheese-grater (happens to me all the time).<br><br> Ouch! Guess how many fingers I just grated in the grater? (Edit: OR: Ouch! Guess what I just grated in the grater? -- my finger!).<br>#1104<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 由</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 由  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1105"">wherefore 自由</br></br></a>  """"""Wherefore art thou, Sprouteo?""""<br><br> <br>#1105<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 抽</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 抽  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1106"">pluck</br></br></a>  ""[When I see the word pluck, I think eyebrows, not vegetables. So, to avoid confusing with pick (#733):] Each time this singular, long, wiry black hair starts to sprout out of my chin again, I pluck it with my fingers.""<br><br> ""If you pluck your fingers, new ones will sprout in their place. (try it ;).""<br>#1106<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 油</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 油  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1107"">oil</br></br></a>  The liquid oil that sprouts from an oil field.<br><br> ""In a rather surprising scientific breakthrough, genetically modified Brussel sprouts (which have become extremely absorbative), are thrown in the water to suck up oil spills.""<br>#1107<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 袖</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 袖  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1108"">sleeve そで</br></br></a>  ""Imagine some magic cloak, that when worn, has little green sprouts appearing on the sides that grow into sleeves.""<br><br> ""The bad magician says, """"As you can see, there's nothing up my sleeves!"""" Then he trips over his cloak and brussel sprouts fall everywhere.""<br>#1108<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 宙</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 宙  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1109"">mid-air</br></br></a>  ""Jack's beanstalk sprouted up, pushed at the roof and lifted the house so that it hangs in mid-air suspended on the SPROUT.""<br><br> ""Hahaha, the image of walking into a house and finding a sea of brussel sprouts floating mid-air is enough for me to remember. Maybe there's a magician in the kitchen shouting a reassuring """"Don't mind the sprouts!"""".""<br>#1109<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 届</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 届  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1110"">deliver</br></br></a>  ""In the US, when the mail is delivered, a flag sprouts up on your mailbox. (We don't have that in Australia.).""<br><br> ""A Japanese man ordered some Brussel sprouts from Belgium. They are delivered with a little Belgian flag (as seen sometimes in shops, little flags indicating the provenance and authenticity of the food like cheese and meat).""<br>#1110<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 笛</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 笛  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1111"">flute&nbsp;ふえ</br></br></a>  Flute is made of bamboo sprout.<br><br> ""You pick up your bamboo flute, and recoil in shock as out comes not the dulcet melody you had hoped to play, but rather a Brussels sprout! You play again, and again a Brussels sprout. A bamboo flute that plays sprouts! Fabulous! Puts that golden egg laying goose in its place.""<br>#1111<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 軸</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 軸  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1112"">axis</br></br></a>  The Germans manufactured so many cars during World War II that it was almost as if they were sprouting from the factories of the Axis.<br><br> ""An absurd image, but what the heck - worked for me. Imagine a car going across a plain at a fast speed. Suddenly a single sprout (the only one to be seen) gets stuck to the car's wheels, causing the car to fly around its axis.""<br>#1112<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 甲</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 甲  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1113"">armor</br></br></a>  ""Funny.. this appeared to me as a pictograph of a samurai's armor. Then I looked up images of the samurai armor and it is not even remotely similar. Then I realised it looks in fact like the belly of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, which I somehow associated with the samurai armor because of the """"turtle samurai"""" that appeared earlier. Fits me. The bit that pokes down is to protect the genitals, I guess.""<br><br> It looks like a bird's eye view of a tank (modern armor).<br>#1113<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 押</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 押  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1114"">push</br></br></a>  ""Push the roots down, instead of plucking the seedling.""<br><br> ""Use your fingers to make sure the roots of your plant are deep underground by pushing them down, down, down.""<br>#1114<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 岬</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 岬  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1115"">headland&nbsp;みさき</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""Headlands are natural forts; in fact, once men build castles on them, they become armoured mountains. (Gibralter, for example, is basically an armoured mountain).""<br>#1115<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 挿</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 挿  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1116"">insert</br></br></a>  ""A rice farmer's delicate fingers have inserted 1,000 rooted seedlings into his field.""<br><br> <br>#1116<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 申</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 申  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1117"">speaketh</br></br></a>  ""I imagine thomeone who can not pronounth the """"s"""" and speaketh like thith becauth they have a cane in their mouth.""<br><br> ""I had persistent trouble confusing this one with 曰 sayeth (#578). The way I keep it sorted out is that this one is used in """"moshi moshi"""" when answering the phone, similar to the way an American would say """"hello, this is X speaking."""".""<br>#1117<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 伸</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 伸  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1118"">expand 伸べる</br></br></a>  Here we see Mr. T. expanding his gang with some trained fighter monkeys.<br><br> ""Mr. T wants to show you the incredible expanding monkey trick. He grabs a monkey by the tail and neck, stretches him out a few times, then blows him up like a balloon. The monkey EXPANDs until it pops. Haha, sucka monkey, I pity you foo.""<br>#1118<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 神</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 神  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1119"">gods かみ様</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""Hinduism has many gods, not just one God. One of the most famous of these gods is Hanuman the monkey. Many altars are dedicated to him.""<br>#1119<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 捜</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 捜  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1120"">search</br></br></a>  The monkey searches around with his fingers for his crotch.<br><br> ""If you are familiar with the Monkey legends (西遊記 Journey to the West) there is a good image for this character: While searching for the end of the universe, monkey reaches to his crotch and urinates on Buddha's fingers. (Update: new link http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RYXFppaKLL4).""<br>#1120<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 果</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 果  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1121"">fruit くだもの</br></br></a>  If only Eve had used her brains and not taken the forbidden fruit from the tree.<br><br> Eve ate fruit from the tree and knowledge filled her brain.…　　　　　　RTK2:　カ　果汁　かじゅう (fruit juice)…　　　　　　　　　　　　　　Semi-Pure Group:　菓1122　課1123　(ﾗ): 裸1124.<br>#1121<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 菓</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 菓  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1122"">candy おか子</br></br></a>  ""This candy is made in the shape of a flower, each petal with the taste of a different fruit.""<br><br> Candy is coloured like flowers and flavoured like fruit.<br>#1122<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 課</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 課  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1123"">chapter</br></br></a>  ""After I finish each chapter of RTK, I eat a piece of fruit to celebrate all the new words I've learned. (Thanks Misha!).""<br><br> ""Words signify the written words in a book. The fruit represents something whole, complete. A chapter in a book often offers a complete idea, setting, or account. It's good to disambiguate the keyword from paragraph (#82). To reinforce the kanji, imagine eating a fruit at the end of each chapter of Tolstoy's """"War and Peace"""" to reward yourself. (If you ate a fruit at the end of each paragraph, you'd very quickly run out of fruit).""<br>#1123<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 裸</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 裸  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1124"">naked はだか</br></br></a>  ""Here we have Adam and Eve eating of the forbidden fruit and realizing they were naked, and so clothing themselves in a cloak.""<br><br> <br>#1124<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 斤</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 斤  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1125"">ax</br></br></a>  Errata: stroke order in 4th edition is wrong. Top stroke is first.<br><br> ""The axe-wielding maniac nails a poor victim, right under a cliff. Blood everywhere! (thanks scottamus!).""<br>#1125<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 所</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 所  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1127"">place</br></br></a>  You outsiders better learn your place! An axe stuck in the door when you get home is a pretty good indicator that this might not be the best place for you.<br><br> A place for everything and everything in its place. To the right of the door is the standard place for the axe.<br>#1127<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 近</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 近  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1129"">near ちかく</br></br></a>  The end is near. The axe-murderer is waiting for you on the road...<br><br> ""An absurd image, but working for me: two points A and B are separated by a long road. To make A and B near, take an ax, cut a big chunk of road, and the work is done.""<br>#1129<br></span>"

It's even as sharp, so watch out for paper cuts!""<br>#1130<br></span>"

The day where you can temporarily attack cars using an axe without punishment. <br>#1134<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 漸</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 漸  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1135"">steadily</br></br></a>  ""I imagine firemen working steadily to rescue a man from a crashed car. First, they spray it with water; then, they use an axe to break through the window.""<br><br> ""Water + Car + Axe: The steadily rising water was filling the car, but the firefighters took their axe and broke the window, getting me out.""<br>#1135<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 断</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 断  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1136"">severance</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""When you get the ax at work, use your severance pay to buy fishhooks and rice. At least that way you can eat sushi.""<br>#1136<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 質</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 質  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1137"">substance しつ問</br></br></a>  What is this substance on this clam? I've already broken 2 axes on it! (Good question...質問).<br><br> ""Another keyword that I do not like by Heisig. 質【しつ】 (n,n-suf) quality. Story: Your at a local ax dealer and you have TWO AXES which you are testing for QUALITY by trying to split CLAMS right down the opening. Picture yourself succeeding with one AX and then some weird SUBSTANCE comes out of the shell...eww (I don't like clams).""<br>#1137<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 斥</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 斥  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1138"">reject</br></br></a>  The kids at school used to reject me.. Made me feel really bad till I brought my axe to school. See the drop of blood on it?<br><br> ""The quality expectations are very high in our axe manufacturing facility. If there's one drop of rust on any axe, it gets rejected.""<br>#1138<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 昨</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 昨  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1140"">yesterday</br></br></a>  One can use a simple word play to remember this character - the day that I saw before today was yesterday.<br><br> ""Yester-DAY, all my troubles seemed SAW far away...""<br>#1140<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 詐</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 詐  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1141"">lie 詐欺</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""Her lies are words that cut not like a knife, no not cleanly, but savagely like a saw.""<br>#1141<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 作</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 作  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1142"">make つくる</br></br></a>  ""Mr T.'s favorite magazine is Make. He loves to make things. But he's a purist: he only uses saws, no power tools.""<br><br> ""When the A-Team crash lands on a deserted island, Mr. T salvages a saw from the wreckage and says, """"I don't know about y'all foos, but I'm gonna make a raft."""".""<br>#1142<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 雪</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 雪  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1143"">snow ゆき</br></br></a>  ""SNOW isn't all that different from RAIN, except it can be removed with a BROOM because it only forms in freezing temperatures.""<br><br> Rain just soaks into the soil. Snow has to be swept away with a broom...　RTK2:　セツ　積雪　せきせつ(pilled up snow).<br>#1143<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 録</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 録  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1144"">record</br></br></a>  A monk won a gold metal for breaking the current record for most swept rice in one minute.<br><br> This character is about a recording for a music box. The tines of the mechanism are like a metal broom and the little pins on the cylinder are like metal grains of rice.<br>#1144<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 尋</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 尋  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1145"">inquire</br></br></a>  ""The policed inquired into the erotica scandal. They tried to sweep away the evidence, but some of it stuck. (Note: katakana エロ ero in the middle of this kanji is the Japanese word for erotica.).""<br><br> <br>#1145<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 急</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 急  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1146"">hurry</br></br></a>  ""She was always bound to a broom, her heart pounding in a hurry to finish before she was punished for being slow.""<br><br> Fantasia: Bound up brooms out of control send Mickey's heart racing--he has to hurry and figure out how to stop them before the magician returns!<br>#1146<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 穏</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 穏  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1147"">calm</br></br></a>  The farmer is calm knowing that his wheat fields are protected from vultures by his strawman with a heart (all the better to do the job properly).<br><br> This whole kanji is a picture of calmness. The wheat has been harvested and even the vultures sit calmly watching the humans sweep and clean-up after the harvest is over. Hearts are peaceful and calm at this time of the year. Even the days are calm without storm.<br>#1147<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 侵</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 侵  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1148"">encroach 侵入</br></br></a>  ""Mr T. ENCROACHES on the French maid; driven wild by her little broom, dainty tiara and sinfully short skirt showing her knickers (crotch)!""<br><br> Mr T. hits a condom salesman (broom + crown + crotch) over the head with a broom because the dude ENCROACHed Mr. T's privates area during the sale.<br>#1148<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 浸</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 浸  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1149"">immersed</br></br></a>  ""The French maid draws a bath for her amorous master, but slips and falls in - getting immersed.""<br><br> ""After being hit in the head with the broom, the condom salesman IMMERSED his head in some water.""<br>#1149<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 寝</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 寝  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1150"">lie down</br></br></a>  ""After work, the French maid goes home and lies down with a turtle. Turtle? Well, he's sloooow and always hard... (thanks to Nukemarine and Wakela!).""<br><br> ""After being hit on the head encroach (#1148), the condom salesman goes back to his house to lie down. He hasn't made a single sale today, so he doesn't have enough money to buy a pillow. He lies down on his pet turtle and cries himself to sleep.""<br>#1150<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 婦</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 婦  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1151"">lady しゅふ</br></br></a>  ""In high society, a lady is a woman who never touches a broom or an apron.""<br><br> The LADY of the house is nothing more than a WOMAN who's a HOUSEWIFE (BROOM and APRON anyone?).<br>#1151<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 掃</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 掃  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1152"">sweep 掃除</br></br></a>  ""Whether I SWEEP something away with my FINGERS or my BROOM, I should always wear my APRON.""<br><br> ""FINGERS of the HOUSEWIFE (in itself, holding a BROOM, with an APRON) busily SWEEP the floor.""<br>#1152<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 当</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 当  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1153"">hit</br></br></a>  Some mothers use a small broom to hit their children when they misbehave.<br><br> ""Here is a weird carnival game where you hold a broom like a javelin and throw it, trying to hit the center of a very small target. The target is so small, in fact, that if someone does manage to hit it, the operator turns in surprise and says, """"Whoa, really?! (本当?!)"""".""<br>#1153<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 争</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 争  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1154"">contend</br></br></a>  ""This can be seen as a Retarius, a roman gladiator. The Retiarius always fought with a net to bound up his opponents, and with a trident, which was able to pierce enemies after tying them. They were terrific contenders, so they were only paired with gladiators specially equipped to fight them.""<br><br> A boxing ring is bound up by the ropes. The contender is cheating and using a rake.<br>#1154<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 浄</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 浄  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1155"">clean&nbsp;</br></br></a>  <br><br> The water contends against the dirt in the ultimate battle for cleaninless.<br>#1155<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 事</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 事  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1156"">matter こと</br></br></a>  Just one word about this matter from your mouth and you will find this rake across it.<br><br> I had to take one day off from work due to 'personal matters' after stepping on a rake and having the handle snap up and smack me across the mouth. I certainly wasn't going to tell anyone about it.<br>#1156<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 唐</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 唐  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1157"">T'ang</br></br></a>  ""Two archeologists are in a cave looking at Chinese artifacts from various eras. One picks up a rake and says, """"What about this – T'ang, do you think?"""" The second puts the rake in his mouth and answers, """"Yes, it does tang a bit"""".""<br><br> ""Screw it, this character refers to the drink. The powdery orange substance is actually found on the floor of tropical caves, where trained aboriginal peoples use wooden rakes to rake the Tang into a pile before putting a bit of it in their mouths to see if it's tasty or not.""<br>#1157<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 糖</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 糖  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1158"">sugar</br></br></a>  Sugar made from rice has a tangy flavour.<br><br> ""The T'ang are the ones who began using sugar in China--of course, the first thing they tried it on was rice.""<br>#1158<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 康</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 康  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1159"">sane 健康</br></br></a>  ""A psychiatric hospital is located in a CAVE. To determine, which patients are sane and can be released, they are given a SIEVE and asked to empty a bathtub (the sane ones take out the plug and get the water out with ease).""<br><br> ""People on the cave age became more sane after they started using sieves to avoid eating harmful things with their grains. (This kanji is almost exclusively used to write 健康, health).""<br>#1159<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 逮</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 逮  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1160"">apprehend</br></br></a>  ""Think police roadblocks. They act like road sieves, letting good people through but apprehending criminals.""<br><br> ""In Space Balls, they were combing the desert in order to apprehend Lone Star. Picture Dark Helmet saying """"Combing the desert failed, we must now sieve the road!"""".""<br>#1160<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 伊</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 伊  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1161"">Italy</br></br></a>  ""The """"boot"""" of Italy has gotten Europe all muddy. Who else could mop it up but Mr T?""<br><br> ""Here I have Mister T cleaning up with a mop, a real mess of spaghetti, in front of the Piza (in Italy).""<br>#1161<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 君</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 君  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1162"">old boy きみ</br></br></a>  ""There's a tendancy in Japan to make the younger members (kouhai) clean up after the older members (senpai) of a group, which results in a lot of grumbling and whining. """"Well old boy,"""" a senpai might say, """"If you did as much work with the mop as you do with your mouth, you would have been done an hour ago"""".""<br><br> ""The Beatles, english old boys, had hairs like mop and a good singing mouth.""<br>#1162<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 群</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 群  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1163"">flock</br></br></a>  Good ol' boys are like sheep; they tend to flock together.<br><br> ""A little girl herder calls out, """"羊君、きて！"""" to the sheeps and they flock to her at once.""<br>#1163<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 耐</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 耐  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1164"">-proof</br></br></a>  ""[akrodha] My comb is rust-proof, water-proof, and fire-proof. But unfortunately it is not idiot-proof--and I glued it to myself.""<br><br> ""I spent $100 recently on this excellent rust-proof, water-proof, fire-proof comb. But two days after having bought it, I left it in my back pocket and sat down, snapping this expensive comb in half! I glued it back together, but now every time I try to comb through my thick hair, it just breaks apart again. I guess my comb is also glue-proof.""<br>#1164<br></span>"

It probably wouldn't seem so heroic if you saw him ten minutes earlier, when a crew of stylists was carefully combing his hair so it would fall perfectly.""<br><br> ""When you stand a comb on its edge, it looks like the mountain (#768) kanji.""<br>#1167<br></span>"

See volfy post for link. Both effective ways to commit suicide, hang your self from the celing with your belt or jump off a mountain.""<br><br> Both of Tiger Wood's initials is the logo on his belt... 　　　　　　　　RTK2:　リョウ　両親　りょうしん(one's parents).<br>#1168<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 満</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 満  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1169"">full</br></br></a>  Add water THEN the flowers. With both the vase will be full.<br><br> ""I was thirsty so I gulped down the water. Then I realized I was also hungry. So I ate the flowers. Yes, I am responsible for both the missing water and the missing flowers. Yes, I'm afraid both. Am I still hungry or thirsty? Thank you for asking! How kind! But no, I feel quite full now.""<br>#1169<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 画</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 画  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1170"">brush stroke</br></br></a>  ""You decide one day to paint a kanji on your ceiling. Unfortunately, you don’t have a brush, so, being innovative, you use a sprout. Knowing it could be messy, you search for a drop-cloth, but can’t find one. Instead, you put a shovel down on the floor to catch any drips resulting from the BRUSH-STROKEs.""<br><br> ""To paint a kanji in your ceiling with only natural materials, you use a sprout as a brush and shovel some dirt to use as paint for your strokes. [modified from johnskb's].""<br>#1170<br></span>"

Thus, I use the character Bender the robot as a primitive.""<br><br> ""Also means """"melody"""". Think of it as a pictogram of a guitar where you have to bend the strings to make a melody.""<br>#1172<br></span>"

The space cadet encounters aliens on the road.<br><br> ""Bender the cadet (see frame 1172) has an """"encounter of the third kind"""" on the road. Also a reference to popular stories of people reportedly chased by UFO's while driving on the road.""<br>#1174<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 斗</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 斗  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1177"">Big Dipper</br></br></a>  ""Since the meaning of """"big dipper"""" is rather specific and the sense of measurement seems to be a more common usage, I concentrate on the primative meaning of measuring cup. This is a pictograph, with the first two strokes representing the measuring ticks on the side of the cup.""<br><br> ""Is it just me, or do all of these traditional kanji pictographs look like they were drawn by a retarded bunny rabbit?""<br>#1177<br></span>"

Naturally we don't just use any cup; it has to be a proper measuring cup.""<br><br> Samurai(s) once received their fee in the form of rice that had been carefully weighed in a measuring cup beforehand.<br>#1178<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 図</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 図  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1180"">map ず</br></br></a>  ""Can't see direct relation to Big Dipper (#1177) since its writing order is completely different. As raulir noted, it's written as overlapping at the last stroke of ツ and the first of メ. I take it as a pictograph or treasure map. Two dots represent big trees and the cross (marking the treasure) is placed relative to them.""<br><br> ""A pictograph of a treasure map. Two steps east then X marks the spot. 図る はかる attempt, deceive; 地図 ちず map; 意図する いとする make a goal, intend to do.""<br>#1180<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 用</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 用  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1181"">utilize</br></br></a>  ""To tenderize meat in an emergency wilderness situation, just utilize your walking stick!""<br><br> ""I'll confuse this with use (#990), so build a distinction right from the start. For me, """"utilize"""" has an artificial, business-speak connotation; you only utilize """"utilize"""" when you're trying to puff up what you're saying and sound important. So: """"BioTools Inc introduces the FG2000 screwdriver, utilizing the our latest FleshGrip(tm) technology!"""" I'm seeing this as a picture of a stubby screwdriver with a handle made of flesh, a short shaft, and prongs to hold a screw in place until you drive it.""<br>#1181<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 庸</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 庸  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1182"">comfortable</br></br></a>  ""To live a comfortable life, single men need only a cave for living, a rake for cleaning and a screwdriver for fixing.""<br><br> ""When I first moved in to my new cave, all I had was a bed (see bed (#592)). But now I've settled in, got myself a few handy things like a rake and a screwdriver, and made myself more comfortable.""<br>#1182<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 備</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 備  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1183"">equip そなえる</br></br></a>  Mr. T wants to climb up and pick the flowers at the top of the cliff. He equips himself with screwdrivers to use as climbing spikes to reach the top of the cliff. Imagine a large AMMO belt full of philips screwdrivers instead of bullets.<br><br> ""An RPG where you're using Mr T as a character. Before you enter a battle, you equip the flower cliff screwdriver. This is a small screwdriver obtained at the bottom of a cliff that, when used in battle, shoots out pink flowers. When they touch the ground in front of the enemy, they create a massive cliff, and the ground under the enemy falls away into the sea. Picture being at the item select menu and EQUIPping this item just before facing a tough boss.""<br>#1183<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 昔</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 昔  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1184"">once upon a time&nbsp;むかし</br></br></a>  ""Once upon a time, the children were forced to eat their salad every day.""<br><br> ""For those who don't know the expression, """"salad days"""" means the time of one's youth. (originally from Shakespeare's Antony and Cleopatra - see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salad_days). I suspect Heisig chose """"salad"""" as the name for the radical just for this phrase...""<br>#1184<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 錯</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 錯  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1185"">confused こうさく</br></br></a>  ""Once upon a time, people of the world got confused because there were so many kinds of Metal coins. today we only have the euro.""<br><br> ""Once upon a time, it was thought that the ancient """"art"""" of alchemy could transform anything into gold. At that time, people were obviously confused about the difference between reality and myth. (Arguably people are still as confused as ever, just about different things now.).""<br>#1185<br></span>"

He keeps watching it over and over again, trying to figure out how the Fairy Godmother does her magic.""<br>#1186<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 措</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 措  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1188"">set aside おく</br></br></a>  ""Once upon a time, our ancestors set aside the use of fingers and began to use cutlery.""<br><br> """"""Once upon a time..."""" Oh hell, you're just too old for this. You close your fairy tale book and set it aside, pushing it away with your fingers.""<br>#1188<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 散</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 散  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1189"">scatter ちる</br></br></a>  ""The taskmaster is dissatisfied with the meal she's served, and scatters the salad & meat across the floor for the servants to clean up.""<br><br> ""Perhaps you've heard of Nyotaimori or Nantaimori (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nyotaimori) in which sushi is ate from the flesh of a naked person, the story comes easily. Scatter salad over the flesh of the taskmaster in preperation for some nantaimori :).""<br>#1189<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 廿</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 廿  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1190"">twenty</br></br></a>  ""A generation is 30, one stroke less is twenty.""<br><br> Ten plus ten is twenty (see generation (#28)).<br>#1190<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 庶</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 庶  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1191"">commoner しょ民</br></br></a>  ""Commoners have to huddle in caverns around a campfire, while higher class people get heating and central air conditioning in a hotel.""<br><br> ""If you are so poor that you are a commoner, you will have to live twenty commoners to a cavern, with only one fire for everyone to share.""<br>#1191<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 遮</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 遮  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1192"">intercept</br></br></a>  The commoners are revolting! We must intercept them on the road before they reach the castle!<br><br> ""If don't want your secret message to be intercepted, make sure your deliveryman is dressed as a commoner while traveling on the road.""<br>#1192<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 席</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 席  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1193"">seat せき</br></br></a>  Remember those poor commoners huddled in groups of 20 in a cave? The only thing they had for a seat was some old toweling (while their lords could recline on luxurious couches).<br><br> ""You're tired from walking the tour at this cavern and there's no benches to sit down on, so you take a towel and sling it up into a hammock-like seat using the stalagmites. (Big no-no).""<br>#1193<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 度</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 度  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1194"">degrees ど</br></br></a>  <br><br> The cave is twenty degrees cooler than the outdoors. Twenty male crotches experience shrinkage.<br>#1194<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 渡</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 渡  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1195"">transit</br></br></a>  ""This particular form of transit is a ferry. Naturally it can only cross the water if it's not frozen, so the temperature must be above 0 degrees.""<br><br> ""The transit system in Tokyo is one of the best in the wrold, but why is it that when it is 35 degrees outside, it is about 2 degrees on the train? Or when it is 2 degrees outside, it is 35 degrees inside the train. This degree of difference means I am always sweating then getting the chills! I think I caught a fever!""<br>#1195<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 奔</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 奔  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1196"">bustle&nbsp;ほん放</br></br></a>  ""Hustle and bustle = a big St. Bernard dog frisking about in a haystack, knocking it down and spreading the hay about, after the field hands just stacked it up.""<br><br> ""A bustle is also the name for the big wire-framed skirts that women used to wear. Here's a St. Bernard dog jammed ass-first into the top of a haystack, looking like some kind of proper Victorian-era lady as he struggles to get out.""<br>#1196<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 噴</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 噴  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1197"">erupt</br></br></a>  History of Pompei: An unexpect eruption and from the mouths of the volcano come lava that threatens the farmers collecting haystacks in the fields and the fisherman catching shells on the coast.<br><br> ""A bit nasty (but makes the whole thing much easier to remember) is to take the right side and call it a bearded clam. For erupt, you can make your own story about the mouth/opening on the left.""<br>#1197<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 墳</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 墳  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1198"">tomb</br></br></a>  After the eruption all is a tomb. The soil has covered the remains of the farmers gathering haystacks and of the fisherman collecting shells.<br><br> ""Using soil and hay to make bricks, the Egyptians built the pyramids to entomb the Pharaohs along with all of their money.""<br>#1198<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 焼</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 焼  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1200"">bake</br></br></a>  ""Ah, there's no better way to bake a pizza than an oven fueled by a burning strawman. And if you listen carefully, there are stifled strawman screams coming from the kitchen.""<br><br> Too lofty (#2095)尭 a career choice for the strawman becoming a baker. "<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 暁</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 暁  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1201"">daybreak あかつき</br></br></a>  The sun rising beside a straw man in a corn field is a classic cartoon depiction of daybreak.<br><br> The first person to see the sun at daybreak is of course the straw man who stands outside all day.<br>#1201<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 半</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 半  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1202"">half はん</br></br></a>  ""Imagine karate chopping the number three in half with a WALKING STICK and pausing the picture just as the first """"board"""" breaks.""<br><br> ""I think of this as a pictograph, there are three boards to cut, the first one is already in half and there are still two more to go.""<br>#1202<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 畔</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 畔  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1204"">paddy ridge</br></br></a>  A PADDY-RIDGE divides the RICE FIELD in HALF.<br><br> ""Think about a large rice field as a big square. Then you draw a line down the middle, halving it into two. Then you draw a line across the middle, halving it again into four... These halvings are paddy-ridges that separate the rice field into separate sections. I dunno the reason why, but that's how it's done.""<br>#1204<br></span>"

He looks at you funny when you hand him a ticket already torn in half. He quietly tears the stub into quarters after you show him your dagger with a smile.""<br><br> <br>#1206<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 巻</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 巻  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1207"">scroll&nbsp;まき</br></br></a>  ""At a mysterious bazaar, you happen to come across something interesting: a rolled-up scroll for only<b> a quarter</b>. You buy it up impulsively until you realize that the powerful spell contained within is cursed by a poisonous <b>snake</b>. If you try to cast this spell, the snake will pop out of nowhere and bite you! Hrmph. No wonder it was so cheap...""<br><br> How to make snake maki: Take a snake. Roll it up in rice and nori (seaweed paper) like a scroll. Cut into quarters and serve on a wooden geta with ginger and wasabi.<br>#1207<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 圏</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 圏  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1208"">sphere</br></br></a>  ""I assosiate scrolls with spell casting, the effect of this spell is pent in a certain sphere of influence, outside it no damage is done.""<br><br> ""[RPG] You're fighting a powerful enemy. Your mage uses a scroll/quartersnake of protection, and he's pent in a sphere of protection.""<br>#1208<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 勝</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 勝  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1209"">victory かつ</br></br></a>  After your VICTORY cut your enemy's FLESH into QUARTERs to show your POWER.<br><br> ""After England's victory over Scottish rebel William Wallace, they had his flesh drawn and quartered and then sent around Britain to demonstrate their power.""<br>#1209<br></span>"

By the light of the quarter moon, the flowers look like clusters of rice grains.""<br>#1210<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 謄</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 謄  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1211"">facsimilie</br></br></a>  Sending a facsimile to the moon can be problematic only a quarter of the words actually get there.<br><br> ""As a prank, a guy sits with his butt flesh on the facsimile machine, inserts a quarter, and tries to fax it to his boss. However the facsimile machine has pattern recognition technology and instead of an image of his flesh, it just transmits the word """"asshole"""". Don't forget it's flesh, not words, on the left side; the flesh image gets transformed into words.""<br>#1211<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 片</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 片  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1212"">one-sided かた</br></br></a>  Fuaburisu's pictograph of a man kneeling and presenting the ring to his future wife is a one-sided version of the story. Others say he was giving her the finger.<br><br> ""Taking the keyword in the sense of only one part of a whole, I see this as a pictograph of a man kneeling and presenting the ring to his future wife (I couldn't see any trees or branches in there).""<br>#1212<br></span>"

He is asked if he is going to talk. Spitting (a drop of saliva) in the torturer's face, he says """"Negative"""".""<br><br> One below zero is a negative number.<br>#1217<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 杯</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 杯  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1219"">cupfuls はい</br></br></a>  ""The maple tree is very negative about it, but the farmer still collects cupfuls of maple syrup from it.""<br><br> A few cupfuls of sake can create a very negative situation. Like smashing into that tree...　　RTK2:　ハイ　一杯　いっぱい(one cupful).<br>#1219<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 矯</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 矯  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1221"">rectify 矯正</br></br></a>  ""Angels have now been given a powerful tool to rectify human behavior instantly, without delay - they have been allowed to drop darts on those who misbehave... spare the dart and spoil the man...""<br><br> ""The darts of the angel Cupid are supposed to bring people joy, but usually just make things a lot worse. Here we see another angel flying around shooting people with the anti-darts (antidote), to rectify the situation.""<br>#1221<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 知</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 知  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1223"">know&nbsp;</br></br></a>  ""I should know. After all, I did graduate from Dartmouth!""<br><br> ""[know; wisdom] [An arrow 矢 like mouth 口] If you know the answers, they will fly like darts from your mouth.""<br>#1223<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 智</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 智  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1224"">wisdom</br></br></a>  Wisdom is knowing everything OVER the sun (fools assume everything UNDER).<br><br> ""Knowing more each day, brings wisdom.""<br>#1224<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 矛</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 矛  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1225"">halberd</br></br></a>  マオ Satan always carried a halberd.<br><br> ""Make the halberd a heroic warrior (perhaps of scandinavian origin) who weilds this polearm - the most effective, brutal and vicious one - with great skill. He can use it to hook, pierce and chop (the three strokes).""<br>#1225<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 柔</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 柔  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1226"">tender</br></br></a>  ""Love me tender, Love me sweet, Never cheat on me. Or I'll impale you on my Halberd, And hang ya atop a tree...""<br><br> ""Use a halberd to tenderize a tree: halberds can chop, poke, and slash, so it's all good!""<br>#1226<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 務</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 務  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1227"">task つとめる</br></br></a>  It is with the halberd he holds that the taskmaster exerts his power over those actually performing the task.<br><br> ""So many video games have a """"boss"""" stage you must pass in order to advance to the next level. Here, your task is to use your halberd to beat the taskmaster with the huge, bulging muscles.""<br>#1227<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 霧</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 霧  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1228"">fog きり</br></br></a>  This fog is the perfect weather for us to perform our task undetected.<br><br> FOG is easy to associate with the RAIN primitive. So think of FOG as a type of RAIN that is slow at the TASK of getting the place wet.<br>#1228<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 班</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 班  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1229"">squad</br></br></a>  ""Am I the only one who took this as penis and balls? In order to be in the man-squad, naturally you need to have two balls with your """"spear"""" in the middle there.""<br><br> Here we have two kings trying out for the cheer-leading squad. A spear on the floor separates their dancing areas.<br>#1229<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 帰</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 帰  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1230"">homecoming かえる</br></br></a>  ""A female warrior returns home from battle. Her husband takes away her spear to symbolize the end of fighting and gives her a broom and an apron. “Boy, this is some kind of HOMECOMING,” thinks the veteran. (Adapted from johnskb).""<br><br> ""Well, the boss man warrior upon his homecoming has set aside his spear. Remember the lady (#1151) (who put aside her broom and apron)? I wonder what they're doing now?""<br>#1230<br></span>"

I suppose robin hood etc would work too.<br><br> I have a BOW made from a SNAKE that I BOUND UP. He sure wasn't happy!<br>#1231<br></span>"

(Real origin of this kanji). Pull and release to fire!<br>#1232<br></span>"

They constantly shoot at each other but never manage to hit their target. But what they lack in skill they make up in determination, and they keep shooting for hours, and days, and months, until it's wintertime and their bows are coated in ice.""<br><br> BOWS with ICE on them are brittle and WEAK.<br>#1236<br></span>"
