"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 著</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 著  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1258"">renowned ちょ</br></br></a>  ""Here I am, putting a wreath of flowers on my love doll's head and pretending she is someone of great renowned.""<br><br> <br>#1258<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 署</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 署  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1259"">signature</br></br></a>  ""Before giving your SIGNATURE to accept the LOVEDOLL, you should EYE over the LOVEDOLL for any damages, then give your SIGNATURE.""<br><br> The ninja's signature move was to paralyse people just by looking in their eyes.<br>#1259<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 暑</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 暑  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1260"">sultry</br></br></a>  ""Ahh, a fine sultry day with my love doll under the hot sun. I think she's getting a tan!""<br><br> ""[from decamer0n] This is the kanji for atsui (暑い) as in hot. If you've ever been in Japan in the summer no doubt you have heard hoards of people bellowing """"Atsui! Atsui!"""" Here you are laying with your love doll under the hot sun. Luckily the manufacturers were smart and when the doll got to hot it would bellow """"Atsui! It's so sultry!"""".""<br>#1260<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 諸</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 諸  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1261"">various</br></br></a>  ""Because i get tired of saying the same old thing, I have lately been trying to use various terms of endearment to my love doll. I think she appreciates it too.""<br><br> ""When you pull the string at the back of Chucky, he will say various things. """"Hidey-ho! Ha ha ha!"""" """"Hi, I'm Chucky. Wanna play?"""" """"I'm going to eat your liver, bitch!"""".""<br>#1261<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 猪</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 猪  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1262"">boar</br></br></a>  ""My love doll is made of special pheremone impregnated vinyl. Unfortunately, a pack of wild dogs mistook her for a wild boar and tore her to pieces. Oh dear!""<br><br> <br>#1262<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 渚</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 渚  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1263"">strand</br></br></a>  I was stranded on a desert island surrounded by water for hundreds of miles on end. I wasn't upset though - I had my love doll! What a great strand of sand to be stranded on - just me and my love doll!<br><br> ""A lovely romantic walk on the strand, splashing in the water with my love doll.""<br>#1263<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 賭</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 賭  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1264"">gamble かける</br></br></a>  ""When we gamble at the shell game, I always win against my love doll.""<br><br> People who gamble compulsively are like puppets controlled by money.<br>#1264<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 峡</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 峡  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1265"">gorge</br></br></a>  ""A gorge is where God has cut into a mountain with a pair of scissors. (synewave,6-10-2006) http://www.travelblog.org/Photos/197361.html.""<br><br> <br>#1265<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 狭</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 狭  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1266"">cramped</br></br></a>  ""In a CRAMPED space, a brave man holds off PACK OF WILD DOGS with only a pair of SCISSORS.""<br><br> ""A pack of wild dogs, waiting in a very cramped waiting room, to get their hair cut by Edward Scissors Hands, who is very popular.""<br>#1266<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 挟</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 挟  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1267"">sandwiched</br></br></a>  <br><br> Fingers sandwiched between a pair of scissors. Don't move or else!<br>#1267<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 追</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 追  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1268"">chase</br></br></a>  ""Maestro, coattails flapping wildly, is being chased down the road by his fans.""<br><br> ""Maestro primative = James Bond. Here he gives chase down the road to the bad guys. I'm thinking of the car chase in 'The Man with the Golden Gun' - NOT pursue (#539). I think about 'Race N Chase' (a scalextric type toy)...there were no pigs in 'Race N Chase', only cars.""<br>#1268<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 師</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 師  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1269"">expert</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""Maestro is such as expert, he can conduct even with a towel hanging from the ceiling in front of him.""<br>#1269<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 帥</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 帥  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1270"">commander</br></br></a>  The COMMANDER is a military MAESTRO who never throws in the TOWEL.<br><br> ""The greatest of them all; Commander James Bond, 007. Here he is the maestro of undressing women, removing the towel from some bond girl. Of course the towel symbolises her last vestige of resistance.""<br>#1270<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 官</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 官  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1271"">bureaucrat</br></br></a>  No one likes classical music anymore. Our Maestro is here at home without his baton sighing sadly before he heads off for another day as his new job as a bureaucrat.<br><br> ""Bureaucrat, def: The maestro without a baton, the one who orchestrates oppressive rules, regulations and taxes on every household.""<br>#1271<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 棺</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 棺  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1272"">coffin</br></br></a>  ""The maestro at home was sick of being a bureaucrat, so he got some wood and built himself a coffin and got in.""<br><br> <br>#1272<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 管</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 管  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1273"">pipe 水管</br></br></a>  Japanese bureaucrats send all their messages through an internal office bamboo pipe system.<br><br> """"""The Japanese internet is a series of bamboo pipes"""" said one ignorant bureaucrat trying to draft Internet legislation.""<br>#1273<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 父</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 父  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1274"">father ちち</br></br></a>  ""Luke, I am your father. Darth Vader (really surprised nobody put this one up before: 2 laserswords).""<br><br> ""Not to confuse anyone, but I think if you put your mind to it, you can see the image of a father here. The first two strokes take on the form of his eye brows, and the third and fourth stroke make up the nose and mustache.""<br>#1274<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 交</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 交  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1275"">mingle</br></br></a>  ""Even though your FATHER is an old man, he can't give up his party lifestyle. Once a week he still dons his cool TOP HAT (well, it was cool 40 years ago) and goes out on the town to MINGLE with the ladies. This is a pretty common thing in Japan, where old motherfuckers still think they can pick up 19 year old girls.""<br><br> ""Darth Vader tries to mingle with his troops. He even weares one of the helmets of the stromtroopers. (one of them laughs: white helmet, black suit. Darth Vader thereby slashes him in 2).""<br>#1275<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 効</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 効  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1276"">merit</br></br></a>  ""Mingling with the powerful can bring you success, bypassing the need for any merit.""<br><br> There is great merit in mingling with the powerful.<br>#1276<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 較</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 較  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1277"">contrast ひかく</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""Our world of today, cars mingling on busy streets, is in stark contrast to the one of yesteryear, where it was people who would mingle on the streets.""<br>#1277<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 校</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 校  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1278"">exam/school</br></br></a>  ""With the exam scores posted on a TREE, the students MINGLED around looking at the results. test. 試.""<br><br> Note: this Kanji does not mean exam. It means school. I find this keyword an choice odd as school by itself is not used elsewhere. Examples: 校長 is principal (lit. school chief); 中学校 is junior high school (lit. middle study/knowledge school).<br>#1278<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 足</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 足  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1279"">leg</br></br></a>  Captain Ahab lost his leg to the great white whale's mouth and had to mend it with a peg leg.<br><br> ""I'll use my mouth to mend your leg, I'll kiss it all better :).""<br>#1279<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 促</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 促  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1280"">stimulate&nbsp;うながす</br></br></a>  ""Mr T, ever the optimist, is trying to stimulate Capt Ahab's wooden leg by rubbing it down. Capt Ahab normally wouldn't let anyone do that, but he appreciates Mr T's stimulating conversation.""<br><br> You stimulate a person by giving him a kick.<br>#1280<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 距</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 距  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1281"">long-distance きょ離</br></br></a>  You can step a long-distance if you have a leg that's gigantic!<br><br> You can step a long-distance if you have gigantic wooden legs (stilts).<br>#1281<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 路</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 路  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1282"">path</br></br></a>  ""When pirates try to hide, it's always easy to find them. Their wooden legs leave distinctive prints, showing where each is hiding and the exact path he took.""<br><br> ""I have a wooden leg for each type of path. One with a rubber stopper at the end for absorbing shocks on paved paths, and one with a wide foot to distribute weight better on mud paths.""<br>#1282<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 露</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 露  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1283"">dew</br></br></a>  After the rain the path was covered with dew.<br><br> Dew forms on the path least weathered.<br>#1283<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 跳</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 跳  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1284"">hop はねる</br></br></a>  <br><br> A turtle with a wooden leg needs to hop to get around.<br>#1284<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 躍</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 躍  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1285"">leap</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""If you're going to leap from a high place, better hope there's a futon below -- otherwise you're going to break your leg at the very least...""<br>#1285<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 践</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 践  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1286"">tread ふむ</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""Pirates must tread carefully when walking on parade floats, so as not to break through the weak plaster with their wooden legs.""<br>#1286<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 踏</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 踏  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1287"">step</br></br></a>  You have to watch your step when moving your leg on a watery day.<br><br> ""So, we've walked on the moon, but it's going to take a pirate with a wooden leg, with a huge supply of cooling water to land on the sun and take that """"one small step for a man"""".""<br>#1287<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 骨</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 骨  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1288"">skeleton</br></br></a>  Your body meat is attached to the bone joints of your skeleton.<br><br> The top box 口 is the skull and the brain 田 has shriveled to the size of marble (but following kanji convention it is depicted as a square) and rolled into the bottom right hand corner. With all the hair and flesh gone the crown has slipped down to the shoulders like a necklace. 月 represents the rest of the body of the skeleton. [Idea for position of crown thanks to n1williams].<br>#1288<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 滑</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 滑  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1289"">slippery</br></br></a>  If a skeleton drinks liquid, the floor will become slippery!<br><br> <br>#1289<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 髄</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 髄  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1290"">marrow</br></br></a>  ""A skeleton is shuffling along the shoulder of the road, so you pull up next to him and ask where he is going. He says he's going to donate his marrow to the hospital because he got into some financial trouble and lost everything; his marrow is the only thing he still possesses.""<br><br> <br>#1290<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 禍</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 禍  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1291"">calamity</br></br></a>  ""Continued from auspicious (#1088). Once a year, the people pray for a sign from the gods. But if the gods are feeling particularly mischievous, they'll send down a jawbone to the altar. The people see this as a sign of calamity to come. The gods think of it as an amusing prank.""<br><br> <br>#1291<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 渦</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 渦  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1292"">whirlpool</br></br></a>  ""Grampa's flushing the toilet, when his denture (Jawbone) pops out and gets sucked down the whirlpool!""<br><br> A whirlpool is water opening its jaws to swallow anything whole.<br>#1292<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 過</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 過  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1293"">overdo すぎ</br></br></a>  ""Jaws 21! Jaws strikes the highway! Man, they're really overdoing it now.""<br><br> In 'American History X' Edward Norton's character overdoes it when he makes the dude that tried to steal his car lie face down with his jawbone open over the pavement of the roadway and then stamps on the back of his head. My teeth still tingle when I think of that!<br>#1293<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 阪</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 阪  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1294"">Heights</br></br></a>  ""If you're scared of Heights, you don't want to stay at The Pinnacle; you are anti- The Pinnacle. Primitive: The Pinnacle is a dream-like gated community at the top of a mount. This allows for innumerable stories for all the kanji with this primitive since you have a whole city to work with. Also prevents confusion with """"mountain"""".""<br><br> ""People are being displaced in 大阪 to make room for a new development, Osaka Heights, the pinnacle of modern Japanese housing. An angry mob of protestors are outside with Anti-Osaka Heights signs.""<br>#1294<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 阿</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 阿  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1295"">Africa</br></br></a>  Can you see Africa from The Pinnacle? I can! I can!<br><br> <br>#1295<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 際</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 際  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1296"">occasion</br></br></a>  ""On occasian, rituals are held at the very tip of The Pinnacle.""<br><br> ""Many rituals are practiced every day (blessing before meals, evening prayer, etc.) Only the peak rituals (wedding, Bar Mitzvah, etc.) qualify to be called an occasion.""<br>#1296<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 障</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 障  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1297"">hinder</br></br></a>  The officer at the gate to The Pinnacle with a giant badge sewn to his chest hinders all visitors. But not the handicapped. They're hindered enough already. They're given a badge and can pass right into The Pinnacle.<br><br> The pinnacle of racism was that of the Nazis. They made the Jews wear a badge on their clothes to identify them. They hindered their every movement. Moreover the peace-loving Dutch all wore the badges so that the Jews would be unidentifiable. Effectively hindering the Nazi plot.<br>#1297<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 随</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 随  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1298"">follow</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""I fled to The Pinnacle for safety, but the demon (trying to possess me) followed me right up the road!"" <br>#1298<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 陪</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 陪  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1299"">auxiliary</br></br></a>  ""In case of emergency, The Pinnacle has auxiliary guard dogs, but they keep them muzzeled until they're needed.""<br><br> <br>#1299<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 陽</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 陽  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1300"">sunshine</br></br></a>  ""A kid is perched on a pinnacle with his piggy bank. He uses the coins to catch the sunshine, and redirect it into people's eyes, far below.""<br><br> The Pinnacle is environmentally friendly. They collect solar power through sunshine on their piggybank shaped solar arrays.<br>#1300<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 陳</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 陳  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1301"">line up 陳列</br></br></a>  ""Every morning at The Pinnacle, the residents line upon the East side for morning stretches and leisure.""<br><br> ""Hikers line up to get to the top of that great pinnacle of the East... Mount Fuji. Seriously, they really do! ...probably the only mountain in the world with a queue at the top.""<br>#1301<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 防</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 防  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1302"">ward off</br></br></a>  A giant compass is The Pinnacle's self-defense system. It points in the direction of any invaders so the city is prepared well ahead to ward off the intruders.<br><br> ""To ward off enemies, the ancient Greece kept watch from the Acropolis, where they had a clear view in all directions.""<br>#1302<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 附</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 附  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1303"">affixed</br></br></a>  A sign was AFFIXED on the PINNACLE of the Acropolis so that tourists would ADHERE to the rules.<br><br> The Pinnacle is firmly affixed to the top of the mount with bubble gum. (adhere (#1000)).<br>#1303<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 院</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 院  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1304"">Inst./institution</br></br></a>  ""The Institution of The Pinnacle is perfect in every way. It is the new House of God, his chosen city.""<br><br> To reach the pinnacle of kanji perfect you need to attend the Heisig Inst.<br>#1304<br></span>"

Story: Here we see an encampment of military vehicles laying siege to The Pinnacle. With other countries being envious of the perfect life they lead there that makes sense. Fortunately, the pinnacle knows how to ward off (#1302) enemies.""<br>#1305<br></span>"

This regiment is called """"Horned Pig Regiment"""". They're wearing Wiking helms and are usually cowered in mud.""<br>#1306<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 降</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 降  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1308"">descend</br></br></a>  """"""Sunglasses-missing-one-lens"""" is obviously the monocle. The proper, high-class way to descend The Pinnacle is wearing a monocle with your walking legs splayed to a full gentlemanly stride.""<br><br> ""After a cool, hip businessman angered the executives at The Pinnacle, they beat him up, popping out a lens from his sunglasses, and tossed out the window, head first, walking legs second. One executive later commented, """"It was like he was descending into Hell from Heaven!"""".""<br>#1308<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 階</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 階  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1309"">story かい</br></br></a>  ""All buildings of The Pinnacle are multi-storey. They don't have much room, so they have to build up. It sucks when someone presses all the buttons on the elevator! You have to stop at each storey!""<br><br> ""Some stupid kid has pushed all the buttons in the elevator. As it stops at all storeys you reach a pinnacle of impatience. Finally you reach your storey, the last one, at the pinnacle of the building.""<br>#1309<br></span>"

The kids at the Pinnacle have a habit of throwing down rice from the city walls in all directions, so people in neighboring communities are forced to wear sunglasses all the time in order to avoid getting rice in their eyes.""<br>#1311<br></span>"

But he still conceals all his wheat at The Pinnacle in case anyone else trys to steal it.<br><br> ""Move the broom with a vulture perched on top, and you'll find the concealed entrance to the heart of The Pinnacle.""<br>#1313<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 陥</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 陥  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1315"">collapse</br></br></a>  ""The Pinnacle is actually bound up by supports from olden times. Eventually, they give out, and the whole thing starts to collapse.""<br><br> ""The Pinnacle is supported by pilings which were bound up in olden times. One day when the bindings rot away, the whole thing will collapse. (tweaking dihutensoa's story to work a little better for me).""<br>#1315<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 穴</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 穴  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1316"">hole</br></br></a>  ""A black hole is a """"House of Infinity"""". Infinity is of course represented by a sideways """"8"""", but here we have a Japanese """"8"""" instead.""<br><br> Billiards anyone? House rules here state that the first person to pot the eight ball into the hole wins the game.<br>#1316<br></span>"

And now it's empty again, as usual!""<br><br> ""If you find yourself in a fight with a karate master with no weapons or martial art skills, just your empty fingers, you should withdraw because 空手 (karate=""""empty hand"""") is more powerful than 控 (=""""empty fingers"""").""<br>#1318<br></span>"

Water naturally collects there which provides moisture for ivy vines to grow.<br><br> The depression in the ground become a trap: the hole was filled with water and covered with ivy.<br>#1323<br></span>"

Otherwise, it'll just explode in the kiln. (If you've never done ceramics before, it's important that the object have a hole in it, or this really will happen.).""<br><br> <br>#1325<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 探</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 探  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1327"">grope さがす</br></br></a>  ""A pictograph of a japanese schoolgirl getting groped by perverts on the train. The fingers of course, a crown (her too short skirt) and the pervert's wood entering from below.""<br><br> ""Note: The combination """"crown +human legs"""" appears seven times in Heisig. In four cases (nos. 323, 1327, 1328, 2920) the crown is above the human legs, and in the other three cases (1888, 2472, 2679) one leg passes through the crown. The naming is inconsistent, so I call the first pattern """"Miss World"""" (who is wearing a crown she won due to her attractive human legs) and the second """"garter"""" (one human leg passes through the crown and wears it as a garter).""<br>#1327<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 深</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 深  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1328"">deep</br></br></a>  ""If the groper's """"tree"""" goes up the girl's miniskirt too deep, he'll ejaculate fluid. (Sorry it's kinda coarse but it works.).""<br><br> ""Thrown in deep water, the Japanese School girl tries to reach a floating tree to save herself.""<br>#1328<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 丘</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 丘  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1329"">hill</br></br></a>  Excalibur is the sword planted in a rock. Lesser known AXCAHILLBUR is the axe planted on top of a hill.<br><br> At Capitol Hill proposals get axed on the floor.<br>#1329<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 岳</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 岳  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1330"">Point</br></br></a>  A point is a extra little hill at the top of a mountain. We'll call it 'Fireman's Point'.<br><br> <br>#1330<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 繰</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 繰  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1369"">winding 繰り返す</br></br></a>  ""After stopping a bank heist, Spiderman is seen winding his webbing around the stolen goods to trap them in a tree until the police arrive to take them back.""<br><br> ""Tip: goods + wood/tree : This combination appears 4 times. I suggest calling it """"furniture"""" (a common type of wooden goods). REF: parch (#215) , maneuver (#671), winding (FRAME 1369), seaweed (#2035). Story: You are winding up your new furniture using a thread to get it through the window of your high-rise apartment.""<br>#1369<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 継</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 継  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1370"">inherit&nbsp;継続 (けいぞく)</br></br></a>  Spider-Man is hooked on rice--it's all he inherited from his Uncle Ben. <br><br> ""A poor chinese fisherman could expect to inherit: the thread for his pole, a hook for catching something to eat, and some rice to live off of. (not concentrating on stroke order, sorry if that throws anyone off). (Adapted from bigloui,12-4-2006).""<br>#1370<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 緑</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 緑  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1371"">green みどり</br></br></a>  Spiderman's nemesis the Green Goblin is in a slump; He's replaced his glider with a broom and is throwing grains of rice instead of bombs.<br><br> ""Tie green thread around the broom that you use for sweeping up grains of rice (ie the kitchen broom) to distinguish it from the other colour threaded brooms that you might use in say the toilet, or the garage etc...""<br>#1371<br></span>"

A stray animal got caught in it by its horns and perished.<br>#1373<br></span>"

He's about to get it out, when you manage to stop the spoon from getting out, so he turns purple, as he chokes, and dies.""<br><br> ""Why is your ass purple? Well, I stopped and sat for a bit on a pile of thread... (I guess it was freshly dyed).""<br>#1375<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 縄</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 縄  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1377"">straw rope</br></br></a>  ""The tortoise has escaped! We tied it up with a straw rope, but all that's left of the rope are some torn threads, and the unbound tortoise is nowhere to be found. (Note that the right half here is not """"eels"""". This is (in my opinion) a mistake in the RTK book, as we already decided in waterfall (#537) to refer to the simplified form of dragon as """"eels"""". It is much better to call the right half of this character an """"unbound tortoise"""".).""<br><br> ""When Spiderman fights the giant tortoise, he grabs a straw rope from the edges of the sumo ring and swings it at his head. However, the tortoise quickly tucks his head back into his shell to avoid the blow (hence no head on the tortoise).""<br>#1377<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 機</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 機  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1382"">mechanism き械</br></br></a>  An abacus is a mechanism made of wood used to calculate how many 'anythings'.<br><br> ""To avoid confusing with contraption (#677), focus on the """"ism"""" of mechanism. For example, fetishism refers to having a fetish; mechanism here refers to having a mecha-like property, where mecha is a type of anime robot that can transform itself. Imagine a mecha that can transform itself between two forms: a huge immovable tree (as a form of defense) and a gigantic marching abacus that smashes enemies between its giant beads.""<br>#1382<br></span>"

Gremlins find water a little too nourishing, as it makes them instantly multiply.""<br>#1388<br></span>"

That's why we use STAMPS instead.<br>#1395<br></span>"

(Imagine just how much honor it takes facing those long lines at the post office!).<br><br> ""In front of the COLUMNS of the Capitol, the HONORABLE congressmen can be bought WHOLESALE.""<br>#1398<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 命</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 命  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1400"">fate いのち</br></br></a>  Pictogram of Emiya Shirou's house from Fate Stay Night<br><br> Mouth meets stamp. Mail the letter to the university and wait on fate…　RTK2:　メイ　一生懸命　いっしょうけんめい(with all one's might)　　　　　　　　ミョウ　寿命　　じゅみょう　　(span of one's life).<br>#1400<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 令</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 令  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1401"">orders れい</br></br></a>  ""(re: dingomick) """"These are your orders,"""" declares the general while passing out documents at the meeting. As everyone started to leave, the general exclaims """"Oh wait! I need to certify these orders!"""" and went around stamping each paper with his personal chop-seal.""<br><br> """"""These are your orders,"""" declares the general at the meeting as he stamps them with his chop-seal. (Primitive: chop-seal imaged as a papal ring, the one's they would press into wax as their official seal. Also a cattle brand.).""<br>#1401<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 零</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 零  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1402"">zero れい/ゼロ</br></br></a>  The amount of people that can order the rain to rain.<br><br> ""Despite the rain, the zero pilot flies on. He has kamikaze orders.""<br>#1402<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 齢</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 齢  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1403"">age</br></br></a>  You know you are fast approaching a ripe old AGE when you get ORDERS from the dentist to get new TEETH.<br><br> <br>#1403<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 冷</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 冷  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1404"">cool つめたい</br></br></a>  ""To keep your water cool, just order some ice.""<br><br> The Japanese boss gives an order at the meeting: eat ice to stay cool (since they won't be running the air conditioning anymore).<br>#1404<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 領</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 領  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1405"">jurisdiction りょう土</br></br></a>  <br><br> Orders are given by the head person in any jurisdiction.<br>#1405<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 鈴</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 鈴  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1406"">small bell</br></br></a>  Some restaurants have a small gold bell to call someone to take customers' orders.<br><br> ""In high society, people ring a small golden bell to call their servants and give their orders.""<br>#1406<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 勇</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 勇  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1407"">courage</br></br></a>  ""I imagined some kind of initiation rite in old China, where every young man has to show his courage. They then receive a chopseal which is a mark of their courage.""<br><br> ""Re: fuaburisu - The initiation rite in question is actually a reverse elbow chop to the brain, and you receive the chop seal if you have the power to withstand it. This initial imagery helps me with the altered chop seal and vertical placement.""<br>#1407<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 通</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 通  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1408"">traffic とおる</br></br></a>  ""I bounce down the road on my pogo stick, easily getting through the dense traffic. (Note: New primitive: chop-seal + utilize = pogo stick. Because a chop-seal is long and thin with a rubbery bit at the end. If it were big enough, you could utilize it as a pogo stick). [Edit: pogo stick also appears in 1409, 1690, 2530].""<br><br> Building on gorgon's story I now change mine to a much more silly and rememberable one. The Chinese police is using a helicopter to check and regulate the traffic. Hanging from the helicopter is a huge chopseal that they utilize to mark some of the cars that are causing trouble on the road.<br>#1408<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 踊</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 踊  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1409"">jump</br></br></a>  The winner of the long jump competition was disqualified when they found he used a pogo stick tied to his leg to jump further.<br><br> ""The high jumper has his wooden leg fitted with a pogo stick, and can now jump even higher. (See my note at traffic (#1408) for pogo stick). EDIT (2 years later): Keyword """"jump"""" leads to confusion later on (see cjon256's post), """"Dancing"""" would be better (but be sure to keep it distinct from dance (#1774)). New Story: I was no good at dancing due to my wooden leg... until I had it fitted with a pogo stick!""<br>#1409<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 疑</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 疑  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1410"">doubt うたがい</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""A very doubtful story: At the entrance to my local zoo they issue you with a special spoon (to feed the animals) and a dart gun (to defend yourself in case of animal attack). You must then hanko (seal) a document to say you’ve received both these items, only after which will they let you enter the zoo. (Oh, and if you forget your hanko, I doubt they’ll let you in).""<br>#1410<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 擬</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 擬  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1411"">mimic </br></br></a>  ""Ask a MIMIC to give an impression of DOUBT, and he will no DOUBT scratch his head with his FINGER.""<br><br> <br>#1411<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 凝</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 凝  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1412"">congeal こらす</br></br></a>  ""I doubt that the jello would congeal sitting on the counter, so I placed it in the icebox.""<br><br> Is there any doubt that ice is congealed stuff?<br>#1412<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 範</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 範  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1413"">pattern</br></br></a>  This pattern made of bamboo is for a new model of car designed to leave as small an ecological fingerprint as possible.<br><br> ""How about a serial killer who's pattern is to drive by the victim and club them with a bamboo stick. Finally he makes a mistake and drops the bamboo stick, which is dusted for fingerprints.""<br>#1413<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 犯</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 犯  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1414"">crime</br></br></a>  Crimes can often be solved using the tools of dogs and fingerprints.<br><br> This crime gang has yet to be caught because their pack of wild dogs takes care of licking off the fingerprints from all the crime scenes.<br>#1414<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 厄</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 厄  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1415"">unlucky</br></br></a>  ""Seeing some finger prints at the edge of a cliff, I wondered who that unlucky person was.""<br><br> Sherlock Holmes is very unlucky: he just fell off a cliff while he was looking around for fingerprints.<br>#1415<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 危</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 危  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1416"">dangerous</br></br></a>  ""You're bound up by ropes to an unlucky person. It's dangerous, because whatever happens to him will happen to you too.""<br><br> ""While rock climbing you are bound to the cliff by just your fingerprints, which is why it's so dangerous.""<br>#1416<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 宛</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 宛  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1417"">address</br></br></a>  Your address should be displayed on your house and mailbox.<br><br> ""For the primitive: This is a hi-tech Japanese mailbox, it automatically lights up in the evening, and has a biometric fingerprint scanner. --- Each house's address, even if it's hard to see in the evening, is like its own unique fingerprint.""<br>#1417<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 腕</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 腕  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1418"">arm うで</br></br></a>  ""Like in Memento, I tattoo my address on my forearm flesh so I don't forget it.""<br><br> ""In Iraq people are having their addresses tattooed on their bodies, usually their arms, so they can be identified if they are killed. (true story).""<br>#1418<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 怨</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 怨  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1420"">grudge うらみ</br></br></a>  I couldn't drop my grudge against him. So I put a severed pig's heart in his mailbox. He got the message.<br><br> I had a little grudge against my ex-girlfriend and her new boyfriend...so I ripped out his heart (like in indiana jones and the temple of doom) and then I left it in her mailbox.<br>#1420<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 柳</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 柳  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1421"">willow</br></br></a>  The WILLOW is the TREE that droops likes a HARE's ears.<br><br> ""A strange thing about the japanese willow tree is, it grows eggs... but the eggs have no yokes. weird eh?""<br>#1421<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 卵</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 卵  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1422"">egg たまご</br></br></a>  The Easter Bunny dropped an egg on my desk and got yolk all over my receipts and stamps.<br><br> The 卯sign of the hare (#2041) hides eggs in his ears for Easter...　RTK2:　ラン　卵巣　らんそう(ovary).<br>#1422<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 留</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 留  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1423"">detain りゅう学</br></br></a>  ""Got a receipt for that dagger, son? If not, we're going to detain you and send you to work in the rice fields.""<br><br> The use of RANSOM NOTE (think of a receipt with a dagger through it on a door) works great with DETAIN. Here the RANSOM NOTE says that the girl has been DETAINED in an undisclosed location. To get her back take the RANSOM to a empty FIELD.<br>#1423<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 貿</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 貿  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1424"">trade</br></br></a>  ""There's a buyback program where you can trade in your dagger for money. But it's quite ineffective, since only registered dagger-owners with the original receipts can participate, and not criminals with illegally-purchased daggers.""<br><br> The new RANSOM note (a receipt stuck to a door with a dagger) from DETAIN (1423) appears again (probably after you went to the field as instructed) now gives instruction to TRADE the victim for CURRENCY you were told to bring.<br>#1424<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 印</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 印  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1425"">stamp</br></br></a>  ""Before sticky backs, they had to staple stamps to letters.""<br><br> ""Aaaagh, this old stamp doesn't stick! Okay I'll just staple it.""<br>#1425<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 興</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 興  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1426"">entertain</br></br></a>  ""To me, this looks like a pictograph of a road leading to the big city (see the buildings?) where there are plenty of places to be entertained. Unfortunately in this city, every store is the same: staples. What tools! [ayoung24].""<br><br> ""Photographically, this kanji simply looks like a set of two speakers (the staples primitives) between the sub-woofer (primitive for same) -- all this as a tool to entertain a group of drunks at a club.""<br>#1426<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 酉</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 酉  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1427"">sign of the bird</br></br></a>  The sign of the bird on this whiskey bottle is of course the Famous Grouse blended Scotch.<br><br> <br>#1427<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 酒</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 酒  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1428"">sake</br></br></a>  Sake is just watered down whisky.<br><br> Sake is the generic term for alcohol (not just japanese rice wine). And a very popular alcoholic drink in Japan is whiskey and water.<br>#1428<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 酌</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 酌  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1429"">bartending</br></br></a>  ""At the local pub, their bartending practises are unusual. They serve the whiskey by pouring it from a ladle, like one would from the punch bowl.""<br><br> ""Ever seen the anime Bartender? Bartending isn't just about bottles of whiskey, it's about ladling out advice.""<br>#1429<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 酵</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 酵  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1430"">fermentation</br></br></a>  The secrets of fermentation are passed to the son who displays the most filial piety.<br><br> ""Since filial piety is all about respecting ones elders, and the older a whiskey bottle is (i.e. the time it have spent undergoing fermentation) the more respect you should give it, the meaning of this kanji becomes clear. If it doesn't, sink back some whiskey and it will.""<br>#1430<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 酷</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 酷  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1431"">cruel ひどい</br></br></a>  It's cruel to pour alcohol down a cow's mouth.<br><br> Offering whiskey to people to encourage them to make revelations is cruel.<br>#1431<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 酬</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 酬  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1432"">repay むくう</br></br></a>  ""Imagine a different kind of tax refund - instead of money, the state repays you with whiskey.""<br><br> Hint: bottle deposit refund - the state will repay the recycling deposit for each alcohol bottle returned.<br>#1432<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 酪</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 酪  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1433"">dairy products</br></br></a>  ""To stay healthy, Dr. Phil told me to have some dairy products with each bottle of whiskey I drink...""<br><br> <br>#1433<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 酢</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 酢  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1434"">vinegar</br></br></a>  Drinking alcohol that's turned to vinegar feels like a saw going down your throat.<br><br> ""I spent ages sawing that whiskey bottle open, but when I got in, it had all turned to vinegar!""<br>#1434<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 酔</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 酔  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1435"">drunk</br></br></a>  God you're drunk! How many whiskeys did you have? 9? 10?<br><br> Whiskey with 90 percent alcohol will get you drunk. I don't care who you are.<br>#1435<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 配</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 配  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1436"">distribute</br></br></a>  To DISTRIBUTE WHISKY during Prohibition you had to be as sneaky as a SNAKE.<br><br> ""In Japan, it's rude to distribute the sake to your self before anybody else.""<br>#1436<br></span>"

Too bad I had to have my anus glued shut from the damage it did to my digestive system...<br><br> ""Red Bull, the chieftain (#2906) is so revered in his clan that everyone sticks to him like glue.""<br>#1439<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 豆</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 豆  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1440"">beans</br></br></a>  ""If I eat BEANS, after ONE MOUTHful I fart like some kind of HORNED ANIMAL.""<br><br> I hate using primitives that are completely unrelated. Let's call this one Mr. Bean! He's an easy character to build stories with.<br>#1440<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 頭</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 頭  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1441"">head あたま</br></br></a>  <br><br> Mr Bean's head.<br>#1441<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 短</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 短  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1442"">short みじかい</br></br></a>  He can't even play darts as he's as short as a bean!<br><br> ""Sort of like ping pong, this kanji represents a game where you throw darts over a table at your opponent. The serve is rarely returned, so the games tend to be short.------------ This character apparently refers to duration, not just to height.""<br>#1442<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 豊</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 豊  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1443"">bountiful</br></br></a>  <br><br> Her bust and bum was so bountiful I couldn't resist the urge to bend her over a nearby table and...<br>#1443<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 鼓</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 鼓  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1444"">drum</br></br></a>  ""Japanese festivals have drums so big, a samurai has to SIT (not stand) on a table to beat one with a tree branch! http://www.d2.dion.ne.jp/~hidafyh/furukawayh/gyouji/image/maturi03.jpg.""<br><br> ""I really hate the primitive meaning of """"table"""" for """"bean."""" I just use """"bean."""" Anyways, for the DRUM primitive, imagine a SAMURAI who beats on a DRUM with two chopsticks, and a BEAN skewered on each end of the chopstick to produce a better sound. And the obvious story is: """"DRUMing on a DRUM with a huge BRANCH"""".""<br>#1444<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 喜</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 喜  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1445"">rejoice よろこぶ</br></br></a>  ""The samurai sitting on the drum is on a stage, and the people below him are rejoicing with their mouths in unison. It helps me to imagine the placement this way.""<br><br> ""In the taiko (drum (#1444)) song of rejoicing, the drummers shout with open mouths.""<br>#1445<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 樹</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 樹  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1446"">timber-trees</br></br></a>  The hippies object to trees being cut down for timber. They have glued themselves to the timber-trees and are beating their drums.<br><br> ""Everyone likes to see big trees fall down. For this kanji imagine hundreds of spectators glued to their chairs, then a drum roll and then a cry of """"timber!!!"""" as the huge tree crashes to the ground.""<br>#1446<br></span>"

Imagine his shock when all he gets is a giant white bowl and just a single drop of blood in the centre and a drizzling of balsamic around the edge. "<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 銀</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 銀  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1459"">silver</br></br></a>  ""Like gold, silver is a metal.""<br><br> ""Not sure why Heisig find the right side so troublesome. My grandma's hairpin (just before long (#1920)) is made of silver, the metal that best reflects sun light. I'm sure you can see the flash from her hair as she walks by on a sunny day. Note that the two elements (sun and hairpin) share not only a horizontal stroke, but also the left vertical one. Therefore a bit odd stroke order.""<br>#1459<br></span>"

Suggest using woman with a halo, as in an innocent girl, something that everyone sees their daughters as being.""<br>#1471<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 食</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 食  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1472"">eat たべる</br></br></a>  That umbrella looks good enough to eat!<br><br> Eating good food under huge umbrellas outside a beach front resort …　RTK2:　ショク　食堂　しょくどう(dining room)　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　ジキ　 断食　だんじき(fasting).<br>#1472<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 離</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 離  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1492"">detach はなせ</br></br></a>  ""I've finally met my arch-rival, the evilest of all villains. Finally, I'm about to fight him. But what's this? He's suspiciously quiet. I move to attack him, and his right arm falls off at the elbow. Strange. I walk up to him and detach his left arm. Very strange. I undo his belt, and take off his top hat... BLAST! It was just a decoy turkey!""<br><br> ""The most ridiculous character ever dreamt up for a film. DETACHO, a top-hat wearing villian who is able to detach his body parts for use as weapons. His most powerful weapons are his elbows, which he can detach, tie together with his belt and use as nunchucks. DETACHO has a sidekick turkey which he uses as an advanced scout as well.""<br>#1492<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 壁</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 壁  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1500"">wall かべ</br></br></a>  Did anyone else used to put ketchup packets on the ground and jump on them so they spattered on the wall?<br><br> ""Primitive for Ketchup: When the taste is too spicy your mouth has basically given up trying to handle it ..or in other words raised the white flag of surrender. But unlike war , putting Ketchup on it will usually solve the problem. Wall(dingomick); Did anyone else used to put ketchup packets on the ground and jump on them so they spattered on the wall?""<br>#1500<br></span>"

Here we have the woodcutter standing atop a tree waving his brand new axe. """"Look what I got for christmas, yippee!"""".""<br><br> ""Axe-man grows a patch of red pepper plants in his back garden.
