"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 親</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 親  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1504"">parent おや</br></br></a>  I remember this one the way the Japanese do: a parent standing on top of a tree watching what his or her kid is doing.<br><br> ""A wise parent lets their kids learn. A kid wants to try to eat the red pepper plant, the wise parent says """"Try it and see for yourself"""".""<br>#1504<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 幸</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 幸  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1505"">happiness</br></br></a>  happiness is the ONE bite of SPICY curry.<br><br> ""This is one of those rare occasions when I forgo Heisig for other methods. 「幸せから一本取ると辛い」 -- if you take but one stroke away from happiness, you get painfulness. (oh well, Heisig used similar one for 百).""<br>#1505<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 執</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 執  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1506"">tenacious</br></br></a>  ""Tenacious-D is happy band led by a round fat man. (It's Tenacious-D time, ya muthafucka', gwaoh!).""<br><br> ""To be tenacious, you need to have deep stores of happiness (so troubles don't discourage you) and you need to be big and round (so hunger doesn't drive you to give up). The most tenacious person of all time was happy round Buddha!""<br>#1506<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 報</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 報  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1507"">report じょうほう</br></br></a>  <br><br> My child's book report got a happy stamp again :-)…　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　ホウ　電報　でんぽう(telegragh).<br>#1507<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 叫</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 叫  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1508"">shout</br></br></a>  ""There was a man in a village who had a special gift : whenever he shouted and screamed, his mouth became a cornucopia, overflowing with fruits and food of all sorts. Many of the locals thought he was a cruel man, always screaming at his wife, until they realised he was in fact very kind, and his gift brought prosperity to his family.""<br><br> You can hold a CORNUCOPIA up to your MOUTH (like a megaphone) to SHOUT lounder. Also notice that the shape of CORNUCOPIA implies the shouts are 4 letter words.<br>#1508<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 糾</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 糾  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1509"">twist</br></br></a>  ""[twist; ask; investigate; verify] Stories full of twists are difficult to write, because of the cornucopia of threads the author has to manage.""<br><br> <br>#1509<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 収</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 収  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1510"">income 収集</br></br></a>  <br><br> Women love men with money. If you have a high income you can get a cornicopia of crotches.<br>#1510<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 卑</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 卑  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1511"">lowly</br></br></a>  ""A LOWLY single rice grain, DROPPED in an empty FIELD, can produce a CORNUCOPIA of food.""<br><br> Lowly people only have a drop of brains and use nothing but 4-letter words.<br>#1511<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 碑</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 碑  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1512"">tombstone</br></br></a>  ""There is a grave of a lowly man with a tombstone made of a simple, small stone. If you bow really low you can read the very small inscription engraved on the stone, it says - “Now that you bowed so low to read this, you are as lowly as I once was”.""<br><br> <br>#1512<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 陸</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 陸  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1513"">land りく</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""When sailors see land in the distance, they first see the pinnacles of the new land, but when they come close enough they'll be able to make out the rice seedlings, and finally the ground!""<br>#1513<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 睦</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 睦  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1514"">intimate むつ言</br></br></a>  I keep an intimate relationship with my rice seedlings -- I never take my eye from the soil.<br><br> <br>#1514<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 勢</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 勢  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1515"">forces 姿勢</br></br></a>  land (#1513) The rice-seedlings still stuck in the soil gather round in a circle. Their combined power forces them out of the ground at last.<br><br> What power makes rice seedlings in the ground grow into well rounded plants? The forces of nature.<br>#1515<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 熱</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 熱  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1516"">heat あつい</br></br></a>  land (#1513) The rice-seedlings (newly freed from the ground but with soil still clinging to their roots) gather in a circle around an oven fire. They need to heat up prior to their journey (presumably plants can't walk if they're too cold?).<br><br> ""Heat up those RICE SEEDLINGS you pulled from the SOIL in a ROUND pan over a low FLAME. (Note: the hot pan image helps reinforce the idea that this kanji for """"atsui"""" refers to something hot to the touch, as opposed to hot weather).""<br>#1516<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 菱</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 菱  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1517"">diamond</br></br></a>  ""land (#1513) Deciding to use the diamond-shaped water caltrop flower as cover/protection, the rice-seedlings with their walking legs (now free from soil), can start their journey.""<br><br> ""Some girls want diamonds, but others will be satisfied with just flowers. However if you think you can win her over with rice seedlings, expect her to get up on her walking legs and walk on out!""<br>#1517<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 陵</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 陵  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1518"">mausoleum</br></br></a>  On top of The Pinnacle is a masoleum for rice seedling farmers. They make an annual walking pilgrimage there.<br><br> <br>#1518<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 亥</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 亥  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1519"">sign of the hog</br></br></a>  A greedy hog in a top hat who has eaten all of the acorns. He even elbows people out of the way to get them.<br><br> ""Top Hat + Elbow + Person: The sign of the hog was a very recognizable tattoo - a hog with a big grin in a top hat, sticking his elbow into the person next to him.""<br>#1519<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 核</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 核  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1520"">nucleus</br></br></a>  <br><br> The nucleus of an oak TREE is an ACORN.<br>#1520<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 刻</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 刻  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1521"">engrave</br></br></a>  ""This famous ninja (I always use ninjas with sabres, distinct from samurai) used to engrave the kanji for his name onto acorns, and throw the acorns to distract his enemies. The legend goes that by the time his victims would pick up the acorn and read the engraved kanji, they were already dead.""<br><br> ""While it's traditional for lovers to engrave their names on a tree in many countries, in Japan, however, it was traditional for a samurai to signify his undying love for a woman by engraving the kanji of her name on an acorn with his sabre.""<br>#1521<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 該</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 該  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1522"">above-stated&nbsp;がい当</br></br></a>  ""I asked my teacher what this strange word meant, and she furiously replied that it was explained in the above-stated paragraph before throwing an acorn at me!""<br><br> The above-stated words are the acorn from which the following statement grows.<br>#1522<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 劾</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 劾  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1523"">censure/severe disapproval</br></br></a>  Acorn Power is the people's way to CENSURE a congressman you don't agree with. Pelt your Senator with acorns today.<br><br> <br>#1523<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 述</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 述  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1524"">mention</br></br></a>  Why are the roads leading through the woods so sticky and dirty? Hmm... I think the forest ranger mentioned something about excess resin on the roads...<br><br> No-body mentioned that there was resin on the road. Now I'm stuck!<br>#1524<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 術</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 術  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1525"">art</br></br></a>  ""Behold the """"Boulev'Art"""" : a life-size section of a boulevard cast in a huge block of resin. Some call it ... art.""<br><br> The definition of art is getting more and more loose these days. Why even some resin spilled onto the boulevard is now counted as art! Hmmph!<br>#1525<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 寒</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 寒  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1526"">cold さむい</br></br></a>  ""A cold lunch: in the house, celery, pre cooked animal legs (i.e. chicken drumsticks) and ice tea.""<br><br> ""Some strange animal tried to steal a stalk of celery from my house. However, it was freezing and the floor was covered in ice, so the mysterious animal couldn't get any traction. Picture a stalk of celery and a pair of animal legs slipping and sliding clumsily around the ice, and never able to leave the house. Eventually it got so cold that the little animal froze to death.""<br>#1526<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 醸</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 醸  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1527"">brew</br></br></a>  ""The Dukes of Hazard brew whiskey while wearing grass skirts (top hats and scarves too). (#1430)).""<br><br> ""Note : up to frame 1530, the kanji share the same chinese reading (JOU), so don't hesitate to group them into the same environment. Here we have the """"brew""""-man, who brews some kind of whiskey using palm tree leaves. Instead of collecting them himself, he just buys the grass skirts from the people on this tropical island where he lives (which you may name the JOU island, after the chinese reading).""<br>#1527<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 譲</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 譲  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1528"">defer 譲り</br></br></a>  <br><br> The islanders defer to the words of their chief Jou in his grass skirt.<br>#1528<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 壌</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 壌  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1529"">lot</br></br></a>  My dream is to buy a small lot on a tropical island and spend the rest of my days relaxing in a grass skirt.<br><br> <br>#1529<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 嬢</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 嬢  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1530"">lass</br></br></a>  ""Conversation at a party: A: """"Who is that lass?"""" B: """"Which one?"""" A: """"The woman wearing the grass skirt."""" B: """"Alas, I don't know"""".""<br><br> ""Two Irishmen visit Hawaii and see a woman wearing a grass skirt and nothing else. """"That's some lassie,"""" says one to the other. """"But alass Danny Boy, you can't be bringing her home."""".""<br>#1530<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 毒</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 毒  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1531"">poison どく</br></br></a>  ""If you grow up with a mother that drinks and smokes, you can be sure it's poison in the stuff you get from her breasts.""<br><br> ""Note that stroke order of grow up primitive isn't obvious from Heisig's diagram: single horizontal stroke is drawn first, then vertical and two horizontals.""<br>#1531<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 素</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 素  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1532"">elementary 素晴らしい 素人 素</br></br></a>  ""When he was growing up, Venom never had many friends in elementary school. Maybe it explains why he turned out how he did.""<br><br> ""This is a pictogram of string theory. Strings are the most elementary particles of matter, which then grow up to become matter itself.""<br>#1532<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 麦</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 麦  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1533"">barley</br></br></a>  ""If you eat lots of barley, you'll grow up to have strong walking legs.""<br><br> <br>#1533<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 青</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 青  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1534"">blue あお</br></br></a>  The last time I saw a blue moon was in my youth when I was growing up.<br><br> """"""Once in a blue moon"""" refers to a rare event. But originally """"blue moon"""" refers to a full moon, in other words a fully grown-up moon. Whether once a month is rare or not depends on what we're talking about, but that happens to be the origin of the expression.""<br>#1534<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 精</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 精  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1535"">refined</br></br></a>  ""Before rice is refined, it is actually blue...bet ya didn't know that!! (alternate....Condi Rice was blue when insurgents blew up the iraqi refinery where oil is refined).""<br><br> Very refined people in the upper classes have skin as pale as rice and blue blood.<br>#1535<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 請</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 請  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1536"">solicit</br></br></a>  ""That door-to-door salesman can stand outside ringing my doorbell until he's blue in the face. There's a big sign on my front door, and the words clearly say """"No Soliciting"""".""<br><br> Going through smurf blue light district - heres a smurfette saying all sorts of dirty words trying to solicit herself.<br>#1536<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 情</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 情  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1537"">feelings</br></br></a>  <br><br> Feeling blue is a state of mind where you're dominated by your feelings.<br>#1537<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 晴</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 晴  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1538"">clear up</br></br></a>  ""Sun and blue sky! Yep, the weather's cleared up!""<br><br> When we speak of clearing up we easily think of both the sun and blue skies. But in another since to clear up is the absence of weather. And therefor the reason weather has no place in its writing.<br>#1538<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 清</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 清  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1539"">pure せい潔</br></br></a>  Pure sea water is always a radiant blue.<br><br> ""Bottles of water claim to be pure. They're generally in blue containers, because blue makes you feel like its that much more pure.""<br>#1539<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 静</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 静  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1540"">quiet しずか</br></br></a>  ""When someone you know who is normally talkative goes quiet, it's usually a sign that they are contending with the blues.""<br><br> """"""And the next contender is.... a Smurf!"""" As you can imagine, the crowd goes quiet with shock.""<br>#1540<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 責</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 責  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1541"">blame せめられる</br></br></a>  ""As one grows up, one typically starts to blame all of their problems on money.""<br><br> ""This is the story of a poor fisherman and his wife. A long time ago he caught an oyster with a small but precious pearl. The intelligent wife told him to sell the pearl immediately: the greedy husband figured if he kept the oyster and fed it, it would grow up and yield an even bigger pearl. One day the oyster grew so big, it crashed through the house and escaped back to sea. The angry wife left her husband, blaming his blind greed for their poverty.""<br>#1541<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 績</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 績  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1542"">exploits</br></br></a>  Spidey's exploits are world famous but still The Daily Bugle's pages blame him for every problem out there.<br><br> [Geek alert] A lot of modern software is full of exploits which can be abused by hackers. I blame multi-threading.<br>#1542<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 積</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 積  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1543"">volume つもり</br></br></a>  <br><br> The volume of the wheat crop is way down this year! Blame the weather!<br>#1543<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 債</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 債  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1544"">bond(finance) さい</br></br></a>  Mr. T's plot of world domination is foiled. Who is to blame? Bond. James Bond.<br><br> [bond; loan; debt] Mr. T buys a lot of high risk bonds and then blames his broker when they all plummet in value.<br>#1544<br></span>"

Luckily, it was just a couple of dents; nobody was harmed.""<br><br> Control is very important! Especially when operating a car. We can take a single cell from a cow, with no harm to the cow. We create a viable cell line from this single cell, and feed the resulting biomatter into a furnace at the exact rate necessary to appease the gods.""<br>#1559<br></span>"

I always have trouble remembering that the bonsai tree is on top, so think of them growing on top of the clouds.""<br>#1571<br></span>"

The viewers have to vote on which bonsai shall remain in the house and which one has to leave.""<br>#1572<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 奉</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 奉  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1573"">dedicate</br></br></a>  ""To join the temple, you have to dedicate yourself to raising bonsai for enlightenment, and cornstalks for sustenance.""<br><br> ""A Japanese farmer who was growing corn tried to dedicate himself to the god of corn (in the hope it would bring better harvests). He had a little room with prayer beads, incense, etc. One day he brought an offerand that he thought would please the god of corn : a bonsai - corn (a corn plant turned into a bonsai). The god was infuriated and yelled at him """"HOW DARE YOU TORTURE MY CORN IN SUCH WAYS!"""". The End.""<br>#1573<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 謹</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 謹  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1576"">discreet</br></br></a>  ""Muttering words of gratitude for a wonderful meal, I discreetly slipped my cabbage under the table for the dog.""<br><br> ""Cabbage primitive: When a cabbage is growing up, you must put it in your mouth before it flowers, because that's when it becomes bitter. Seriously, it's called 'bolting' or something. When you're discreet, you try to make your words like a cabbage: well-layered, but in an unassuming way.""<br>#1576<br></span>"

Sino- (Chinese) people had to put a lot of sweat into learning the kanji. See the drops of sweat coming off.""<br>#1578<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 垂</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 垂  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1582"">droop</br></br></a>  ""For an old man with a walking stick, even a drop of silage to carry on his back will make him droop low down to the floor.""<br><br> Even a drop of silage is enough to make an old man with a walking stick droop low down to the floor. (rgravina - fixed up order).<br>#1582<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 睡</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 睡  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1583"">drowsy</br></br></a>  Our eyes droop when we are drowsy.<br><br> ""Hint : the eyes of Droopy Dog (see droop (#1582)). When you are drowsy you have """"droopy eyes"""". That is, you have Droopy's eyes!""<br>#1583<br></span>"

You sit on piles of silage and everyone likes to imitate old-time farmers with a piece of wheat sticking out of their mouths.<br><br> ""[ride; power; multiplication; record; counter for vehicles; board; mount; join] In the near future, we hope to ride on biomass fueled vehicles. After being sat down in the office too long, people often say 腰がいたい！It's the part of the body that needs massaging.""<br><br> ""To the puritans reading this site - please stop reporting stories that have anything to do with sex! Although (as wrightak said) this kanji really refers to the hips, Heisig clearly chose the keyword 'loins' because it was anatomically close enough, and the primitives lent themselves to an easy-to-remember story. Just because you're all sexually repressed doesn't mean other people won't benefit from a story such as """"the part of the body people need more than any other are the loins"""".""<br>#1605<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 閲</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 閲  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1618"">review</br></br></a>  A little devil at the gates of hell reviews your record to see if you're evil enough to get in.<br><br> ""As I was reviewing for my exam at a quiet saloon, the devil popped out of nowhere and offered to make sure I pass. But I told him no way, since that's cheating. Besides, I'm just reviewing things I already know. I won't fail. But he kept insisting, so I kicked him and sent him crashing through the entrance gates.""<br>#1618<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 閥</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 閥  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1619"">clique</br></br></a>  You set a guard at the gate to fell intruders not of your clique.<br><br> ""The felled souls of the world, cut down like trees, pass through the gates of hell and join the clique.""<br>#1619<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 間</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 間  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1620"">interval 時かん</br></br></a>  ""The interval between star systems (suns) was too large, so the stargates were created to travel between them.""<br><br> We open the gates at regular intervals to let a bit of sun in.<br>#1620<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 簡</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 簡  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1621"">simplicity かん単</br></br></a>  The simplicity of bamboo plant is in all its joints being at equal intervals.<br><br> [simplicity; brevity] The ししおどし is a bamboo device for scaring birds from the gates of your garden by clacking against a stone at regular intervals. Its design is simplicity itself. (Inspired by PepeSeco).<br>#1621<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 開</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 開  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1622"">open</br></br></a>  ""Sure you can squeeze through these gates by kicking them or pushing them with your body, but if you want to get them wide open, you need to do that with both your hands.""<br><br> ""To open the gate, use your both hands.""<br>#1622<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 閉</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 閉  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1623"">closed とじる</br></br></a>  ""The gates are too big to be closed by man. Only a genie can. """"Close sesame!"""".""<br><br> ""You hear lesbians moaning """"オォ~"""" from behind closed gates, and you ask a genius how to get in there.""<br>#1623<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 閣</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 閣  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1624"">tower かく議</br></br></a>  <br><br> Remember the two towers from lord of the rings... each has it's own - very difficult to master - entrance gate.<br>#1624<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 閑</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 閑  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1625"">leisure ひま</br></br></a>  ""Imagine the gates the Garden of Eden, the ultimate land of leisure. You're not allowed in, but if you peek through you can see trees.""<br><br> Getting wood watching lesbians is my idea of leisure time.<br>#1625<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 聞</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 聞  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1626"">hear きく</br></br></a>  Press your ear to the gates and see if you can hear what is going on inside.<br><br> ""To distinguish from listen, you hear someone at the door (gate).""<br>#1626<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 潤</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 潤  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1627"">wet うるおい</br></br></a>  ""Forgetting about the moat, the king stepped out of his gate and landed in the water. Needless to say he got wet.""<br><br> ""(I had the same idea as Dingomick) I imagine some prankster who put a bucket full of water on top of the huge gates, so that it would fall on the king as he came through them. See the king now, between the gates, all wet, dripping drops of water.""<br>#1627<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 欄</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 欄  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1628"">column</br></br></a>  [column; handrail; blank; space] I think about oriental (eastern) Torii gates: they have two supporting columns made of wood.<br><br> A column of text scratched on a black tree beside the gates of Hell: To the East lies The Beast.<br>#1628<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 闘</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 闘  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1629"">fight</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""Food fight! Look, beans are stuck to the gates like glue.""<br>#1629<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 倉</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 倉  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1630"">godown</br></br></a>  ""(Warning-this one is crude) Imagine a godown (dockside warehouse) where you can meet girls who will godown on you with their mouth. To keep the place a bit of a secert, they only have one gate.""<br><br> ""Hint : the """"godown"""" is like a warehouse, it's on the docks and mostly in Asia. To make an image distinct from that of """"warehouse"""" or """"storehouse"""", etc, I picture the goods stored there, piled up on pallets really high, and thus they have to """"godown"""" before they can be taken outside. The front of this godown is a """"meeting of small gates"""", i.e. a row of gates through which goods come in and out. The mouth can be an opening somewhere in the back, or the top, where cranes lift down the goods.""<br>#1630<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 創</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 創  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1631"">genesis/create 創る</br></br></a>  Back in the day the people were so excited to get hold of the Sega genesis they looted the godown with sabers.<br><br> I prefer to have girls Godown on my sabre to prevent unwanted GENESIS of babies............創造　そうぞう (creation).<br>#1631<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 非</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 非  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1632"">un- ひ</br></br></a>  This looks like a pictogram of 3 fingers from each hand trying to open up a crack in a wall. That's an un-believable way to escape from prison OR the UN- have a prison in the Hague.<br><br> ""People in the jail cell are un-friendly, un-comely, and un-cooperative.""<br>#1632<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 俳</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 俳  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1633"">haiku はい句</br></br></a>  I pity the fool/ Who put me in this jail cell/ I pity the fool. (Credit taijuando).<br><br> I pity the fool/ Who put me in this jail/ I pity the fool.<br>#1633<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 排</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 排  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1634"">repudiate 排除</br></br></a>  ""When ordered to go to the jail cell, the defendant gave the judge the finger and said he repudiated all that the legal system stood for if they were going to send an innocent man like him to jail.""<br><br> ""He reached his fingers through the bars of his jail cell, trying to touch his beloved. But she repudiated him and left.""<br>#1634<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 悲</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 悲  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1635"">sad かなしい</br></br></a>  ""Saddness is like having your heart captured and jailed because of some sad or terrible event, etc. Here the sad heart waits for someone to come and un-lock their jail cell and set them free again.""<br><br> ""Stuck in a jail cell with his heart crying out to see his family again, the prisoner has never felt so sad.""<br>#1635<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 罪</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 罪  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1636"">guilt 無ざい</br></br></a>  ""Guilty under the eyes of the law, therefore sentenced to jail. [note: 'UNDER the eye of the law' works in penalty (#833) as well.].""<br><br> ""It is his guilt that is causing them. He is having these nightmares where the great (sideways) eye appears at the top of his jail cell, and is staring down intently at him. Guilt is a merciless tormentor.""<br>#1636<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 輩</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 輩  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1637"">comrade 先輩</br></br></a>  ""Some man jailed in Russia, is freed by his comrade (from the Communist party perhaps), who crashes into the jail cell with a vehicle.""<br><br> (+fuaburisu) But it's the wrong jail cell! Your comrade is one floor above.<br>#1637<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 扉</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 扉  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1638"">front door</br></br></a>  The only way out of a jail cell is to serve your time and walk out the front door. There are no other doors.<br><br> ""An old man serving a very long jail sentence painted a life-like door at the back of his jail cell, hlafway open, with the blue sky, clouds, etc, as some kind of symbol of freedom. Every time the prison officers come to take him they ask him to come to the door. The old man with a grin always answers """"Which door?"""", looking at his painted door with a grin. And the prison officer always answer, sighing - """"The front door !"""".""<br>#1638<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 侯</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 侯  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1639"">marquis</br></br></a>  <br><br> <br>#1639<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 候</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 候  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1640"">climate</br></br></a>  The marquis has absolutely no interest in issuses of climate change. He's old and near death. [Don't forget the walking stick to symbolize his old age.].<br><br> The marquis moves to a warmer climate after he gets old enough to need a walking stick to get around.<br>#1640<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 決</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 決  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1641"">decide</br></br></a>  """"""Decide!"""" """"Decide?! Death by drowning in polluted water or death by guillotine. How can I decide?"""" I asked.""<br><br> To decide if someone is a witch or not first dunk them in water. If they don't drown they are a witch and can be sent to the guillotine.<br>#1641<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 快</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 快  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1642"">cheerful</br></br></a>  A large crowd in a cheerful state of mind applaude each criminal as they become victims of the guillotine.<br><br> A cheerful crowd of insulted aliens applaude as Data's head is chopped off by guillotine.<br>#1642<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 偉</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 偉  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1643"">admirable えらい</br></br></a>  ""Mr. T is certainly an ADMIRABLE PERSON, so much so that parents are buying lockets with his picture in it and having their children wear them like amulets.""<br><br> ""For locket: The locket (key dangling from something, the vertical stroke) opens like a mouth, but you need a jeweler's monocle to make out the pictures within. ----- Dracula survives a staking attempt when the locket with Mina's admirable picture deflects the blow. """"It was an admirable attempt,"""" he admits as he sucks his attacker's blood.""<br>#1643<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 違</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 違  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1644"">difference ちがう</br></br></a>  ""You lose your precious locket on the road to somewhere. You ask people if they've seen it, but no luck. """"Just buy another one,"""" someone says. """"I mean, what's the difference?"""" Then of course you say """"Well, it makes a huge difference!! Since it has sentimental value, I don't want a different one! """" Then of course they understand.""<br><br> ""An odd version of The Road Less Traveled: """"I found a locket in the road, and that has made all the difference."""".""<br>#1644<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 緯</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 緯  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1645"">horizontal&nbsp;経緯</br></br></a>  Spiderman buys a locket for Mary Jane because he wants to get HORIZONTAL with her.<br><br> ""Spiderman on a boat, marking the Earth's latitudes. He first attaches a personal locket to a small piece of thread for ballast and good luck, and shoots with his right hand. After a few minutes (and lots and lots of thread), the locket and thread have flown around the world. Spiderman catches the locket with his left hand, and ties the thread's ends together. Voilà.""<br>#1645<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 衛</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 衛  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1646"">defense えい生</br></br></a>  ""[defense; protection] For """"defense against the dark arts"""" class, you go the magical boulevard and buy an enchanted locket.""<br><br> ""Since it was in the middle of the boulevard, everyone could see she hit the man only in self-defense, as he was trying to steal her valuable locket.""<br>#1646<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 韓</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 韓  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1647"">Korea かん国</br></br></a>  ""There's a young Korean male actor, Yon-sama, famous amongst middle-aged Japanese women. Extremely famous. Read about his affect on Japan/Korean relations on Everything2.com. In any case, women just flipped over this guy, traveled to Korea to see his home, started taking Korean language classes, etc. So, imagine here the misty eyes of the Japanese women as they clutch their lockets with Yon-sama's picture inside watching his Korean romantic mini series called """"Winter Sonata"""".""<br><br> This character represents the flag of South Korea: a locket (circular taegeuk) in the middle of the mist (white background). http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_of_South_Korea.<br>#1647<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 干</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 干  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1648"">dry</br></br></a>  Dry one item in ten minutes on the clothesline.<br><br> Note: the book shows the strokes for potato rather than dry...dry does not have the hook at the end.<br>#1648<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 肝</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 肝  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1649"">liver</br></br></a>  Well you all know that the liver is the part of the body that would be quite grateful if you led a dry lifestyle (i.e. no alcohol).<br><br> <br>#1649<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 刊</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 刊  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1650"">publish</br></br></a>  The newspaper pages are hung on the clotheseline to dry and then cut down with a sabre to be published.<br><br> ""The newspaper pages are hung on the clotheseline to dry. This gives the government a chance to censor the news: they cut up unwanted stories with a sabre. Therefore, only state-approved stories are published.""<br>#1650<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 汗</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 汗  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1651"">sweat</br></br></a>  ""The way sweat is supposed to work: it gets your skin wet, and then as it evaporates/dries, it cools you off.""<br><br> ""When you sweat your clothes become soaked with water, prompting you to hang them to dry on a clothesline.""<br>#1651<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 軒</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 軒  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1652"">flats </br></br></a>  ""Flats in the city are crowded. You get a space for your car in front, and a clothesline out back. Nothing else.""<br><br> Small flats (garages) for cars help keeping them dry.<br>#1652<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 岸</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 岸  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1653"">beach きし</br></br></a>  ""At the base of mountain cliffs, there is usually a beach. You often can see people lying there, drying off after a swim.""<br><br> Three impossibilities for a beach: There cannot be a beach at the top of a mountain. There cannot be a beach on the top of a cliff. There cannot be a beach that is completely dry.<br>#1653<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 幹</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 幹  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1654"">tree trunk&nbsp;みき</br></br></a>  ""A fine mist is falling, and so everyone gathers around near the tree-trunk, effectively using the rest of the tree as an umbrella in order to keep dry.""<br><br> ""By astridtops - In the rainy mist, Totoro is standing in front of a tree-trunk at the bus stop, under the umbrella he just received. Look at him smiling: even when the big drops fall, he remains dry! Great story...which I get to by thinking: tree-trunk->TT ->Tonari no Totoro. I also imagine Mickey Mouse is there too as the KUNyomi for this kanji is みき.""<br>#1654<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 芋</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 芋  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1655"">potato</br></br></a>  ""If your potatos are growing flowers and those little hooked roots, you should either buy less or eat them faster.""<br><br> ""If your potatoes are growing flowers, you need to store them in a more dry place, like hanging them on hooks so they don't accumulate moisture on the floor.""<br>#1655<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 宇</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 宇  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1656"">eaves</br></br></a>  Under the eaves of the house the poor family has potatoe plants.<br><br> ""Very good image Erik. To help those who struggleded with this, the eaves of a house is usually the bit where you hang the roof gutter along, usually made of zinc or plastic and shaped as a half-pipe. It catches rain water, so it flows to a drain pipe instead of down onto people and windows. And in this family the potato plants grow along the eaves so the water pours down on them. They are poor. so no gutter.""<br>#1656<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 余</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 余  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1657"">too much あまり</br></br></a>  You hang an umbrella upside-down on a hook of the scales and fill it with little potatoes. No luck: it weights too much.<br><br> ""This is the kanji for 「あまり Amari」, which means too little in negative sentences and too much in the rest (always with a negative sense). I take the liberty of using the symbol """">"""" (more than, another meaning!!) as the umbrella component, and using two (#2) and little (#105) for the potato primitive. So, this kanji either means """"two much"""" (more than 2) or """"two little"""". (thanks, Virtua_leaf and Thunderball!).""<br>#1657<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 除</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 除  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1658"">exclude のぞく</br></br></a>  ""To become a member of The Pinnacle, they test you on a scale. If you weigh too much, they exclude you.""<br><br> You won't make it unless you exclude something. The climb to the pinacle cannot be completed if you are carrying too much. You just have to decide what you can afford to exclude.<br>#1658<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 徐</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 徐  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1659"">gradually じょ々</br></br></a>  <br><br> I set up a column chart next to my scales so I could record my weight gradually changing.<br>#1659<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 叙</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 叙  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1660"">confer</br></br></a>  ""Amazed at the weight of his crotch, they conferred every honor upon him. (Image: guy with his junk on a scale getting a medal pinned to his chest/around his neck/being knighted, etc.).""<br><br> ""When you confer again 又, you confer too much 余!""<br>#1660<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 途</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 途  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1661"">route</br></br></a>  ""On this route, all trucks have to check in at the scales before they can get on the road.""<br><br> ""There are too many roads, so you need to plan a route.""<br>#1661<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 斜</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 斜  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1662"">diagonal</br></br></a>  The main bar of an old-fashioned scale(balance) will be very diagonal if you place a giant measuring cup on one side.<br><br> ""The constellation of libra (meaning """" scales"""" in latin) is diagonal to the handle of the big dipper.""<br>#1662<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 塗</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 塗  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1663"">paint ぬる</br></br></a>  If you add too much water to the paint it will drip onto the ground.<br><br> A true artisan mixes his own paint from water and soils on a scale in careful proportions.<br>#1663<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 束</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 束  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1664"">bundle</br></br></a>  ""Mnemonic: Bundle of joy. Here I see the proverbial stork with a baby hanging from its mouth fly straight into a tree. Painful, but he doesn't drop the bundle.""<br><br> ""Unlike in 杏, this big mouth isn't content to wait for apricots to fall in his mouth, so he has climbed the tree and is taking them in bundles.""<br>#1664<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 頼</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 頼  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1665"">trust</br></br></a>  ""We found a bundle of severed heads in your room, its difficult to trust you.""<br><br> RTK is a bundle of pages that we trust to teach us kanji (no ライ!)…　　　RTK2:　ライ　信頼　しんらい(trust)…　　　　　　　　Mixed Group:　(ｿｸ): 束1664　速1669　(ﾁｮｸ): 勅1667　(ｿ): 疎1668　(ｾｲ): 整1670.<br>#1665<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 瀬</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 瀬  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1666"">rapids せとぎわ</br></br></a>  You need complete trust in your water guide to attempt Class 5 rapids.<br><br> <br>#1666<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 勅</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 勅  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1667"">imperial order</br></br></a>  This is an imperial order for pizza. To deliver the huge bundle of pizzas to the emperor, the pizza boy needs huge muscles.<br><br> <br>#1667<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 疎</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 疎  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1668"">alienate 疎外感（そがいかん｝</br></br></a>  This kanji is so strange that it was alienated at the kanji zoo. The bundle of joy stork bundles this kanji up and takes it to a kanji foster home.<br><br> <br>#1668<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 速</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 速  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1669"">quick はやい</br></br></a>  ""If you find a bundle of money on the road, pick it up quick before anyone notices.""<br><br> ""Uh oh. The stork just dropped the bundle of joy in the middle of the road. Somebody save it, quick!""<br>#1669<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 整</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 整  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1670"">organize</br></br></a>  ""Recycling in Japan, you have to make sure all your bundles are organized correctly otherwise the taskmasters won't accept them.""<br><br> When a bundle of taskmasters organize something chances are it won't be done correctly because they are constantly arguing.<br>#1670<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 剣</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 剣  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1671"">saber&nbsp;けん</br></br></a>  ""If it helps, make the awl primitive ice pick instead. They're basically the same thing. This kanji is an easy David vs. Goliath story of the icepick vs. the saber...""<br><br> ""Every self-respecting ninja knows the story of """"The Awl and the Sabre"""". According to the legend, a woman once defended herself by using an awl against a sabre! She used to work all day with that awl. However, the bandit using the sabre had no skill. And thus the awl beat the sabre. And from there the saying goes : """"The sabre is powerless against the awl, if one can't use the sabre."""".""<br>#1671<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 険</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 険  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1672"">precipitous 危険</br></br></a>  ""The edge of The Pinnacle is precipitous, so they have a guard posted with an ice pick to poke people and keep them from the edge.""<br><br> Well I have someone climbing an inflatable precipitous pinnacle. Once at the top it is so precipitous that the person is afraid to climb down and instead punctures the inflatable pinnacle with an awl to get safely and slowly back to the ground.<br>#1672<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 検</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 検  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1673"">examination 検索</br></br></a>  You're giving a TREE an EXAMINATION. You take a wood sample from the TREE with an AWL (cmp exam (#1278)).<br><br> ""Don't confuse with exam (#1278), test (#354), evaluate (#1487). Think of examination as a doctor's examination. You're having problems getting wood in bed. You go in for a doctor's examination. The doctor shoves an icepick into your manhood as part of the examination.""<br>#1673<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 倹</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 倹  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1674"">frugal&nbsp;けん約</br></br></a>  ""Mr. T is as frugal as they come. He uses his one ice pick for everything: to eat, pick his teeth, clean his toilet, kill people, cook, etc.""<br><br> The Dalai Lama is a very frugal monk and a fit person for being 73...　RTK2:　ケン　倹約　けんやく (economizing)...　　　　　　　　　　　　Pure Group:　剣1671　険1672　権1673　験1980.<br>#1674<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 重</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 重  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1675"">heavy おもい</br></br></a>  The first computer in the world was as heavy as thousand computers are now.<br><br> ""To me it looks like a car with two extra wheels, like a truck. As it is a very heavy vehicle I suggest an image of a huge mining truck, like the yellow Liebherr T282B. Remember that the first """"wheel"""" is a bit bent. http://www.primidi.com/2004/06/21.html.""<br>#1675<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 動</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 動  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1676"">move 運どう</br></br></a>  ""Even though the furniture is heavy, it'll be easy to move with all the muscles that he has.""<br><br> ""His MUSCLES are so HEAVY, he barely can move...thats ironic.""<br>#1676<br></span>"

Mr Ts new exercise video called """"Work it suckaz"""". Here is shouting """"move it work it move work it!"""".""<br>#1678<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 種</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 種  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1679"">species</br></br></a>  ""After the whole low-carb craze, scientists developed a new low-carb species of wheat, so that dieters could eat it without getting heavier.""<br><br> ""This kanji also means """"Seed."""" STORY: Scientists have developed a new SPECIES of WHEAT that has large HEAVY seeds. Now we can feed the world.""<br>#1679<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 衝</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 衝  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1680"">collide</br></br></a>  Two heavy trucks in a game of chicken collide while racing toward each other on the boulevard.<br><br> ""衝 【しょう】 (n) (1) important point (e.g. on a route); (2) important role (responsibility, etc.); (3) (astronomical) opposition. STORY:Two HEAVY trucks are playing a game of chicken on the BOULEVARD. However, they both missed the IMPORTANT POINT: that they have to turn in different directions. Naturally, they COLLIDE when they both turn in the same direction. (ty dingomick).""<br>#1680<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 薫</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 薫  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1681"">fragrant</br></br></a>  <br><br> <br>#1681<br></span>"

The cabin air and food got to him. (Primitive: these all got MUCH easier when using CAVEMAN instead. ).<br><br> ""If you hang around a third class hospital, you'll get ill with the sickness everyone else has.""<br>#1682<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 痴</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 痴  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1683"">stupid</br></br></a>  Of course caveman is stupid. He doesn't know anything. He's a caveman!<br><br> <br>#1683<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 痘</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 痘  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1684"">pox い痕</br></br></a>  Caveman has horrible pox. They look like edamame beans oozing bight green paste.<br><br> Pox is a sickness which symptoms include bean-shaped bumps on the skin.<br>#1684<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 症</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 症  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1685"">symptoms</br></br></a>  ""Once you have all the symptoms right, you have correctly identified the sickness.""<br><br> A sickness can only be correctly diagnosed if the symptoms are identified correctly.<br>#1685<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 疾</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 疾  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1686"">rapidly</br></br></a>  <br><br> ""If shot with a poison dart, sickness develops rapidly.""<br>#1686<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 痢</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 痢  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1687"">diarrhea げ痢</br></br></a>  ""For a country full of pay-per-use public toilets, sudden diarrhea is certainly the most profitable sickness!""<br><br> ""Caveman doesn't have any skills, so he sells his diarrhea as chili to peasant wheat farmers for an amazing profit.""<br>#1687<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 疲</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 疲  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1688"">tired つかれ</br></br></a>  I picture an exhausted sick caveman snuggling up in a comfy pelt blanket.<br><br> Your body feels tired when you have a sickness. All you want to do is wrap yourself up in a nice warm pelt and get better.<br>#1688<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 疫</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 疫  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1689"">epidemic</br></br></a>  Sickness-missiles are being engineered by bio-terrorists to spread epidemics all over the world. Vin Diesel in xXx<br><br> <br>#1689<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 痛</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 痛  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1690"">pain いたい</br></br></a>  The CAVEMAN felt such a pain after his POGO STICK got stuck in his butt.<br><br> When I was feeling sick my mum said I shouldn't go out to play on my pogo stick until I felt better. Well I wasn't strong enough to stay up on it and so fell over and have the pain to prove my mum right.<br>#1690<br></span>"

I guess that's ok since raw mammoth can't be too good...<br><br> This mannerism is a sickness of the modern generation. It was only recently that we started putting ketchup on everything.<br>#1691<br></span>"

(Primitive: CARDBOARD BOX, especially kids playing with them.).""<br><br> ""Note that stroke order with box primitive is as follows: first horizontal line, then enclosed element, and then a hook (it's incorrect in 4th edition).""<br>#1692<br></span>"

Here, he pulls out his BOX of DARTS, and the child on the examination table squirms.""<br>#1694<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 匹</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 匹  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1695"">equal/counter for small animals ひき</br></br></a>  This kanji is used commonly as a counter for small animals. This is a pictograph of a SMALL ANIMAL'S view from inside a CARDBOARD BOX looking out at his masters HUMAN LEGS. He's probably hiding so the master does not COUNT him with the other animals which will probably be eaten (thus he avoids everyones EQUAL fate on the farm: the kitchen table).<br><br> Imagine a magician doing that trick where he puts his assistant in a box and proceeds to saw her in half. Don’t the human legs sticking horizontally out of the box remind you of an equal sign?<br>#1695<br></span>"

Scuba divers also know that as you ascend in the water, the lucidity of the water improves, too.""<br><br> ""A few drops of acid/peyote and the Indians obtain lucidity on their vision quest, as if they were floating in the lucid sky.""<br>#1704<br></span>"
