"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 修</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 修  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1722"">discipline</br></br></a>  Mr. T is a harsh taskmaster who will discipline you (beat you into shape) with his walking stick.<br><br> ""You may not have known it, but Mr. T is into discispline. Not just self discipline, in order to get into shape, but what he really likes is when the Task master spanks him with her walking stick. Don't tell Mr. T I told you. I pity da fool, and da fool would be me!!!""<br>#1722<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 珍</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 珍  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1723"">rare</br></br></a>  ""The king has a really rare umbrella, it can change shape.""<br><br> ""Tip: umbrella + shape : This combination of primitives appears four times in Heisig, so it may be worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest """"parasol"""" (because it is the same shape as an umbrella). REF: rare (FRAME 1723) , check-up (#1724), measles (#2574), fallible (#2720).""<br>#1723<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 診</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 診  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1724"">checkup</br></br></a>  The doctor at my checkup was expressing words of concern about my umbrella shaped gut.<br><br> ""At a check-up the proctologist views an X-Ray. I say, is that shape an umbrella?""<br>#1724<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 欺</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 欺  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1762"">deceit あざむい</br></br></a>  Kasparov practices deceit by grabbing your rook while pretending to yawn.<br><br> ""Every day, a smuggler takes bushel baskets on donkeys across the border. But the border patrols can never arrest him for lack of evidence no matter how much they search the bushel baskets: they can't find whatever he is smuggling. What was his deceit? He was smuggling donkeys!""<br>#1762<br></span>"

The large wooden chess pieces need to be carted in a shopping trolley.<br>#1763<br></span>"

They are clearly eachother's equal.<br><br> ""These two bushel baskets are tremendously huge. But not only they are huge, they are also perfectly equal in size.""<br>#1768<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 勘</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 勘  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1769"">intuition</br></br></a>  Intuition is a tremendously powerful resource of the mind.<br><br> ""Using Zareon's story for the previous frame """"tremendously""""... The two chessplayers who are eachother's equals are so good at chess that they don't have to even move a muscle. Their brain power does it for them. Furthermore, they don't even have to think, really. Their intuition takes control. This is: extreme chess.""<br>#1769<br></span>"

STORY: The MAESTRO is on the ROAD waiting for a pimp to DISPATCH some new ladies (lower than him) so that he can GIVE THEM money from his PURSE and then DO IT with them. Where is the MAESTRO'S baton? "<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 並</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 並  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1785"">row</br></br></a>  ""This is a simplification of 竝, a ideogram of two people standing in a row.""<br><br> ""Hint : as a primitive I use the image of a rowing boat. In a rowing boat people sit in rows, but also side-by-side (another meaning of the kanji), working together (yet another meaning of this kanji). Note : there will also be a kanji for """"rowboat"""" coming at frame 1876. The rowing boat is associated with the sport, and is a primitive, while the kanji for """"rowboat"""" has a generic meaning of """"a small boat"""". In any case, the kanji for """"rowboat"""" will not appear as a primitive in the book.""<br>#1785<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 普</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 普  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1786"">universal 普通</br></br></a>  People at Universal Studios wait in rows so long that the sun goes down.<br><br> ""To me, row is way too close to file (#812), so I'm adopting Fab's meaning of rowboat from the previous frame. Universal Studios went through a number of logo animations before settling on the one they are most famous for: the letters UNIVERSAL orbiting the Earth. One of the most ridiculous of these involved a man rowing himself in a boat around the sun.""<br>#1786<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 湿</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 湿  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1788"">damp&nbsp;</br></br></a>  You first wash your clothes with water and wring them until they're are just damp before hanging them in a row under the sun to dry. If you don't wring them damp first they will take days to dry!<br><br> ""If your things are damp, lay them up in a row under the sun and let the water evaporate. (thx Raichu)...　RTK2:　シツ　湿気　しっけ(humidity).""<br>#1788<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 霊</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 霊  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1791"">spirits れい</br></br></a>  After raining for two days in a row, you plead with the SPIRITS for some relief.&nbsp;<br><br> ""When it rains, two worlds come together and spirits can be seen in the forest, dancing in a row.""<br>#1791<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 業</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 業  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1792"">profession</br></br></a>  A truly gruesome profession: an abattoir worker. Where the carcasses are upside down in a row that have not yet been cut up into sausages and steaks.<br><br> ""The legal profession was turned upside down when Row vs. Wade determined that a fetus is not yet a human…　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　ギョウ　営業中　えいぎょうちゅう(""""Open for Business"""")　　　　　　　　　　ゴウ　宿業　　しゅくごう　　(accumulated karma).""<br>#1792<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 撲</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 撲  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1793"">slap</br></br></a>  After a row husbands take their wives upsides down over the knee and slap them with their fingers on the bottom (if that doesn't get me banned…).<br><br> ""Here we have badly behaving HUSBANDs, whose wives have had them hung UPSIDE DOWN IN A ROW. Each wife approaches her HUSBAND, berates him, gives him a sharp SLAP in the face and, Three-Stooges style, pokes him in the eyes with her FINGERS.""<br>#1793<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 僕</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 僕  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1794"">me ぼく</br></br></a>  ""Mr. T also finds himself as one of the HUSBANDs, whose wives have had them hung UPSIDE DOWN IN A ROW. But when his wife comes up to punish him, he pleads, “It’s ME, Baby. I wasn’t behaving badly like these other foo’s.”.""<br><br> ""Building on johnskb: Although it goes against the Heisig method, this story is a lot easier to remember when you know it's the kanji for """"boku."""" Males usually use either """"boku"""" or """"ore"""" (instead of """"watashi"""") to refer themselves. """"Boku"""" is slightly boyish and soft; """"ore"""" is rough & tough. Mr. T would definitely use """"ore"""" -- but when he's one of the husbands hung upside down in a row about to be punished by his wife, he puts on a sweet act and switches to """"boku"""" when he pleads """"come on baby, it's ME!"""".""<br>#1794<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 共</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 共  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1795"">together/Noah's ark primitive&nbsp;とも</br></br></a>  ""The character for deluge (#1799) gave me the idea to use together as a primitive for Noah's Ark. Noah kept plenty of salad on board to entice the animals with their animal legs to scurry on board together, two by two.""<br><br> ""The conjoined twins, who are always together, have trouble eating together because one is a vegetarian, eating salad and the other is a avid meat eater, eating chicken legs.[Thanks fuaburisu!].""<br>#1795<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 供</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 供  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1796"">submit</br></br></a>  ""It took over 600 frames for Mr T to make (#1142), the Ark, but when he was finally done, he cast his saw aside and submitted the Ark to Noah for his approval. """"I pity the foo who doesn't climb aboard this ark,"""" said Noah to his friend.""<br><br> ""Mr. T submits a resume together with his application. """"I pity da foo don't got no resume!"""" he says.""<br>#1796<br></span>"

When such a set does turn up, they are inevitably showcased on TV.""<br>#1797<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 婚</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 婚  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1830"">marriage 結婚</br></br></a>  Marriage is the day in this woman's life where she gets a new family name.<br><br> Tip: Heisig later introduces the kanji 昏 dusk (#2451). Story: Never enter into marriage with a woman at dusk (wait until you see them in daylight). Note: This is an ancient proverb . . . (probably).<br>#1830<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 低</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 低  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1831"">lower ひくい</br></br></a>  Mr. T travels to Japan and knows he must bow lower when presenting his business card.<br><br> A person bows low when presenting his business card.<br>#1831<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 抵</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 抵  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1832"">resist てい抗</br></br></a>  Most japanese find it impossible to resist pushy businessmen in Japan when they push their damned business cards into your fingers.<br><br> ""Japan business etiquette tip: When someone hands you a business card, resist the impulse to fiddle around with it with your fingers, and by all means resist the urge to use the card to pick gunk from under your fingernails. Just examine it carefully, ask politely about the (few by now) kanji that you don't know, and put it away carefully in a location that shows your counterparts how important they are to you.""<br>#1832<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 底</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 底  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1833"">bottom&nbsp;そこ</br></br></a>  I put all those useless business cards at the bottom of a cave.<br><br> ""At the bottom of the cave you find a meishi: """"LOST? DIAL 1-800-..."""".""<br>#1833<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 民</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 民  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1834"">people</br></br></a>  All the people of the world with all their family names shouting with their big mouths.<br><br> ""How many of you know what """"vox populi"""" means?""<br>#1834<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 眠</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 眠  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1835"">sleep ねむる</br></br></a>  <br><br> The little boy from The Sixth Sense couldn't sleep because before his very eyes he saw a dead crowd of people everywhere.<br>#1835<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 捕</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 捕  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1836"">catch</br></br></a>  ""I was retreating from the battlefield. In the chaos, my friend threw his dogtags at me to give to his family. I managed to catch them with my fingers as the chopper was lifting off.""<br><br> ""Dog tag: This is a wild animal track device. It has an arrowhead and screwdriver-shaped radio beacon. It's evidently fired in animals to track their movements. When animal has a dog tag, it's easy to catch it: just take a dog tag in your fingers.""<br>#1836<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 浦</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 浦  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1837"">bay</br></br></a>  The water of the bay washes all the dog tags up after the battle.<br><br> ""Otis Redding is sitting on the dock of the bay, looking over the water while clutching the dog tags of his fallen friend from Vietnam.""<br>#1837<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 蒲</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 蒲  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1838"">bullrush</br></br></a>  Bulrush was the flower that you could see near almost all bays in japan before the japanese started putting concrete everywhere. Just check how many percent of Japan's coastline that is concretised... you'll be surprised.<br><br> <br>#1838<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 舗</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 舗  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1839"">shop</br></br></a>  A shop in an impoverished country is just a cottage with a dog tag identifying it.<br><br> <br>#1839<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 補</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 補  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1840"">supplement&nbsp;おぎなう</br></br></a>  ""I usually hear supplement in """"dietry supplement"""". So you're given a cloak for extra fibre and dogtags for extra iron. Keeps you regular and stops you feeling tired and run-down.""<br><br> ""The name and number printed on a soldier's cloak is a supplement to his main I.D. tag; his dog-tag, in helping identify the soldier.""<br>#1840<br></span>"

Can you find it? Yep, got it.""<br>#1841<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 郷</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 郷  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1849"">hometown</br></br></a>  ""Your hometown is where you broke out of your cocoon (born), and where you left when your hair was silver (died), your whole life was spent inside the city walls.""<br><br> Your home town is where you earned enough silver to enable you to break out of your giant cocoon (leave home) and explore outside the city walls.<br>#1849<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 響</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 響  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1850"">echo</br></br></a>  People's voices are like echoes of sounds from their hometowns....you can always tell where they're from by how they talk.<br><br> ""My hometown is a ghost town, any sounds echoes and echoes.""<br>#1850<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 郎</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 郎  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1851"">son&nbsp; 野郎</br></br></a>  The daughter is a good girl that grows up to be a woman. The son is a good boy that grows up to defend the city walls.<br><br> A good son stays within the city walls so he can care for his parents…　RTK2:　ロウ　新郎　しんろう(bridegroom)…　Pure Group:　廊1852.<br>#1851<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 廊</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 廊  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1852"">corridor ろう</br></br></a>  Your son plays in the corridor pretending he's exploring a cave.<br><br> ""(ロウ) I think of the corridor found in the cave that Yoda made Luke Skywalker walk through as part of his Jedi training in Empire Strikes Back. It was in this corridor that Luke met Darth Vadar, cut off his head and found himself behind Darth Vadar's mask. An early little hint that Luke was Darth Vadar's son.""<br>#1852<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 盾</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 盾  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1853"">shield&nbsp;たて</br></br></a>  This is a magic shield with ten eyes which have the power to drag the victim towards it.<br><br> ""From Wikipedia: """"If a Spartan hoplite were to return to Sparta alive and without his shield, it was assumed that he threw his shield at the enemy in an effort to flee; an act punishable by death or banishment."""" Picture the enemy of a Spartan soldier poking his eyes out with a sewing needle and trying to steal his shield. However, the Spartan desperately clutches on, and is dragged around for a while, preferring to die than to lose his shield.""<br>#1853<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 循</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 循  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1854"">sequential&nbsp;じゅん環</br></br></a>  ""This is mostly used in the word 循環, """"circulation"""" (of buses through their routes, of blood, etc). So I think of a column of little Roman soldiers with their shields marching sequentially through the veins of a person, as an anthropomorphization of the immune system.""<br><br> ""A column of shielded soldiers advancing sequentially to avoid revealing the size of their army (Think """"Sandpeople always ride single file to hide their numbers"""" from Star Wars).""<br>#1854<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 派</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 派  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1855"">faction</br></br></a>  ""Drag + rag gave me trouble until I came up with zombie for it. The zombie population became more diverse, separating into different factions. One of them being the water Zombies.""<br><br> ""The radical faction is almost eliminated, sir. They're living in the sewers dressed in rags and dragging their supplies.""<br>#1855<br></span>"

(any zombie movie).""<br><br> ""When the masses are hurt, say in a natural disaster like an earthquake, they can be seen everywhere dragging their bloody rags.""<br>#1857<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 逓</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 逓  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1858"">parcel post</br></br></a>  (I prefer 2 towels over cornstalk and belt) - Have you ever wondered why your parcels always end up in such bad condition when you get them? Or why you never get them at all? That's because you've never looked at how they're actually delivered - each postman is given a load of parcel post and 2 towels to drag them down the road on.<br><br> <br>#1858<br></span>"

Less adjectives!"""" and such all the time.""<br><br> A Grammar is basically a word director that tells us what part of speech each word is.<br>#1865<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 飼</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 飼  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1866"">domesticate かう</br></br></a>  ""After a pride of hungry lions ate the director, the producer decided to tone down his documentary and film domesticated cats instead.""<br><br> <br>#1866<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 嗣</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 嗣  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1867"">heir し子</br></br></a>  The director's mouth dropped open as he flipped through the scrapbook of properties he was about to become heir to.<br><br> ""Careful with inherit (#1370). The egoistic director leaves instructions about what shall be handed down to his heir upon the director's death. First, the director's mouth should be surgically removed and preserved, to be handed down to his heir. Second, a scrapbook of the director's proudest scenes should also be handed down. The mouth reminds the heir that the director must be a loudmouth; the scrapbook reminds the heir of how to be a good director.""<br>#1867<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 舟</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 舟  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1868"">boat</br></br></a>  ""I see this kanji as a pictograph of a two story boat seen from the front. The glass canopy is the body of the boat. The drop on top is the chimney. The horizontal line is the ceiling/floor between the the 1st/2nd floor. Finally, the two drops in the middle are the lights on the decks.""<br><br> ""Cinnabar (丹) colored boat, the extra drop signifying that the paint hasn't dried yet. The stick represents the oars.""<br>#1868<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 舶</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 舶  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1869"">liner</br></br></a>  ""The most famous LINER is the Titanic, which struck an iceberg and sunk. Just imagine that huge LINER strucking an even huger mass of white ice.""<br><br> <br>#1869<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 航</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 航  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1870"">navigate こう行</br></br></a>  ""To navigate a """"boat"""" through a """"whirlwind"""" takes a skilled navigator.""<br><br> ""In Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker, you can navigate your boat by summoning whirlwinds.""<br>#1870<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 般</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 般  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1871"">carrier はん</br></br></a>  ""Carrier?! This means """"general"""" (as in the general public or generally). OK.. Carriers, i.e. boats with missiles, are not available to the general public.""<br><br> ""In general, carrier boats have missiles.""<br>#1871<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 盤</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 盤  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1872"">tray</br></br></a>  ""What do you call a """"CARRIER"""" of DISHes? A TRAY.""<br><br> ""Imagine a restaurant set in Disney's Fantasia or maybe in Harry Potter's university, where dishes are magically landing and taking off of a carrier tray.""<br>#1872<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 搬</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 搬  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1873"">conveyor</br></br></a>  ""When workers neglect workplace safety, their fingers get cut off and carried away by the conveyor belt, which looks like a 'finger carrier' in that case.""<br><br> ""During WWII, morse code was the primary means of communication from sea. The morse code specialist was the conveyor of messages to and from the crew of the carrier, using his fingers to tap out the secret messages. (This works especially well for 搬送周波数 carrier frequency and 搬送波 carrier wave, being the radio waves/frequencies used in morse code).""<br>#1873<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 船</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 船  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1874"">ship ふね</br></br></a>  A boy floats his toy boat in a gully and imagines it as an immense ship.<br><br> ""Aargh, hard to keep this separate from boat. How about this: the phrase """"shape up or ship out!"""" This phrase originally meant that a soldier had better get his act together, or else face being shipped off into a combat zone. Here we see a poor WW-I soldier who has been shipped off to a combat zone. He's riding in the boat overseas to fight in the trenches (gulley).""<br>#1874<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 艦</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 艦  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1875"">warship かん</br></br></a>  ""The warship towers over the smaller benign boats, overseeing their safe path from port to port.""<br><br> A warship is a boat that oversees the seas. Think of it as the patroller of the ocean.<br>#1875<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 艇</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 艇  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1876"">rowboat</br></br></a>  ""In venice, the boat used by the courts to transport criminals is a rowboat.""<br><br> <br>#1876<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 瓜</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 瓜  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1877"">melon</br></br></a>  ""何これ???? ok, sorry to be crude... if you claw at a girls melons, she is gonna give you the elbow.""<br><br> ""Vegetarian vultures are fighting for a melon, each trying to elbow its way to it with claws.""<br>#1877<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 弧</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 弧  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1878"">arc</br></br></a>  ""When you use a bow to shoot a melon, the arc varies depending on how far away you are.""<br><br> <br>#1878<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 孤</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 孤  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1879"">orphan ことう</br></br></a>  An orphan will never know the joys on sucking on his mother's melons........<br><br> ""Unlike the celebrated story of Momotaro the peach boy, no one knows the story of the melon boy who was left an orphan.""<br>#1879<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 繭</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 繭  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1880"">cocoon まゆ</br></br></a>  ""This is a simple two-column manga showing the metamorphosis of a caterpillar into a cocoon. First, the caterpillar gets under a large flower (bees tend to hang around flowers, which scare away other predators). Then, in the first frame, we see the caterpillar (insect). Then, a bar separating this frame from the next frame (remember that Japanese manga run the other way!), in which we see the insect covered with thread, making a beautiful cocoon.""<br><br> ""The magic flower is the reason why Spider-Man ended up miniaturized and confined inside a hood-like cocoon together with an insect. Now, only a walking stick separates them both.""<br>#1880<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 益</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 益  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1881"">benefit</br></br></a>  The benefit of having sharp horns and fast legs is that an animal can get to the food dish first.<br><br> The benefit of being an animal with horns and fast legs is in keeping it from becoming a dish for the other animals! (shaydwyrm).<br>#1881<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 暇</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 暇  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1882"">spare time/right side is ""hobby"" primitive</br></br></a>  ""Some jackass-like people have way too much spare time. You can find video's of them all over the internet, if you like such things, you can watch it all day. You see them stapling their mouths shut, or throwing eachother upside down in boxes or kicking each other in the crotch.""<br><br> ""Tip: The complex right side of this kanji appears twice more in Heisig. He later names it """"hobby"""". REF: shrimp (#2689), haze (#2779).""<br>#1882<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 敷</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 敷  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1883"">spread</br></br></a>  Arrowheads are spread all over the field. The taskmaster profiteerer forces you to find them all using a compass.<br><br> ""Instead of being glued to one specialty (#46) 専, I decided to spread my attention in many directions 方, and be a taskmaster at none.""<br>#1883<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 来</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 来  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1884"">come</br></br></a>  ""You horny bastard, don't come, at least not yet!""<br><br> ""Here I see, of all things, Bambi. His animal horns have not yet come out. (As we can see in the kanji, the animal horns are not at the top, not """"poking through"""". ) Remember: Bambi will soon come to have a great set of animal horns but they have not yet come out.""<br>#1884<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 気</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 気  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1885"">spirit き</br></br></a>  ""Captain Hook, his spirit crushed, is lying on the ground cursing Wolverine who has defeated him with his far superior claws.""<br><br> You're reclining on the floor trying to hook a sheaf with a small hook through the cracks. That you've been doing this for seven hours without success shows your burning spirit.<br>#1885<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 汽</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 汽  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1886"">vapor</br></br></a>  Water vapor almost looks like a spirit but has no soul.<br><br> ""Wolverine disappears into water vapor, seemingly his spirit dissipating into nothingness.""<br>#1886<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 飛</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 飛  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1887"">fly</br></br></a>  Hooks with small wings attached look like hummingbirds with a long beak. Two hummingbirds are trying to fly away with our little measuring box. What do they want it for?<br><br> Two hummingbirds flying into a measuring box serving as a bird feeder…　RTK2:　ヒ　飛行機　ひこうき(airplane).<br>#1887<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 沈</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 沈  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1888"">sink</br></br></a>  The maimed waitress (no head and arms just her legs and trunk) is dropped into the water with a cement crown to make sure she sinks. She shouldn't have been so nosy about her yakuza-boyfriend's schemes.<br><br> ""This is the famous story of Archimedes and the Crown, where buoyancy was discovered. Watching the crown sink in the water, Archimedes detected the fraud and ran naked through the city (human legs distorted from running) yelling """"Eureka! Eureka!"""" See http://math.nyu.edu/~crorres/Archimedes/Crown/CrownIntro.html and http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eureka_%28word%29.""<br>#1888<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 妻</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 妻  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1889"">wife</br></br></a>  Ten rakes woman. your wife digs her fingernails into you and it feels like 10 rakes when she finds you ontop of another woman.<br><br> ""(I'm really not sexist, this just helps me remember the kanji): I make my WIFE do all the yard work, and as a really mean joke, I bought her TEN RAKES for her birthday this year. """"Do the yardwork, WOMAN! You have TEN perfectly good RAKES to choose from!"""".""<br>#1889<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 衰</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 衰  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1890"">decline</br></br></a>  ""If you thought that the dude in 哀 was pathetic, you haven't seen him after his decline. Here he is carrying a stick around in his mouth like a dog, begging people to throw it for him. Note that the mouth is closed only after the stick goes in, as is only logical.""<br><br> <br>#1890<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 衷</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 衷  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1891"">inmost</br></br></a>  The guy from pathetic (#401) shared his inmost feelings with a girl and she rammed a walking stick down his throat. It ruptured his inmost organs.<br><br> ""Besides making money from acting like a dog (see decline), the pathetic man has risked his inmost internal organs by becoming a cane swallower!""<br>#1891<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 革</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 革  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1893"">leather</br></br></a>  You can feed twenty mouths for a year for the price of ten leather coats.<br><br> ""I asked the street vendor the price of the LEATHER jacket. He said TWENTY, but with my MOUTH, I talked him down to TEN. (correct stroke order).""<br>#1893<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 声</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 声  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1896"">voice</br></br></a>  ""When an enemy's flag is raised, a true samurai can split it in half with just his voice.""<br><br> ""Having lost his voice, the samurai comunicated to his troops with a striped flag.""<br>#1896<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 呉</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 呉  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1897"">give</br></br></a>  ""As a present, I gave my dentist a hand-crank tool for spreading mouths. He was so happy since it makes his job easier.""<br><br> ""I see this as a pictograph of an old-style phonograph - a stand, record, crank and bell (the mouth). Even the primitives work out - a tool with a crank which plays music out of the bell mouth. Imaginge giving one of these old and beautiful phonographs to a classical or jazz music buff!""<br>#1897<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 娯</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 娯  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1898"">recreation</br></br></a>  ""A man from a less enlightened society comes for a visit, and asks the host to give him a woman for some recreation.""<br><br> ""While at the dentist's office giving him his hand-crank tool, one of the assistant's asks me if I'd like to join her in the back for some recreation.""<br>#1898<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 誤</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 誤  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1899"">mistake あやまり</br></br></a>  <br><br> You must give words of apology when you make a mistake.<br>#1899<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 蒸</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 蒸  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1900"">steam</br></br></a>  <br><br> Note: complete + water + floor are later combined into 丞 helping hand (#2919). Story: The driver of a steam train asks you for a helping hand and explains that your job is to throw flowers on the fire to make the steam.<br>#1900<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 承</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 承  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1901"">acquiesce</br></br></a>  To get someone to completely acquiesce it takes 3 dunks in the water before they give.<br><br> ""To get someone to acquiesce, duck them completely in aqua (=water) three times. (variation on dingomick's).""<br>#1901<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 函</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 函  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1902"">bin はこ</br></br></a>  Damn racoons ill show them. I put a snare in the bin as well as a few phosphorous sparklers so as to scare the shit out of the buggers as they rummage through my bin.<br><br> ""(thegeezer3) Damn racoons... I'll show them. I'll put a SNARE in the BIN as well as a few SPARKLERS so as to scare the shit out of the buggers, then hit them with a SHOVEL.""<br>#1902<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 極</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 極  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1903"">poles&nbsp;きょく</br></br></a>  ""Can simplify this using decay (#1243). Then: The expedition to the poles is bad for your health, and the decay that started in your mouth spreads to your crotch – at which point you fall to the floor.""<br><br> ""(modified Katsuo) Can simplify this using decay (#1243). You travel to the poles, a frozen wasteland. In desperate need of food you try to set up a snare but the tree is decayed (see story for decay (#1243)) so you catch no prey. The brutal cold first attacks your mouth as your lips turn blue, then your crotch also gets cold as your body fails; finally you fall to the floor.""<br>#1903<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 牙</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 牙  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1904"">tusk</br></br></a>  ""He stored the tusks into a box, along with the broken halberds.""<br><br> The kanji looks like an elephant with tusks. the box is the elephant's eye. The final stroke is the tusk.<br>#1904<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 芽</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 芽  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1905"">bud め</br></br></a>  Zoo keepers are baffled as to why the tips of the elephant's tusks keep budding into flowers.<br><br> Buds while they're still small tend to be tusk-shaped.<br>#1905<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 邪</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 邪  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1906"">wicked&nbsp;よこしま</br></br></a>  The wicked queen builds her city walls out of menacing tusks.<br><br> ""As everyone knows, rhinoceroses and elephants are often killed for the value of their TUSKS. Here we see a WICKED city mayor who has had countless elephants killed just to make his CITY WALLS out of TUSKS.""<br>#1906<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 雅</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 雅  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1907"">gracious/elegant</br></br></a>  """"""Goodness gracious! Such an elegant turkey with a tusk."""" This mnemonic is meant to join RtK's keyword with a better proposition. Heisig could have used """"elegant"""" here, which is not confounded so easily with graceful (#721), and accurately represents the character's meaning (it is also the chosen keyword in Kodansha's Kanji Learner's Dictionary).""<br><br> <br>#1907<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 釈</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 釈  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1908"">explanation</br></br></a>  ""Mrs. Badger follows the animal tracks to the den where she finds her husband getting a blowjob from a fox. """"I have a good explanation for this. Really!"""".""<br><br> ""Animal track primitive: As expected, animal tracks were left in place of the trail of rice I'd purposely dropped the night before. EDIT - also try the footprint for a primitive meaning, the classic symbol of detective films. STORY: This shakuhachi player is so talented, he can do interpretations of animal noises too. They're so realistic he soon has animal tracks leading straight to wherever he's playing.""<br>#1908<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 番</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 番  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1909"">turn いちばん</br></br></a>  The famers take it in turns to watch out for any animal tracks on their rice field.<br><br> They take turns alternating between wheat and rice in this field…　　RTK2:　バン　電話番号　でんわばんごう(telephone number).<br>#1909<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 長</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 長  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1920"">long ながい</br></br></a>  The Geisha with long hair uses an ornate lacquered hairpin to bundle it all up.<br><br> ""The top of this one reminds me of the staple primitive. So here's my story: The girl's hair was so long that she had to use staples instead of hairpins. It worked, but stapling her hair to her head was kinda painful.""<br>#1920<br></span>"

"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 喪</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 喪  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1926"">miss</br></br></a>  ""I miss my parents dearly. Here they lay, under a big cross, their mouths side by side. I stick hairpins in their graves. CAREFUL: the stroke order/primitive order is: ten, L mouth, R mouth, hairpin. """"Soil"""" is not drawn in its stroke order.""<br><br> ""This kanji means miss as in """"miss a (dearly departed) person"""", not as in """"miss a target"""".　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　Here the dearly departed has been buried in the ground, with her favourite hairpin in place of a gravestone, and two mourners stand around crying with open mouths.""<br>#1926<br></span>"
"<span style=""font-family: TakaoPGothic; font-size: 150px; ""> 巣</span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; "">"	"<span style=""font-family: KanjiStrokeOrders; font-size: 150px; ""> 巣  </span><br><span style=""font-family: Mincho; font-size: 22px; ""> <a href=""http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1927"">nest</br></br></a>  Owls only nest in fruit trees.<br><br> ""The wise old OWL makes her nest out of FRUIT, carving out the middle for her chicks, because then it's less work: no running back & forth to get food!""<br>#1927<br></span>"

It sees so many potential animals to eat but since it only has one mouth, it decides that the tasty looking chihuahua will be its meal for tonight. (adapted from Copycatken,1-9-2006).""<br><br> ""I have a strange story for this one but it works. I imagine a owl getting into a rice field which serves as a boxing ring. His opponent is a little chihuahua. The fight starts, the owl takes one punch to the mouth and is out cold. In the chihuahua's corner is that coach from Rocky saying """"Your an ANIMAL!!"""". A vivid image of this story works pretty well for me.""<br>#1933<br></span>"
